given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
"a capricious and often brutal administration"
He judged her to be capricious, and easily weary of the pleasure of the moment.他认为她是任性的，很容易对一时的快乐产生厌倦。

cascade

[kæ'skeɪd], [kæ'skeɪd]


Image Search
n. 瀑布；[电]串联
v. 瀑布似地落下；（将 ... ）连结；串联
a small waterfall, typically one of several that fall in stages down a steep rocky slope.
a mass of something that falls or hangs in copious or luxuriant quantities.
a large number or amount of something occurring or arriving in rapid succession.
a process whereby something, typically information or knowledge, is successively passed on.
a succession of devices or stages in a process, each of which triggers or initiates the next.
(of water) pour downward rapidly and in large quantities.
fall or hang in copious or luxuriant quantities.
arrange (a number of devices or objects) in a series or sequence.
"a cascade of pink bougainvillea"
"a cascade of antiwar literature"
"the greater the number of people who are well briefed, the wider the cascade effect"
"water was cascading down the stairs"
"blonde hair cascaded down her back"
The water formed a cascade down the mountain.水沿山泻下，形成一条瀑布。
Climbing plants with their bright flowers hung in cascades over the garden wall.开出鲜艳花朵的爬藤植物瀑布般悬挂在花园墙上。
When it rained, water would cascade down the window.下雨的时候，雨水像瀑布一样沿着窗沿泻下。
We can cascade them to determine their overall effect.我们可以将它们串联起来确定它们的总体影响。

category

['kætəɡəri], ['kætəɡɔːri]


Image Search
n. 种类；类别；范畴
a class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics.
one of a possibly exhaustive set of classes among which all things might be distributed.
one of the a priori conceptions applied by the mind to sense impressions.
"five categories of intelligence"
There are different categories of books in a library.图书馆里有各种不同种类的书籍。
They fall into different categories.他们属于不同的类别。
They misplaced this book under another category.他们把它错放到另一个类别去了。
How can a scientific category have its derivatives?科学范畴何以能衍生?
His research does not belong to the category of natural science.他的研究不属于自然科学范畴。

cater

['keɪtə(r)], ['keɪtər]


Image Search
v. 提供饮食及服务；迎合；满足
provide food and drink, typically at social events and in a professional capacity.
provide with food and drink in a professional capacity.
provide with what is needed or required.
try to satisfy (a particular need or demand).
"he catered a lunch for 20 people"
"my mother helped to cater for the party"
"the school caters to children with learning difficulties"
"he catered to her every whim"
Our hotel also caters for weddings and parties.本饭店也承办婚礼、宴会。
These hotels cater especially to foreign tourists.这些旅馆专门为外国游客提供服务。
They only publish novels which cater to the mass market.他们只出版迎合大众市场的小说。
TV programs must cater for many different tastes.电视节目必须满足观众的不同爱好。

cauliflower

['kɒliflaʊə(r)], ['kɔːliflaʊər]


Image Search
n. 花椰菜
a cabbage of a variety that bears a large immature flower head of small creamy-white flower buds.
the flower head of the cauliflower plant eaten as a vegetable.
I'll have the fillet of beef then,with cauliflower.那么我要牛肉片炒花椰菜。
Cauliflower is my favorite vegetable.花椰菜是我最喜欢的蔬菜。

cautious

['kɔːʃəs], ['kɔːʃəs]


Image Search
adj. 谨慎的；十分小心的
(of a person) careful to avoid potential problems or dangers.
(of an action) characterized by the desire to avoid potential problems.
"a cautious driver"
"the plan received a cautious welcome"
She is cautious of telling secrets.她很谨慎，不会泄露秘密。
He is cautious in his choice of words.他措辞很谨慎。
They've taken a very cautious approach.他们采取了十分谨慎的态度。
The old lady is very cautious with money.那位老太太用钱很谨慎。
I should be cautious not to give offence.我应该小心不要得罪人。

cavernous

['kævənəs], ['kævərnəs]


Image Search
adj. 似巨穴的；多洞穴的
like a cavern in size, shape, or atmosphere.
giving the impression of vast, dark depths.
"a cavernous warehouse"
"his cavernous eyes"
According to some accounts, Mithras died, was buried in a cavernous rock tomb, and was resurrected.根据一些传说,密特拉神死后被埋在一个似巨穴的岩石坟墓,然后复活。
Suddenly there was a commotion in the rear of the cavernous room.突然,在那间多出口的房间背后一阵骚动。

cede

[siːd], [siːd]


Image Search
v. 割让(领土；权利)
v. 放弃
give up (power or territory).
"they have had to cede control of the schools to the government"
That is what the regime fears most, because then it either has to shoot its own people or cede power.这是当前伊朗政权最害怕的，因为到那时只能被迫选择开枪射击自己的人们，或放弃权力。
This second step will be awkward, because votes cannot be taken from members that do not want to cede them.第二步会比较麻烦，因为投票权并不能从那些不愿放弃他们的成员那里拿过来。

celery

['seləri], ['seləri]


Image Search
n. 芹菜
a cultivated plant of the parsley family, with closely packed succulent leafstalks that are eaten raw or cooked.
He was eating a stick of celery.他正在吃一根芹菜。
The chidren crunched the celery sticks.孩子们大声地咀嚼着芹菜梗。
We have spinach, Chinese cabbage, onion and celery.有菠菜、大白菜、洋葱和芹菜。

celestial

[sə'lestiəl], [sə'lestʃl]


Image Search
adj. 天上的；非凡的
n. 天神
Celestial.
adj. 中国的；中国人的
n. 中国人
positioned in or relating to the sky, or outer space as observed in astronomy.
belonging or relating to heaven.
supremely good.
"a celestial body"
"the celestial city"
"the celestial beauty of music"
The rosy light yet beamed like a celestial dawn.玫瑰色的红光依然象天上的朝霞一样绚丽。
She is a celestial bodhisattva and an ascended master.她是天上的菩萨和已提升的大师。
And if living in the lower celestial and Brahma realms, their heads are always turned towards the higher planes of those worlds.虽然他们还在低层的天神界以及梵天界，从那时起，就会转生较高级的天神界以及梵天界。

censor

['sensə(r)], ['sensər]


Image Search
n. 检查员；监察官
vt. 检查
an official who examines material that is about to be released, such as books, movies, news, and art, and suppresses any parts that are considered obscene, politically unacceptable, or a threat to security.
an aspect of the superego that is said to prevent certain ideas and memories from emerging into consciousness.
(in ancient Rome) either of two magistrates who held censuses and supervised public morals.
examine (a book, movie, etc.) officially and suppress unacceptable parts of it.
"my mail was being censored"
They had to accept the blue pencil of the censor.他们不得不接受检查员的修改。
Don't write anything that will bother the censor.你可别写什么给检查员找麻烦的话。
A white censor was standing over me.有一个白人监察官在监视着我。
The censor insisted on excising the passage from the film.电影审查员坚持剪去影片的这一段。
It is not constitutional to censor the press.审查新闻是违反宪法的。

chagrin

['ʃæɡrɪn], [ʃə'ɡrɪn]


Image Search
n. 懊恼
v. 使 ... 懊恼
distress or embarrassment at having failed or been humiliated.
feel distressed or humiliated.
"Jeff, much to his chagrin, wasn't invited"
"he was chagrined when his friend poured scorn on him"
Much to his chagrin, he do not win the race.他没能赢那场比赛，大为懊丧。
He noted with chagrin how little hair clung to his head.他苦恼地发现原来他头上的毛发是那么的稀疏。

chasm

['kæzəm], ['kæzəm]


Image Search
n. 分歧；深坑；裂口
a deep fissure in the earth, rock, or another surface.
a profound difference between people, viewpoints, feelings, etc.
"the chasm between rich and poor"
There is always a vast chasm between rich and poor.贫富的鸿沟始终存在。
The chasm between you and he can not be solved by us.你和他之间的裂痕不是我们能解决的。
There is a chasm between the professor and the schoolmaster.教授和校长之间出现了分歧。
Suddenly a huge chasm opened in the earth.大地突然裂开，形成一道深坑。
We come now to a place in the path where there is a chasm.我们现在来到半途中的一个峡谷。
This new writer was totally unware of the chasm in the story.这个写作新手完全没意识到故事中的脱节处。

chasten

['tʃeɪsn], ['tʃeɪsn]


Image Search
vt. (通过惩罚而使坏习惯等)改正、磨炼
(of a reproof or misfortune) have a restraining or moderating effect on.
(especially of God) discipline; punish.
"the director was somewhat chastened by his recent flops"
I have learned a lot from the chastening experience.我从这个可以引以为戒的经历中学到了很多。
He was chastened by his failure.他因失败而得到了教训。

cheddar

['tʃedə(r)], ['tʃedər]


Image Search
n. 干酪的一种
a kind of firm smooth cheese, originally made in Cheddar in southern England.
A hard cheese similar to Cheddar and usually orange.莱斯特干酪类似于切达干酪的一种干奶酪，通常为黄色

cheese

[tʃiːz], [tʃiːz]


Image Search
n. 干酪；乳酪；奶酪
vt. 使停止
a food made from the pressed curds of milk.
a complete molded mass of cheese with its rind, often in a round flat shape.
a round flat object resembling a cheese.
the quality of being too obviously sentimental.
an important person.
exasperate, frustrate, or bore.
"grated cheese"
"a 50-pound, muslin-wrapped cheese"
"the conversations tend too far toward cheese"
"he was a big cheese in the business world"
"that really cheesed off Ricky"
This cheese is rather bland.这干酪没什么味道。
The cheese was emitting a strong smell.干酪散发出强烈的气味。
Just have a taste of this cheese!尝一点儿这种乳酪吧！
Cheese often upsets her stomach.她吃乳酪後常常感到肠胃不适。
There are many kinds of cheese.奶酪有许多种。
We had a homely meal of bread and cheese.我们吃了一顿面包加乳酪的家常便餐。
I had a frugal meal of bread and cheese last night.我昨晚吃了只有面包和奶酪的便餐。
Cheese it, or you'll have the ceiling down.别吵了，否则天花板就要给你们吵下来了。

chili pepper


Image Search
a small hot-tasting pod of a variety of capsicum, used chopped (and often dried) in sauces, relishes, and spice powders. There are various forms with pods of differing size, color, and strength of flavor, such as cascabels and jalapeños.
short for chili powder.
short for chili con carne.
This variety of red pepper is especially hot.这种红辣椒特别辣。
A handful of freshly picked chili peppers may look harmless.一把新摘的红辣椒看起来好象没有什么杀伤力。

chilly

['tʃɪli], ['tʃɪli]


Image Search
adj. 寒冷的；冷淡的
n. 干辣椒
uncomfortably cool or cold.
(of a person) feeling cold.
unfriendly.
"it had turned chilly"
"I felt a bit chilly"
"a chilly reception"
It's a chilly morning.这是一个寒冷的早晨。
A gust of chilly autumn wind is blowing from the north.一阵冷飕飕的秋风从北方吹来。
It often happens that a balmy morning passes into a chilly afternoon.一个温和的上午常常转为一个寒冷的下午。
The visitors got a very chilly reception.客人受到了非常冷淡的接待。
He had a chilly welcome of our coming.他冷淡地迎接我们的到来。

chronic

['krɒnɪk], ['krɑːnɪk]


Image Search
adj. 长期的；慢性的；惯常的
(of an illness) persisting for a long time or constantly recurring.
(of a person) having an illness persisting for a long time or constantly recurring.
(of a problem) long-lasting and difficult to eradicate.
(of a person) having a particular bad habit.
"chronic bronchitis"
"a chronic asthmatic"
"the school suffers from chronic overcrowding"
"a chronic liar"
There is a chronic unemployment problem in America.在美国存在长期失业问题。
We finally won in this chronic war.我们终于打赢了这场长期战争。
My brother has chronic bronchitis.我的哥哥患有慢性支气管炎。
Have you got any chronic diseases in the past?你过去有没有慢性病?
The school put us on notice for chronic lateness.因经常迟到学校将我们的名字公布在公告栏上。

chronicle

['krɒnɪkl], ['krɑːnɪkl]


Image Search
n. 年代记；记录；编年史
a factual written account of important or historical events in the order of their occurrence.
a work of fiction or nonfiction that describes a particular series of events.
record (a related series of events) in a factual and detailed way.
"his work chronicles 20th-century displacement and migration"
Since I will start building a brand new workstation pretty soon, I've decided to chronicle my experience.既然我将很快搭建一个全新的工作站，我决定记录下这一过程。
The subscription rule was canceled because an event chronicle rule that it depends on failed.由于所依赖的事件历史记录规则失败，订阅规则被取消。
Every mouldering stone was a chronicle.每块崩碎剥落的石头都是一部编年史。
The chronicle breaks down into four parts.这部编年史分成四部分。

cinch

[sɪntʃ], [sɪntʃ]


Image Search
n. (马的)肚带；容易做的事情；必然发生的事情
v. 系肚带；确保
an extremely easy task.
a sure thing; a certainty.
a girth for a Western saddle or pack.
secure (a garment) with a belt.
fix (a saddle) securely by means of a girth; girth up (a horse).
make certain of.
"the program was a cinch to use"
"he was a cinch to take a prize"
"his advice cinched her decision to accept the offer"
That horse is a cinch to win the next race.那匹马在下一场比赛中肯定赢。
That's a cinch for me.那对我来说太容易了。

circumstances

['sɜːkəmstənsɪz], ['sɜːkəmstənsɪz]


Image Search
n. 情况；境遇；事项；详细情节
名词circumstance的复数形式.
a fact or condition connected with or relevant to an event or action.
an event or fact that causes or helps to cause something to happen, typically something undesirable.
one's state of financial or material welfare.
"we wanted to marry but circumstances didn't permit"
"he was found dead but there were no suspicious circumstances"
"the artists are living in reduced circumstances"
Circumstances have compelled a change of plan.因情况所迫，计划已经改变。
Maybe under these circumstances we may say that man can conquer nature.也许在这样的情况下我们可以说人定胜天。
He is in bad, distressed circumstances.他境遇贫困，生活痛苦。
Circumstances combined early to make her view the world as a vale of tears.种种境遇使她很早就认为这世间苦难无边。
She writes with circumstances.她写得很详细。

clam

[klæm], [klæm]


Image Search
n. 蛤；沉默寡言的人
vi. 保持沉默；挖蚌
a marine bivalve mollusk with shells of equal size.
any of a number of edible bivalve mollusks, e.g., a scallop.
a dollar.
a shy or withdrawn person.
dig for or collect clams.
abruptly stop talking, either for fear of revealing a secret or from shyness.
"all I got for the job was 50 lousy clams"
"it was one of the worst times for clamming"
Yup! I also like clam soup and sea cucumbers.对呀！我还喜欢蛤仔汤和海参。
Everybody shut up like a clam as soon as you mention it.你一提及此事，大家便都闭口不言
He is a clam about his business dealing.他对自己的生意买卖守口如瓶。
It started off well, but he seemed to clam up towards the end.刚开始很，但是最后他似乎有些沉默。
I used to clam up when the talk turned to politics or economics当话题转到政治或经济问题时，我常沉默不语。

clarity

['klærəti], ['klærəti]


Image Search
n. 清楚；透明
the quality of being clear, in particular.
the quality of coherence and intelligibility.
the quality of being easy to see or hear; sharpness of image or sound.
the quality of being certain or definite.
the quality of transparency or purity.
"for the sake of clarity, each of these strategies is dealt with separately"
"the clarity of the picture"
"it was clarity of purpose that he needed"
"the crystal clarity of water"
These adjectives mean lacking clarity of meaning.这些形容词都有意思不清楚的含义。
Let me try to provide some clarity.让我提供一些清楚的信息。
Clarity is very important for a business letter.文笔清晰对于商业信件非常重要。
Clarity of dictionis vital for a public speaker.发音清晰对演说家至关重要。
But we are a long way from clarity and honesty.但我们离透明和坦诚还相去甚远。
Clarity was just one major problem for researchers.透明度是研究者们所研究的一个主要课题。

classify

['klæsɪfaɪ], ['klæsɪfaɪ]


Image Search
vt. 分类；归类
arrange (a group of people or things) in classes or categories according to shared qualities or characteristics.
assign (someone or something) to a particular class or category.
designate (documents or information) as officially secret or to which only authorized people may have access.
"mountain peaks are classified according to their shape"
"elements are usually classified as metals or nonmetals"
"government officials classified 6.3 million documents in 1992"
The books in the library are classified by subject.图书馆的书是按科目分类的。
We can classify these subjects under three headings.我们可以将这些题目加以分类成三个主题。
Would you classify her novels as serious literature or other?你认为她的小说属于文学类，还是其它类?
It is entirly proper to classify Kant as a transcendental idealist.把康德化归类为先验的唯心主义者是完全正确的。

clergy

['klɜːdʒi], ['klɜːrdʒi]


Image Search
n. [总称]牧师；神职人员
the body of all people ordained for religious duties, especially in the Christian Church.
"all marriages were to be solemnized by the clergy"
The clergy were sacred beings in Miss Ainley's eyes.在安利小姐看来，牧师都是圣人。
I could heartily wish that more of our country clergy would follow this example.我衷心希望，我国有更多的牧师效法这个榜样。
Prior to the law's enactment, most of the Danish clergy opposed it.在通过该法规之前，多数丹麦神职人员反对此法规。
The superior clergy and a small remnant of other educated men read and wrote Latin.上等的神职人员和一小部分残余的其他受过教育的人使用拉丁语读写。

clutch

[klʌtʃ], [klʌtʃ]


Image Search
vt. 抓住；抓牢
vi. 企图抓住；踩离合器
n. 抓住；爪子；离合器；紧要关头
n. 一窝鸡（蛋）；一群
adj. 关键的；致胜的
grasp or seize (something) tightly or eagerly.
become nervous and panicked.
a tight grasp or an act of grasping something.
a person's power or control, especially when perceived as cruel or inescapable.
a slim, flat handbag without handles or a strap.
a mechanism for connecting and disconnecting a vehicle engine from its transmission system.
the pedal operating a vehicle's clutch.
(in sport) denoting or occurring in a critical situation in which the outcome of a game or competition is at stake.
(of a player or action) achieving or characterized by success at a critical moment in a game or competition.
a group of eggs fertilized at the same time, typically laid in a single session and (in birds) incubated together.
a brood of chicks.
a small group of people or things.
"he stood clutching a microphone"
"doctors could clutch up and lose control as easily as anyone"
"she made a clutch at his body"
"she escaped the clutches of her temperamental family"
"they both are hard-nosed players who seem to thrive in clutch situations"
"a clutch quarterback"
"a clutch of young girls on roller skates"
The boy clutched the marbles and ran away.那男孩一把抢去弹珠便逃之夭夭。
The child clutched his toy.那个孩子紧抓着他的玩具不放。
John jumped up to clutch at the branch,but missed.约翰跳起来试图抓住那树枝，但是没有成功。
It is useless to clutch at a straw.抓救命稻草是无济于事的。
Engage the clutch before selecting a gear.先踩离合器再挂挡。
The eagle flew away with a rabbit in the clutch of its claws.鹰用爪子紧紧抓住一只野兔，飞走了。
He fell into the clutches of the criminal gang.他落到了犯罪集团的魔爪中。
He burnt out the clutch on his car.他把他汽车上的离合器烧坏了。
She release the clutch and the car begin to move.她放开离合器，汽车就动了。
He was great in the clutch as he could make shots and pass to his teammates for easy shots.他总能在比赛紧要关头投篮命中或者妙传队友轻松得分。
He's won a whole clutch of awards.他获得一大堆奖。
The Prime Minister was there with a clutch of cabinet ministers.首相和一群内阁部长都在那里。
Tmac is a choker and will never be able to get it done during clutch time.麦迪就像一条围巾，在关键的时候很难从脖子上取下来。

coalesce

[ˌkəʊə'les], [ˌkoʊə'les]


Image Search
v. 合并；联合；接合
come together and form one mass or whole.
combine (elements) in a mass or whole.
"the puddles had coalesced into shallow streams"
"to help coalesce the community, they established an office"
The views of party leaders coalesced to form a coherent policy.党的领导人的各种观点已统一为一致的政策。
I hope patriotism can coalesce under this kind of idea and express itself.愿爱国主义在这样的理念下凝聚起来，表达出来。

coerce

[kəʊ'ɜːs], [koʊ'ɜːrs]


Image Search
vt. 强制；威胁
persuade (an unwilling person) to do something by using force or threats.
obtain (something) by using force or threats.
"they were coerced into silence"
"their confessions were allegedly coerced by torture"
You can't coerce her into obedience.你不能强制她服从。
Do you think there is any way that we can coerce them otherwise?你认为我们有什么办法强迫他们不那样吗?
His plan was to resist every effort to coerce him to the last ditch.他的计划就是要同那欺凌他的力量抵抗到底。
The policy of the prohibition against using tortures to coerce a statement is provided clearly and definitely.严禁逼供信政策明确规定了公安机关及其人员在讯问过程中不得刑讯逼供。

cognizable

['kɒgnɪzəbl], ['kɒgnɪzəbəl]


Image Search
adj. 可认识的
perceptible; clearly identifiable.
within the jurisdiction of a court.
At the present time, human actual law system is far distant from the cognizable justice target. 目前，人类的实在法制度与可认知的正义目标还有很远的距离。
Yet, the integration of discourse, as a subject, and the cognizable psychology of both a translator and a reader are more important. 然而，语篇这一课题所具有的整体性，以及译者与读者的认知心理更是中心所在。
His opinion also noted that the decision does not foreclose the act from challenge by someone who suffers “judicially cognizable injury resulting from it. 译为：他的意见也表明这结果没有妨碍来自一位受害者的“公平审理受伤害结果”的提案。
The denial of a recognized nationality, just as the denial of a recognized citizenship, constitutes a legally cognizable injury-in-fact for the purpose of standing. 否定公认国籍，如同否定公认公民权，于是构成兴讼论据的法定事实损害。
The Cognizable Base of Hayak's Individualism 哈耶克的个人主义的认知基础

collaborated

[kə'læbəreɪt], [kə'læbəreɪt]


Image Search
vi. 合作；通敌
work jointly on an activity, especially to produce or create something.
cooperate traitorously with an enemy.
"he collaborated with a distinguished painter on the designs"
"the indigenous elite who collaborated with the colonizers"
She collaborated with her sister/She and her sister collaborated on a biography of their father.她和姐姐合作写父亲的传记。
We would ask you to collaborate with us.我们愿意请你们和我们合作。
This supplier and I collaborate on certain points.我与供应商有数方面或以上的合作。

commemorate

[kə'meməreɪt], [kə'meməreɪt]


Image Search
vt. 纪念
recall and show respect for (someone or something).
celebrate (an event, a person, or a situation) by doing or building something.
"a wreath-laying ceremony to commemorate the war dead"
"it was a night commemorated in a song"
A monument was built to commemorate the victory.为了纪念胜利，建造了一座纪念碑。
Christmas commemorates the birth of Christ.圣诞节是为了纪念耶酥的诞生。
They reared a monument to commemorate the great musician.他们建立起一座纪念碑，纪念这位伟大的音乐家。
We celebrate this day to commemorate the brave soldiers.我们庆祝这天，以纪念英勇的士兵。
Today, moon cakes are eaten to commemorate this event.今天，人们吃月饼纪念此事。

commentary

['kɒməntri], ['kɑːmənteri]


Image Search
n. 实况报道；现场解说；评论；注释
an expression of opinions or offering of explanations explanations about an event or situation.
a descriptive spoken account (especially on a broadcast) of an event or performance as it happens.
a set of explanatory or critical notes on a text.
"an editorial commentary"
"a commentary on the Old Testament"
His running commentary on the football match was excellent.他对这次足球赛所作的实况报道十分精彩。
Tours have live English commentary.旅游配有现场英语解说。
We'd better not make any commentary on others.我们最好不要评论他人。
I think his commentary on this issue is not correct.我认为他对这个问题的评论是不正确的。
The mere quotation outtells all commentary.纯粹的引用文句比所有一手注解更能表达。

commission

[kə'mɪʃn], [kə'mɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 佣金；委员会；委托；委任；犯罪
vt. 授予；使服役；委托
an instruction, command, or duty given to a person or group of people.
an order for something, especially a work of art, to be produced.
a work produced in response to a commission.
the authority to perform a task or certain duties.
a group of people officially charged with a particular function.
an amount of money, typically a set percentage of the value involved, paid to an agent in a commercial transaction.
a warrant conferring the rank of officer in an army, navy, or air force.
the action of committing a crime or offense.
give an order for or authorize the production of (something such as a building, piece of equipment, or work of art).
order or authorize (a person or organization) to do or produce something.
bring (something newly produced, such as a factory or machine) into working condition.
bring (a warship) into readiness for active service.
appoint (someone) to the rank of officer in the armed services.
"his commission to redesign the building"
"Mozart at last received a commission to write an opera"
"the United Nations High Commission for Refugees"
"foreign banks may charge a commission"
"he has resigned his commission"
"use of a deadly weapon in the commission of a felony"
"the portrait was commissioned by his widow in 1792"
"they commissioned an architect to manage the building project"
"we had a few hiccups getting the heating equipment commissioned"
"the aircraft carrier Midway was commissioned in 1945"
"he was commissioned after attending midshipman school"
Do not deduct any commission from the consignment value.不要从货物的价值中扣除佣金。
The report was submitted to the commission for consideration.这份报告已呈报委员会审批。
He had received the commission to build a new bridge over the river.他受委托在这条河上建一座新桥。
We all approve of the commission of authority to him.我们都赞成把职权委任於他。
The prisoner pleaded that he was drawn in to the commission of the crime.囚犯辩解说他是受人引诱而犯罪的。
He was commissioned captain of the United States Air Force.他被授予美国空军上校。
Some wartime vessels are still commissioned in that area.有些战时的军舰仍在该地区服役。
The musician was commissioned a new symphony for the festival.那位音乐家受托为这个节庆写一首新的交响乐曲。

commodities

[kə'mɒdəti], [kə'mɑːdəti]


Image Search
n. 商品；日用品；有价值之物
a raw material or primary agricultural product that can be bought and sold, such as copper or coffee.
a useful or valuable thing, such as water or time.
Coal is becoming a rare commodity.煤正在成为一种稀缺商品。
In spite of the depression, the price of commodity is still high尽管有些萧条,但商品的价格仍然很高。
The country is heavily dependent on its exports of agricultural commodities.这个国家很大程度上依靠农产品的出口。
Time is our most valuable commodity.时间是最有价值之物。

compassion

[kəm'pæʃn], [kəm'pæʃn]


Image Search
n. 怜悯；同情
sympathetic pity and concern for the sufferings or misfortunes of others.
"the victims should be treated with compassion"
I had compassion for him.我怜悯他。
He teaches us to have compassion on the poor.他教导我们对穷人应有怜悯心。
Compassion is a sign of weakness.怜悯是弱者的标志。
I should not have compassion for those lofty birds.我不会怜悯这些高贵的鸟。
We had compassion for the poor widow.我们同情这个可怜的寡妇。
The nurse had great compassion for her patients.那位护士十分同情她的病人。
I feel a measure of compassion for her.我对她怀有一定程度的同情。
Compassion often engenders love.同情常会产生爱情。

compel

[kəm'pel], [kəm'pel]


Image Search
v. 强迫；迫使；使不得已
force or oblige (someone) to do something.
bring about (something) by the use of force or pressure.
drive forcibly.
"a sense of duty compelled Harry to answer her questions"
"they may compel a witness's attendance at court by issue of a summons"
"by heav'n's high will compell'd from shore to shore"
Nothing can compel me to do such a thing.没有什么可以强迫我做这件事。
I was compelled to do so by absolute necessity.我因绝对的需要,被迫这样做的。
The heavy rain compelled us to stay indoors.大雨迫使我们呆在户内。
Duty compelled the soldiers to volunteer for the mission.责任驱使军人必须志愿加入此任务
Her intelligence and skill compel our admiration.她的聪明和技巧使我们非常佩服。

competent

['kɒmpɪtənt], ['kɑːmpɪtənt]


Image Search
adj. 有能力的；足够的；胜任的
having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully.
(of a person) efficient and capable.
acceptable and satisfactory, though not outstanding.
(chiefly of a court or other body) accepted as having legal authority to deal with a particular matter.
(of a criminal defendant) able to understand the charges and to aid in defending themselves.
capable of performing the normal function effectively.
"a highly competent surgeon"
"an infinitely competent mother of three"
"she spoke quite competent French"
"the governor was not the competent authority to deal with the matter"
Her drawing is competent, but her composition is poor.她的画有功力，但布局欠佳。
She was declared mentally competent to stand trial.她被宣告有接受审判的精神能力。
He is competent enough to fill that position.他完全胜任那个职位。
Is Mary competent as a teacher?玛丽胜任教师的工作吗？
We know you are competent in doing this job.我们知道你可以胜任这项工作。

competition

[ˌkɒmpə'tɪʃn], [ˌkɑːmpə'tɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 竞争；比赛
the activity or condition of competing.
an event or contest in which people compete.
the person or people with whom one is competing, especially in a commercial or sporting arena; the opposition.
interaction between organisms, populations, or species, in which birth, growth and death depend on gaining a share of a limited environmental resource.
"there is fierce competition between banks"
"a beauty competition"
"I walked around to check out the competition"
Everyone in modern society faces keen competitions.现代社会的每个人都面临着激烈的竞争。
To our satisfaction, he had got the first prize in the diving competition.我们满意的是,他在跳水比赛中获得了一等奖。

compliant

[kəm'plaɪənt], [kəm'plaɪənt]


Image Search
adj. 适用的；顺从的
inclined to agree with others or obey rules, especially to an excessive degree; acquiescent.
meeting or in accordance with rules or standards.
having the property of compliance.
"good-humored, eagerly compliant girls"
"the systems are Y2K compliant"
Future versions will be fully compliant with the industry standard.今后的版本将完全符合工业标准的要求。
For years I had tried to be a compliant and dutiful wife.几年来,我努力做一名顺从和尽职尽职的妻子。

complicate

['kɒmplɪkeɪt], ['kɑːmplɪkeɪt]


Image Search
v. 使复杂化；使起纠纷
adj. 复杂的
make (something) more difficult or confusing by causing it to be more complex.
introduce complications in (an existing condition).
"middlemen can complicate the process"
"smoking may complicate pregnancy"
There is no need to complicate matters.没有必要使问题复杂化。
He always likes to complicate simple matters.他总喜欢把简单的事情复杂化。
This text is more complicate than we can imagine.这篇课文比我们想象的还要复杂。
My brother can understand the most complicate circuit diagrams.再复杂的线路图哥哥都能看懂。

comply

[kəm'plaɪ], [kəm'plaɪ]


Image Search
vi. 顺从；遵照；答应
(of a person or group) act in accordance with a wish or command.
(of an article) meet specified standards.
"we are unable to comply with your request"
"all secondhand furniture must comply with the new standards"
She was told to pay the fine, but refused to comply.通知她交纳罚款，但她拒不服从。
He was willing to comply with my proposal.他愿意顺从我的建议。
Everyone should comply with the law.每个人都应该遵守法律。
Is it our duty to comply with his requests?我们有义务满足他的要求吗?
I am sorry I am unable to comply with your request.很抱歉，我不能答应你的请求。

composure

[kəm'pəʊʒə(r)], [kəm'poʊʒər]


Image Search
n. 镇静；沉着
the state or feeling of being calm and in control of oneself.
"she was struggling to regain her composure"
Keep calm; don't lose your composure.保持镇静，不要惊慌失措。
She recovered her composure and smiled.她恢复了镇静，笑了笑。
He could see that she was struggling to preserve her composure.他看出她是竭力故作镇定。
He showed great composure in difficult situations.他在困难环境中表现得极沉着。

comprehensive

[ˌkɒmprɪ'hensɪv], [ˌkɑːmprɪ'hensɪv]


Image Search
adj. 全面的；广泛的；综合的；理解的
complete; including all or nearly all elements or aspects of something.
of large content or scope; wide-ranging.
(of automobile insurance) providing coverage for most risks, including damage to the policyholder's own vehicle.
an examination testing a student's command of a special field of knowledge.
relating to understanding.
a secondary school catering to children of all abilities from a given area.
"a comprehensive list of sources"
"a comprehensive collection of photographs"
"comprehensive and collision insurance"
The reporter has made a comprehensive report.记者已做了全面的报道。
She has a comprehensive grasp of the subject.她已全面掌握了这一学科。
Applying the most comprehensive metal is iron.应用最广泛的金属是铁。
We have a rather comprehensive subway system here.我们这儿有相当广泛的地铁系统。
He was educated at the local comprehensive school.他曾在地区的综合中学受教育。
This book should be adapted to the comprehensive ability of the freshmen.应该将本书改写一下,以便适合新生的理解能力。

compress

['kɒmpres], ['kɑːmpres]


Image Search
vt. 压缩；压榨
n. [医]敷布
flatten by pressure; squeeze; press.
be squeezed or pressed together or into a smaller space.
squeeze or press (two things) together.
express in a shorter form; abridge.
alter the form of (data) to reduce the amount of storage necessary.
having a narrow shape as if flattened, especially sideways.
a pad of absorbent material pressed onto part of the body to relieve inflammation or stop bleeding.
"the skirt can be folded and compressed into a small bag"
"the land is sinking as the soil compresses"
"Violet compressed her lips together grimly"
"in this chapter we compress into summary form the main findings"
"most sea snakes have a compressed tail"
"a cold compress"
Compress this clay into a small ball.把这块粘土压缩成一个小球。
Click the picture that you want to compress.单击要压缩的图片。

compromise

['kɒmprəmaɪz], ['kɑːmprəmaɪz]


Image Search
n. 妥协；折衷；折衷案；和解
vt. 妥协处理；危害
vi. 妥协，和解；让步
an agreement or a settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions.
a middle state between conflicting opinions or actions reached by mutual concession or modification.
the acceptance of standards that are lower than is desirable.
settle a dispute by mutual concession.
settle (a dispute) by mutual concession.
accept standards that are lower than is desirable.
weaken (a reputation or principle) by accepting standards that are lower than is desirable.
bring into disrepute or danger by indiscreet, foolish, or reckless behavior.
cause to become vulnerable or function less effectively.
"an ability to listen to two sides in a dispute, and devise a compromise acceptable to both"
"a compromise between commercial appeal and historical interest"
"sexism should be tackled without compromise"
"in the end we compromised and deferred the issue"
"I should compromise the matter with my father"
"we were not prepared to compromise on safety"
"commercial pressures could compromise safety"
"situations in which his troops could be compromised"
"yo-yo dieting can compromise your immune system"
He did it without compromise of his dignity.他做这事而不损及他的尊严。
The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.这个协议是双方妥协的产物而不是一方让步。
After some discussion we arrive at a compromise.经过一番讨论之后，我们达成一项折衷方案。
Or are we ready to compromise our faith?或者，我们准备好了在信仰上折衷吗？
With this increased awareness, attackers are finding it more difficult to compromise systems at the network level.由于对这些认识得越来越清楚，攻击者发现在网络级上危害系统更加困难。
Build the disorder that does not have the market to compromise project quality forthrightly.建没市场的混乱直接地危害工程质量。
They found it wiser to compromise with her.他们觉得与她妥协更明智。
The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.这个协议是双方妥协的产物而不是一方让步。
The agreement is a compromise, not a sell-out.这个协议是双方妥协的产物而不是一方让步。
I think we'd better reach a compromise.我认为我们最好相互让步。

conceal

[kən'siːl], [kən'siːl]


Image Search
vt. 隐藏；隐瞒；掩盖
keep from sight; hide.
keep (something) secret; prevent from being known or noticed.
"a line of sand dunes concealed the distant sea"
"love that they had to conceal from others"
He concealed himself behind the tree.他藏在树后。
It is against law to conceal evidence.隐藏证据是违法的。
It is wrong for a man to conceal things from his wife.一个男人对妻子隐瞒事情是不对的。
She tried to conceal what she had done to them.她试图隐瞒对他们所做的事。
He could hardly conceal his joy at his departure.他几乎掩饰不住临行时的喜悦。

concept

['kɒnsept], ['kɑːnsept]


Image Search
n. 观念；概念；想法
an abstract idea; a general notion.
a plan or intention; a conception.
an idea or invention to help sell or publicize a commodity.
an idea or mental picture of a group or class of objects formed by combining all their aspects.
(of a car or other vehicle) produced as an experimental model to test the viability of new design features.
"structuralism is a difficult concept"
"the center has kept firmly to its original concept"
"a new concept in corporate hospitality"
I can not understand such an abstract concept.我无法理解如此抽象的观念。
He presented a new concept of the origins of the universe.他提出了一种宇宙起源的新概念。
We had no concept that this tiny mistake would ruin the whole plan.我们完全没有想到这个小小的失误会毁掉整个计划。

concise

[kən'saɪs], [kən'saɪs]


Image Search
adj. 简明的；简要的
giving a lot of information clearly and in a few words; brief but comprehensive.
"a concise account of the country's history"
His article is concise and comprehensive.他的文章言简意赅。
I like the new concise dictionary very much.我很喜欢这部新的简明词典。
I gave a concise answer to this.我对于此事给了一个简要的答复。
He gave a concise and firm summary of our position.他扼要而坚定地阐述了我方的立场。

conclude

[kən'kluːd], [kən'kluːd]


Image Search
vt. 推断出；缔结；使结束
vi. 结束；总结；作决定；作协议
bring (something) to an end.
come to an end.
formally and finally settle or arrange (a treaty or agreement).
arrive at a judgment or opinion by reasoning.
say in conclusion.
decide to do something.
"they conclude their study with these words"
"the talk concluded with slides"
"an attempt to conclude a ceasefire"
"the doctors concluded that Esther had suffered a stroke"
"“It's a wicked old world,” she concluded"
"I concluded to go without his knowledge"
From his appearance we may safely conclude that he is a chain smoker.从他的外表，我们可以有把握地断定他烟抽得很凶。
The two countries are reported to have concluded a military convention.据报导,这两个国家已缔结军事协定。
He conclude the negotiation with dispatch.他迅速结束谈判。
The concert concluded with the National Anthem.音乐会最后以演奏国歌结束。
I want to conclude on a positive note.让我从乐观的角度作个总结。

condemn

[kən'dem], [kən'dem]


Image Search
vt. 谴责；判刑
express complete disapproval of, typically in public; censure.
sentence (someone) to a particular punishment, especially death.
officially declare (something, especially a building) to be unfit for use.
prove or show the guilt of.
(of circumstances) force (someone) to endure something unpleasant or undesirable.
"fair-minded people declined to condemn her on mere suspicion"
"the rebels had been condemned to death"
"the pool has been condemned as a health hazard"
"she could see in his eyes that her stumble had condemned her"
"the physical ailments that condemned him to a lonely childhood"
We must not condemn her on pure supposition.我们不能单凭猜测就谴责她。
We condemn all sorts of slanders.我们谴责一切诽谤中伤的言论。
Most people are willing to condemn violence.大部分的人极力谴责暴力。
The criminal was condemned to death.这个罪犯被判死刑。

condescending

[ˌkɒndɪ'sendɪŋ], [ˌkɒndɪ'sendɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 高傲的；表现出优越感的
动词condescend的现在分词.
having or showing a feeling of patronizing superiority.
show feelings of superiority; be patronizing.
do something in a haughty way, as though it is below one's dignity or level of importance.
"she thought the teachers were arrogant and condescending"
"take care not to condescend to your reader"
"we'll be waiting for twenty minutes before she condescends to appear"
I don't like Mrs Smith; she's condescending.我不喜欢史密斯夫人，她总是自以为高人一等。
His condescending attitude really gets my back up.他那种居高临下的恩赐态度实在使我很生气。
Penny's condescending manner really gets under my skin.彭尼那种以恩赐态度对待别人的样子真的把激怒了。

condone

[kən'dəʊn], [kən'doʊn]


Image Search
vt. 宽恕
accept and allow (behavior that is considered morally wrong or offensive) to continue.
approve or sanction (something), especially with reluctance.
"the college cannot condone any behavior that involves illicit drugs"
"the practice is not officially condoned by any airline"
People cannot condone the use of fierce violence.人们不能宽恕使用凶残的暴力。
No faith or culture should condone the outrages against them.任何信仰或文化都不能宽恕对妇幼施加的暴行。

confederate

[kən'fedərət], [kən'fedərət]


Image Search
n. 同盟者；同盟国；同伙
Confederate：美国南部联盟.
adj. 同盟的；联合的
v. （使)结盟；（使)联合
joined by an agreement or treaty.
relating to the Confederate States of America.
a person one works with, especially in something secret or illegal; an accomplice.
a supporter of the Confederate States of America.
bring (states or groups of people) into an alliance.
"some local groups united to form confederate councils"
"the Confederate flag"
"where was his confederate, the girl who had stolen Richard's wallet?"
"Switzerland is a model for the new confederated Europe"
The thief was arrested, but his confederate escaped.小偷被逮住了，但他的同伙却逃之夭夭。
Confederate forces defeated in Federal army in both battles.同盟国势力打败了两次战役中的联邦军队。
The country tried to confederate with other countries for mutual safety.这个国家为了共同安全，曾试图与别的国家结盟。

confer

[kən'fɜː(r)], [kən'fɜːr]


Image Search
v. 商讨；授予，赐予
grant or bestow (a title, degree, benefit, or right).
have discussions; exchange opinions.
"moves were made to confer an honorary degree on her"
"the officials were conferring with allies"
I must confer with my lawyer before I decide.我必须先同我的律师商量一下才能做出决定。
I will confer with him on the subject.我将和他商议这件事。
The Queen conferred knighthood on several distinguished men.女王将爵士头衔授予几位杰出人士。
The university confers master degree on her.学校授予她硕士学位。

confine

[kən'faɪn], [kən'faɪn]


Image Search
vt. 限制；禁闭
n. 范围；界限；约束；限制
keep or restrict someone or something within certain limits of (space, scope, quantity, or time).
restrain or forbid someone from leaving (a place).
(of a person) be unable to leave (one's bed, home, or a wheelchair) because of illness or disability.
(of a woman) remain in bed for a period before, during, and after the birth of a child.
the borders or boundaries of a place, especially with regard to their restricting freedom of movement.
the limits or restrictions of something abstract, especially a subject or sphere of activity.
"he does not confine his message to politics"
"the troops were confined to their barracks"
"he was confined to bed for four days with a bad dose of flu"
"she was confined for nearly a month"
"they were cramped within the confines of a little cabin"
"the narrow confines of political life"
I wish the speaker would confine himself to the subject.我希望演说者不要离题。
I am sick, I have to confine to bed.我病了，我得卧床休息。
The thief was confined in a prison.窃贼被关押在监狱里。
Is it cruel to confine a bird in a cage?把鸟关在笼子里残忍不残忍?
This is outside the confines of human knowledge.这超出了人类知识范畴。
The refiner defined a definite confine with her fine finger.提炼者用她精细的手指定义了一个明确的界限。
Our first example of confining waves will be to confine a wave at one boundary.约束波的第一例子是使波动在一个界面上受到限制。
It will use magnetic fields to confine hydrogen isotopes and heat them to hundreds of millions of degrees Celcius.它利用磁场约束氢的同位素并将其加热到数亿摄氏度。
The murderer was placed in the confine.杀人犯被监禁了。

confirm

[kən'fɜːm], [kən'fɜːrm]


Image Search
v. 证实；批准；确定
establish the truth or correctness of (something previously believed, suspected, or feared to be the case).
state with assurance that a report or fact is true.
reinforce someone in (an opinion, belief, or feeling).
make (a provisional arrangement or appointment) definite.
make (something, especially a person's appointment to a position or an agreement) formally valid; ratify.
formally declare (someone) to be appointed to a particular position.
administer the religious rite of confirmation to.
"if these fears are confirmed, the outlook for the economy will be dire"
"he confirmed that the general was in the hands of the rebels"
"he fueled his misogyny by cultivating women who confirmed him in this view"
"Mr. Baker's assistant telephoned to confirm his appointment with the chairman"
"the organization has confirmed the appointment of Mr. Collins as managing director"
"he was confirmed as the new peace envoy"
"he had been baptized and confirmed"
His letter confirmed everything.他的信证实了一切。
The treaty was confirmed by the president.条约已被总统批准。
Could you confirm the dispatch date?您可以确定发货日期吗?

confiscate

['kɒnfɪskeɪt], ['kɒnfɪsˌkeɪt]


Image Search
v. 没收；充公
take or seize (someone's property) with authority.
take (a possession, especially land) as a penalty and give it to the public treasury.
"the guards confiscated his camera"
"the government confiscated his property"
We'll have to confiscate this object.我们要没收这些物品。
The present policy of our Party is still to reduce rents, not to confiscate land.目前我党方针，仍然是减租而不是没收土地。

conflict

['kɒnflɪkt], ['kɑːnflɪkt]


Image Search
n. 冲突；战斗；矛盾；斗争
vi. 冲突；抵触；争执
a serious disagreement or argument, typically a protracted one.
a prolonged armed struggle.
an incompatibility between two or more opinions, principles, or interests.
a condition in which a person experiences a clash of opposing wishes or needs.
be incompatible or at variance; clash.
having or showing confused and mutually inconsistent feelings.
"the eternal conflict between the sexes"
"overseas conflicts"
"there was a conflict between his business and domestic life"
"parents' and children's interests sometimes conflict"
"my feelings are so conflicted that I hardly know how to answer"
Both sides suffered heavy casualties in the border armed conflict.在这次边界武装冲突中双方都遭到了重大伤亡。
He was wounded in the conflict.他在战斗中负伤。
This is an irreconcilable conflict.这是一个不可调和的矛盾。
He's got involved in a political conflict he can't extricate himself from.他陷在一场政治斗争中不能脱身。
Your interests conflict with mine.你的利益和我的冲突。
The hours of those two exams conflict.那两门测验的钟点互有抵触。
John often comes into conflict with his boss.约翰经常和他的老板发生争执。
A careless move may well trigger an all new debate and conflict.一不小心，还可能引发全新的争执和冲突。

conform

[kən'fɔːm], [kən'fɔːrm]


Image Search
v. 使一致；遵从
comply with rules, standards, or laws.
(of a person) behave according to socially acceptable conventions or standards.
be similar in form or type; agree.
"the kitchen does not conform to hygiene regulations"
"the pressure to conform"
"the countryside should conform to a certain idea of the picturesque"
His ideas do not conform to mine.他的想法和我的不一致。
He doesn't conform to the usual stereotype of the city businessman with a dark suit and rolled umbrella.他不像典型的城市商人那样，穿一身深色的套服、 带一把收好的雨伞。
She refused to conform to the normal social conventions.她拒绝遵从正常的社会习俗。
She left home to escape the pressure to conform to her family's way of life.她离家出走以求摆脱她家生活方式对她的束缚。
Students are required to conform to the rules.学生被要求遵守规则。

confound

[kən'faʊnd], [kən'faʊnd]


Image Search
vt. 使困惑；混淆；挫败；诅咒
cause surprise or confusion in (someone), especially by acting against their expectations.
prove (a theory, expectation, or prediction) wrong.
defeat (a plan, aim, or hope).
overthrow (an enemy).
mix up (something) with something else so that the individual elements become difficult to distinguish.
used to express anger or annoyance.
"the inflation figure confounded economic analysts"
"the rise in prices confounded expectations"
"we will confound these tactics by the pressure groups"
"'nuke' is now a cooking technique, as microwave radiation is confounded with nuclear radiation"
"oh, confound it, where is the thing?"
Don't confound the means with the ends.不要把手段和目的混淆起来。
To confound two things means not to be able to tell them apart.混淆两件事物的意思是说没能把它们区分开来。

confront

[kən'frʌnt], [kən'frʌnt]


Image Search
vt. 对抗；遭遇；面临
meet (someone) face to face with hostile or argumentative intent.
face up to and deal with (a problem or difficult situation).
compel (someone) to face or consider something, especially by way of accusation.
(of a problem, difficulty, etc.) present itself to (someone) so that dealing with it cannot be avoided.
appear or be placed in front of (someone) so as to unsettle or threaten.
"300 policemen confronted an equal number of union supporters"
"we knew we couldn't ignore the race issue and decided we'd confront it head on"
"Tricia confronted him with her suspicions"
"post-czarist Russia was confronted with a Ukrainian national movement"
"we were confronted with pictures of moving skeletons"
We must confront future with optimism.我们必须乐观地面对未来。
You must confront your problems.你必须面对自己的问题。
It's no use to confront your boss.对抗你的老板是没有用的。
A soldier often has to confront danger.士兵常常要身临险境。
Confronted by an angry crowd, the police retreated.警察面对愤怒的人群只好后撤了。
The difficulties that confront us seem insuperable.我们面临的困难似乎是不可克服的。

congenial

[kən'dʒiːniəl], [kən'dʒiːniəl]


Image Search
adj. 同性质的；适意的；趣味相同的；友善的
(of a person) pleasant because of a personality, qualities, or interests that are similar to one's own.
(of a thing) pleasant or agreeable because suited to one's taste or inclination.
"his need for some congenial company"
"he went back to a climate more congenial to his cold stony soul"
No fuss was made in my day if a new writer took from an old one whatever material he found congenial.在我那个时代，如果一个新作家从一个老作家的作品中摘取了他能用的合适材料，并不受到反对。
In the next year he obtained, through the good offices of an old friend, a post with a publishing firm which, though not highly paid, he found more congenial.第二年，通过一个老朋友帮忙，他在一家出版公司谋到一个职位，薪水虽不高，却更令他感到惬意。
They are of congenial temper.他们的性情相投。
I found him very congenial.我发现他跟人很合得来。

conglomerate

[kən'ɡlɒmərət], [kən'ɡlɑːmərət]


Image Search
n. 联合企业；密集体；城郊混合区；[地]砾岩
adj. 聚成一团的；成簇的
vt. 使聚集；使结成；结合
a number of different things or parts that are put or grouped together to form a whole but remain distinct entities.
a large corporation formed by the merging of separate and diverse firms.
a coarse-grained sedimentary rock composed of rounded fragments (> 2 mm) within a matrix of finer grained material.
relating to a conglomerate, especially a large corporation.
gather together into a compact mass.
form a conglomerate by merging diverse businesses.
"the Earth is a specialized conglomerate of organisms"
"a media conglomerate"
"the sediments vary from coarse conglomerate to fine silt and clay"
"conglomerate businesses"
"atoms that conglomerate at the center"
An American conglomerate holds a major share in the company.一家美国的大联合企业持有该公司的大部分股份。
The firm has been taken over by an American conglomerate.该公司已被美国一企业集团接管。
The house was a conglomerate of architectural styles.这幢房子是多种建筑风格的综合。
Sandstone and conglomerate are the consolidated equivalent of sand and gravel.砂岩和砾岩分别是砂和砾石固结的产物。
A large number of people conglomerated round her.在她周围聚集了一大群人。

conniving

[kə'naɪv], [kə'naɪv]


Image Search
v. 共谋；默许；纵容
given to or involved in conspiring to do something immoral, illegal, or harmful.
secretly allow (something considered immoral, illegal, wrong, or harmful) to occur.
conspire to do something considered immoral, illegal, or harmful.
"a heartless and conniving person"
"you have it in your power to connive at my escape"
"the government had connived with security forces in permitting murder"
We want to let to benefit the customer and connive development.我们就是要做到让利于客户
The student tried to connive with her friend to cheat in the examination.那个学生企图和她的朋友串谋考试作弊。
Some government officials connive at graft.有些政府官员对贪污受贿视而不见。
The prisoners paid the guards to connive at their escape.囚犯们贿赂看守，使看守默许他们越狱。
Some policemen connive at gambling.有些警察纵容赌博。

consensus

[kən'sensəs], [kən'sensəs]


Image Search
n. 一致；同意；共识
general agreement.
"a consensus of opinion among judges"
The two parties have reached a consensus.这两个政党达成了一致意见。
It would be a good idea to predict which proposal is most likely to achieve consensus.不妨研究一下哪项提案最有可能获得一致同意。
Yet the events of the past two years have called that consensus in question.然而,过去两年来发生的各种事件使人们对这一共识产生了疑虑。

consent

[kən'sent], [kən'sent]


Image Search
n. 同意；赞成
v. 同意；答应
permission for something to happen or agreement to do something.
give permission for something to happen.
agree to do something.
"no change may be made without the consent of all the partners"
"he consented to a search by a detective"
"he had consented to serve on the panel"
My father will never give his consent to our marriage.我父亲决不会同意我们的婚姻的。
By the common consent of critics, Shakespeare is the prince of character delineators.评论家一致公认莎士比亚是刻画人物的大师。
Her smile implied her consent to our proposal.她的微笑暗示她赞成我们的提议。
On the other hand, it is not likely that the few landlords from the upper strata of the Miao nationality will consent to their demand.但是这样的要求，可能苗族上层少数地主分子不赞成。
I'm sure he wouldn't consent我确信他不会同意。
His father would not consent to his leaving school.他的父亲不会同意他放弃学业。
I agree with you, but yet I can't consent.我同意你的意见, 但是我不能答应。
Her father reluctantly consented to the marriage.她父亲勉强答应了这桩婚姻。

consequence

['kɒnsɪkwəns], ['kɑːnsəkwens]


Image Search
n. 结果；后果；重要性；影响
a result or effect of an action or condition.
importance or relevance.
social distinction.
"many have been laid off from work as a consequence of the administration's policies"
"the past is of no consequence"
"a woman of consequence"
It terrified me to contemplate the consequence of your action.一想到你行动的后果,我就感到害怕。
He studied hard, and in consequence he passed the exam.他努力学习，因此通过了考试。
Happiness is not a reward it is a consequence.幸福不是报偿，而是结果。
In consequence of his bad conduct he was dismissed.由于行为不良，他被开除了。
He is a man of great consequence.他是一个很重要的人物。
Both sides think of the point as of no consequence.双方都认为这一点不重要。
The difference is not of consequence.此差别是无关紧要的。

conserve

[kən'sɜːv], [kən'sɜːrv]


Image Search
n. 蜜饯；果酱
v. 保存；保持；节省；用糖保存
protect (something, especially an environmentally or culturally important place or thing) from harm or destruction.
prevent the wasteful or harmful overuse of (a resource).
maintain (a quantity such as energy or mass) at a constant overall total.
retain (a particular amino acid, nucleotide, or sequence of these) unchanged in different protein or DNA molecules.
preserve (food, typically fruit) with sugar.
a sweet food made by preserving fruit with sugar; jam.
"the funds raised will help conserve endangered meadowlands"
"industry should conserve more water"
This is a recipe for strawberry conserve.这是制作草莓酱的食谱。
I was surprised to find that the strong man liked to eat conserves.我很惊讶地发现这个强壮的男人喜欢吃蜜饯。
This is a recipe for strawberry conserve.这是制作草莓酱的食谱。
We must learn to conserve what remains.我们必须学会保存那些剩余的资源。
We must conserve our forests and woodlands for future generations.我们必须为子孙后代保护森林资源。
It is important to conserve energy.节省能源十分重要。

considerable

[kən'sɪdərəbl], [kən'sɪdərəbl]


Image Search
adj. 重要的；相当大的；可观的
notably large in size, amount, or extent.
(of a person) having merit or distinction.
"a position of considerable influence"
"he was a limited, but still considerable, novelist"
The mayor is a considerable official.市长是一位重要的官员。
He is a considerable person in that college.他是那所学院相当重要的人物。
The economy was a considerable issue in the campaign.在竞选运动中经济是一个重要问题。
His remarks provoked considerable comment.他的话引起了相当大的议论。
Your work shows considerable improvement.你的工作显示出相当大的改进。
The design requires considerable modification.这个设计需要大的修改。
It is a considerable sum of money.那是一笔数量可观的钱。
He was a man of considerable wealth.他是个有可观的财富的人。

consonant

['kɒnsənənt], ['kɑːnsənənt]


Image Search
n. 辅音
adj. 一致的；符合的；辅音的
a basic speech sound in which the breath is at least partly obstructed and which can be combined with a vowel to form a syllable.
a letter representing a consonant.
denoting or relating to a consonant sound or letter.
in agreement or harmony with.
making a harmonious interval or chord.
"a consonant phoneme"
"the findings are consonant with other research"
"the bass is consonant with all the upper notes"
She asked me to pronounce each vowel and consonant clearly.她叫我把每个元音和辅音都清晰地发出来。
Many letters in the alphabet such as b, c, d, etc are consonants.字母表中的许多字母像b，c，d，等等都是辅音字母。
His view on the issue is consonant with mine.他对这个问题的看法和我是一致的。
The quality of this suit is not quite consonant with its price .这套衣服的质量与价钱不太相符。
English has 24 consonant phonemes.英语有24个辅音音素。

consortium

[kən'sɔːtɪəm], [kən'sɔːʃɪəm]


Image Search
n. 财团；联合；合伙
an association, typically of several business companies.
the right of association and companionship with one's husband or wife.
The aircraft will be built by a European consortium.这架飞机将由一个欧洲财团建造。
The new aircraft was developed by a European consortium.这种新飞机是一家欧洲财团出资研制的。
They want to organize a consortium of labor parties.他们想要组织一个劳工团体。
Each of the groups making up the consortium has its own scientific focus.每一个小组为协会拟订各自的关注方面。

conspicuous

[kən'spɪkjuəs], [kən'spɪkjuəs]


Image Search
adj. 显著的；显眼的；显而易见的
standing out so as to be clearly visible.
attracting notice or attention.
"he was very thin, with a conspicuous Adam's apple"
"he showed conspicuous bravery"
Lincoln is a conspicuous example of a poor boy who succeeded.林肯是一个穷苦孩子而功成名就的出色例子。
He was conspicuous for his bravery.他因骁勇而出名。
A traffic sign should be conspicuous.交通标志应该明显。
Notices shall be put in conspicuous places.要保证把布告贴在显眼的地方。
I found several conspicuous errors in his speech.我发现他的演讲中有几个显而易见的错误。

constrain

[kən'streɪn], [kən'streɪn]


Image Search
vt. 强迫；限制
compel or force (someone) toward a particular course of action.
cause to appear unnaturally forced, typically because of embarrassment.
severely restrict the scope, extent, or activity of.
bring about (something) by compulsion.
confine forcibly; imprison.
"children are constrained to work in the way the book dictates"
"he was acting in a constrained manner"
"agricultural development is considerably constrained by climate"
"Calypso in her caves constrained his stay"
I felt constrained to do what he told me.做他叫我做的事,我心里很不舒服。
She tried to constrain herself from a cough in class.上课时她竭力忍住不咳嗽。
Cold weather constrains the plant's growth.寒冷的天气抑制了植物的生长。
Don't constrain yourself only to class study.不要把自己的学习只局限于课堂。
The police used horses to constrain the crowd from violence.警察骑着马阻止那群人诉诸暴力。

construction

[kən'strʌkʃn], [kən'strʌkʃn]


Image Search
n. 建设；结构；建筑物；建造；构造；解释
the building of something, typically a large structure.
the building of large structures considered as an industry.
the style or method used in the building of something.
a building or other structure.
the creation or formation of an abstract entity.
an interpretation or explanation.
the arrangement of words according to syntactical rules.
"there was a skyscraper under construction"
"the mill is of brick construction"
"language plays a large part in our construction of reality"
"you could put an honest construction upon their conduct"
"sentence construction"
China is striding ahead in her economic construction.中国正在经济建设方面大步前进。
It is an object of simple construction.它是一个简单结构的物体。
The cathedral is a fantastic modern construction.那个教堂是奇特的现代建筑。
The new airport is still under construction.新机场仍在修建中。
The building was of bizarre construction.这建筑构造奇异。
This page is still under construction.此页还在构造之中。
I was inclined to put a favorable construction on his reply.我总是对他的回答作出很好的解释。

consume

[kən'sjuːm], [kən'suːm]


Image Search
v. 消耗；吃喝；毁灭
eat, drink, or ingest (food or drink).
buy (goods or services).
use up (a resource).
(especially of a fire) completely destroy.
(of a feeling) absorb all of the attention and energy of (someone).
"people consume a good deal of sugar in drinks"
"these machines consume 5 percent of the natural gas in the U.S"
"the fire spread rapidly, consuming many homes"
"Carolyn was consumed with guilt"
His old car consumed much gasoline.他的旧汽车耗油很多。
Each year Americans consume a high percentage of the world's energy.每年美国人都消耗掉世界能源的很大比例
I'm sure that Chinese people consume the largest amount of rice in the world.我敢肯定,世界上中国人吃掉的大米最多。
I saw the flames consuming the whole building.我看见火焰吞噬了整栋建筑物。

consumer

[kən'sjuːmə], [kən'sjuːmə]


Image Search
n. 消费者；用户；消费品
a person who purchases goods and services for personal use.
a person or thing that eats or uses something.
"consumer demand"
"Scandinavians are the largest consumers of rye"
We need more feedback from the consumer in order to improve our goods.我们需要从消费者那里多得到些反馈信息以提高产品质量。
The price increases were passed on by the firm to the consumers.那个公司把上涨的费用都转嫁到了消费者身上。
We should adopt the consumers' suggestion.我们应该接受用户的建议。
Consumer goods production was to go up by 6.6 percent in that city.在那个城市消费品生产将增长6.6%25。
That covers many consumer products.这涉及到许多消费产品。

contemplation

[ˌkɒntəm'pleɪʃn], [ˌkɑːntəm'pleɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 注视；沉思；打算
the action of looking thoughtfully at something for a long time.
deep reflective thought.
the state of being thought about or planned.
religious meditation.
(in Christian spirituality) a form of prayer or meditation in which a person seeks to pass beyond mental images and concepts to a direct experience of the divine.
"the road is too busy for leisurely contemplation of the scenery"
"he would retire to his room for study or contemplation"
I take greater comfort in the contemplation of eternity.在对永恒的注视之中我获得较大的安慰。
Mr. Quilp was serenely gazing at the stars, quite absorbed in celestial contemplation.奎尔普先生正在从容地注视着繁星，好象全神对着天空沉思似的。
She spent an hour in quiet contemplation.她静静地沉思了一个小时。
He has a new novel in contemplation.他打算写一部新小说。
Various kinds of studies concerning earthquake prediction are now under contemplation in the Yamasaki region.在山崎地区，现在已经打算进行地震预报的各种研究工作。

contemporary

[kən'temprəri], [kən'tempəreri]


Image Search
adj. 同时代的；当代的
n. 同时代的人；同龄人
living or occurring at the same time.
dating from the same time.
belonging to or occurring in the present.
following modern ideas or fashion in style or design.
a person or thing living or existing at the same time as another.
a person of roughly the same age as another.
"the event was recorded by a contemporary historian"
"this series of paintings is contemporary with other works in an early style"
"the tension and complexities of our contemporary society"
"contemporary art"
"he was a contemporary of Darwin"
"my contemporaries at school"
Marlowe was contemporary with Shakespeare.马洛与莎士比亚是同时代的。
He had devoted his whole life to the study of contemporary art.他把他的一生都献给了当代艺术研究。
Thackeray is a contemporary of Dickens.萨克莱跟狄更斯是同时期的人。
She and I were contemporaries at college.她和我在学院里是同学。
He is a contemporary of mine, but our experiences are completely different.他和我是同龄人，但我们的经历截然不同。

contented

[kən'tentɪd], [kən'tentɪd]


Image Search
adj. 满足的；心安的
动词content的过去式和过去分词形式.
happy and at ease.
willing to accept something; satisfied.
satisfy (someone).
accept as adequate despite wanting more or better.
"I felt warm and contented"
"I was never contented with half measures"
"nothing would content her"
"we contented ourselves with a few small purchases"
A contented person does not create progress.满足的人不能进步。
The lady looked at me with a contented smile.那位夫人带着满意的微笑看着我。
By following the steps, mothers should be able to lead a fulfilling and contented life.按照这些步骤去做,妈妈们一定会感到日子充实、心情惬意。

contradict

[ˌkɒntrə'dɪkt], [ˌkɒntrə'dɪkt]


Image Search
vt. 反驳；与 ... 矛盾
deny the truth of (a statement), especially by asserting the opposite.
assert the opposite of a statement made by (someone).
be in conflict with.
"the survey appears to contradict the industry's claims"
"he did not contradict her but just said nothing"
"that evaporation seems to contradict one of the most fundamental principles of physics"
He did not contradict his attorney's comment.他没有反驳律师的意见。
She doesn't like to contradict her husband in public.她不愿在众人面前反驳她丈夫。
Don't contradict your father.别和你父亲犟嘴。
The report contradicts what we heard yesterday.这个报道与我们昨天听到的有矛盾。
The two statements contradict each other.两种说法相互抵触。

contradiction

[ˌkɒntrə'dɪkʃn], [ˌkɑːntrə'dɪkʃn]


Image Search
n. 矛盾；反驳；否认；不一致
a combination of statements, ideas, or features of a situation that are opposed to one another.
a person, thing, or situation in which inconsistent elements are present.
the statement of a position opposite to one already made.
"the proposed new system suffers from a set of internal contradictions"
"the paradox of using force to overcome force is a real contradiction"
"the second sentence appears to be in flat contradiction of the first"
Motion itself is a contradiction.运动本身就是矛盾。
The contradiction was only apparent.那矛盾只是表面上的。
The contradiction has become apparent.矛盾表面化了。
This contradiction is hushed up .这个矛盾消除了。
The report received the following contradiction.这报告受到如下反驳意见。
he spoke as if his claims were immune to contradiction.他认为他的说法无法反驳。
Those facts admit of no contradiction.那些事实不容否认。
There seems to be a contradiction between her word and action.她的言行似乎不一致。
That's a flat contradiction of what you said before.这可和你以前说的恰恰相反。

contribution

[ˌkɒntrɪ'bjuːʃn], [ˌkɑːntrɪ'bjuːʃn]


Image Search
n. 贡献；捐款(赠)；投稿
a gift or payment to a common fund or collection.
the part played by a person or thing in bringing about a result or helping something to advance.
an article or other piece of writing submitted for publication in a collection.
"charitable contributions"
"he made a lasting contribution by designing the modern radio telescope"
Don't undervalue Jim's contribution to the research.不要低估了吉姆在研究工作中的贡献。
He has made an important contribution to the company's success.他对公司的成功作出了重要的贡献。
All contribution, however small, will be greatly appreciated.所有捐款，无论数目多么少，我们都深表感谢。
The union successfully negotiated increased employer contributions to the health benefits package.工会成功地让雇主增加对医疗福利的捐赠。

contrite

[kən'traɪt], [kən'traɪt]


Image Search
adj. 悔悟了的；后悔的；痛悔的
feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.
"a broken and a contrite heart"
He was to be contrite and wish to be reconciled.他必须感到悔悟，并且希望得到赦免。
He made a contrite apology.他深表懊悔地致歉。
The look she gave Anna was guilty and contrite.她给安娜的脸色是内疚和愧悔的。
She was contrite the whole morning after her angry outburst.她发了一通脾气之后整个早上都追悔莫及。

controversial

[ˌkɒntrə'vɜːʃl], [ˌkɑːntrə'vɜːrʃl]


Image Search
adj. 有争议的；引起争论的
giving rise or likely to give rise to public disagreement.
"years of wrangling over a controversial bypass"
We tried to stay away from controversial topics at the dinner party.晚宴上我们尽力避免一些有争议的话题。
This is a controversial question.这是个引起争论的问题。

convention

[kən'venʃn], [kən'venʃn]


Image Search
n. 大会；协定；惯例；公约
a way in which something is usually done, especially within a particular area or activity.
behavior that is considered acceptable or polite to most members of a society.
an artificial bid by which a bidder tries to convey specific information about the hand to their partner.
an agreement between countries covering particular matters, especially one less formal than a treaty.
a large meeting or conference, especially of members of a political party or a particular profession.
(in the US) an assembly of the delegates of a political party to select candidates for office.
an organized meeting of enthusiasts for a television program, movie, or literary genre.
a body set up by agreement to deal with a particular issue.
"the woman who overturned so many conventions of children's literature"
"he was an upholder of convention and correct form"
"a convention of retail merchants"
"a Star Trek convention"
"the convention is a UN body responsible for the regulation of sea dumping"
The convention looms as political battle.这场大会将是一场政治角斗。
Delegates will be picked at a convention.代表将在大会上选出。
This convention results in no ambiguity.这个协定不会导致误解。
The countries all agreed to sign the convention.各国都同意签署这项协定。
The handshake is a social convention.握手是社交惯例。
Convention requires that such meetings open with prayer.惯例上要求这样的集会应当以祈祷开始。
Property Management Convention agreed receivers?物业管理公约约定啥？
We follow Geneva Convention procedures.我们遵守日内瓦公约规定的程序。

conventional

[kən'venʃənl], [kən'venʃənl]


Image Search
adj. 传统的；惯例的；常规的
based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed.
(of a person) concerned with what is generally held to be acceptable at the expense of individuality and sincerity.
(of a work of art or literature) following traditional forms and genres.
(of weapons or power) nonnuclear.
(of a bid) intended to convey a particular meaning according to an agreed upon convention.
"a conventional morality had dictated behavior"
"conventional love poetry"
"agreement on reducing conventional forces in Europe"
Her book is a hilarious send-up of a conventional spy story.她写的书用的是取笑传统侦探小说的笔法，令人捧腹。
According to conventional wisdom, voters usually make their choice on the basis of domestic issues.按一般人在这些问题上的看法，选民常常着眼于国内问题来选择候选人。
After a conventional opening remarks, he made a brilliant speech.在一个常规的开场白后,他做了个很精彩的演讲。
I can never get a girl like that with conventional methods.我用寻常套路可永远也得不到这样的女孩。

convolute

['kɒnvəˌluːt], ['kɒnvəˌluːt]


Image Search
v. 盘旋；回旋
adj. 回旋状的
make (an argument, story, etc.) complex and difficult to follow.
rolled longitudinally upon itself, as a leaf in the bud.

coordinations


Image Search
the organization of the different elements of a complex body or activity so as to enable them to work together effectively.
cooperative effort resulting in an effective relationship.
the ability to use different parts of the body together smoothly and efficiently.
the linking of atoms by coordinate bonds.
"both countries agreed to intensify efforts at economic policy coordination"
"action groups work in coordination with local groups to end rainforest destruction"
"changing from one foot position to another requires coordination and balance"

cope

[kəʊp], [koʊp]


Image Search
vi. 应付；对抗；妥善处理
vt. 笼罩；盖上斗篷
n. 长袍；斗篷状物
(of a person) deal effectively with something difficult.
(of a machine or system) have the capacity to deal successfully with.
a long, loose cloak worn by a priest or bishop on ceremonial occasions.
a thing resembling or likened to a cloak.
(in building) cover (a joint or structure) with a coping.
"his ability to cope with stress"
"the roads are barely adequate to cope with the present traffic"
"the bay and the square were a seamless cope"
He was scarcely able to cope with the situation.他几乎不知道如何去应付这个局面。
I don't know how she copes with looking after her family and doing a full-time job.既要照顾家庭又要全天工作，我不知道她是如何对付的。
No one could cope with him in debate.没人能同他在辩论中对抗。
I cannot cope with such a pile of work.我无法处理这么多工作。
How do you cope with the problem of poor vision?怎样解决视力不好这一难题呢?
The cope of clouds covering the city cleared up by mid-day.笼罩城市的厚重乌云在中午时散开了。
The judge was wearing a black cope.这位法官穿著一件黑色的法衣。
The brick cope was corroded by frost damage.这个砖墙已被霜冻腐蚀了。
The cope of clouds covering the city cleared up by mid-day.笼罩城市的厚重乌云在中午时散开了。

cordial

['kɔːdiəl], ['kɔːrdʒəl]


Image Search
n. 兴奋剂；补品
adj. 热忱的；诚恳的；兴奋的
warm and friendly.
strongly felt.
another term for liqueur.
a sweet fruit-flavored drink.
a comforting or pleasant-tasting medicine.
"the atmosphere was cordial and relaxed"
"I earned his cordial loathing"
"wine cups and fruit cordials"
By means of a few drops of strong cordial, the doctor revived the besotted corpse for a few minutes.博士滴了几滴强烈的兴奋剂，使这个没有知觉的身躯复活了几分钟。
It was a cordial affair in which Pancalli expressed his appreciation for the work carried out by Juventus in recent months.这是一次热忱的会晤，潘卡利感谢了近几个月来尤文所做的工作。
Please accept my cordial and humblest apologies.请接受我诚恳的道歉。

(of a person) fat.

cosmopolitan

[ˌkɒzmə'pɒlɪtən], [ˌkɑːzmə'pɑːlɪtən]


Image Search
adj. 世界性的；久经世故的；遍生于世界的；四海一家的
n. 世界主义者
familiar with and at ease in many different countries and cultures.
including people from many different countries.
having an exciting and glamorous character associated with travel and a mixture of cultures.
(of a plant or animal) found all over the world.
a cosmopolitan person.
a cosmopolitan organism or species.
a cocktail typically made with vodka, Cointreau, cranberry juice, and lime juice.
"his knowledge of French, Italian, and Spanish made him genuinely cosmopolitan"
"immigration transformed the city into a cosmopolitan metropolis"
"their designs became a byword for cosmopolitan chic"
New York is a highly cosmopolitan city.纽约是一个高度世界性的城市。
Alexander envisioned a cosmopolitan culture in his new empire.亚历山大打算让他的新帝国具有世界性的文化。
The rose is a cosmopolitan plant.玫瑰是遍生于世界各地的植物。
She has a very cosmopolitan outlook on life.她有四海一家的人生观。

counsel

['kaʊnsl], ['kaʊnsl]


Image Search
n. 劝告；建议；诉讼律师
v. 提供建议；劝告
advice, especially that given formally.
consultation, especially to seek or give advice.
the lawyer or lawyers conducting a case.
give advice to (someone).
give professional psychological help and advice to (someone).
recommend (a course of action).
"the counsel for the defense"
"he was counseled by his supporters to return to Germany"
"he was being counseled for depression"
"the athlete's coach counseled caution"
Good counsel has no price.[谚]忠言无价。
Listen to the counsel of your elders.听从长辈的劝告吧.
Each side of a case in court has its own counsel.法庭上原告和被告双方都有各自的律师。
The court heard counsel for both sides.法庭听取了双方律师的陈述.
Most experts counsel caution in such cases.大多数专家建议在这样的情况下要谨慎从事。
I counsel honesty and hard work.我主张诚实和苦干。
They counsel against traveling at night in such a dangerous country.他们劝告说勿在此危险的国家夜游。
I would counsel you not to marry too young.我劝你不要过早结婚。

counterfeit

['kaʊntəfɪt], ['kaʊntərfɪt]


Image Search
n. 膺品；伪造品
adj. 假冒的；假装的
v. 仿造；伪装；假装
made in exact imitation of something valuable or important with the intention to deceive or defraud.
pretended; sham.
a fraudulent imitation of something else; a forgery.
imitate fraudulently.
pretend to feel or possess (an emotion or quality).
resemble closely.
"two men were remanded on bail on a charge of passing counterfeit $10 bills"
"a counterfeit image of reality"
"he knew the tapes to be counterfeits"
"my signature is extremely hard to counterfeit"
"no pretense could have counterfeited such terror"
"sleep counterfeited Death so well"
This ten-dollar bill is a counterfeit.这张十元钞票是伪钞。
We suspect the paper to be a counterfeit.我们疑心这个证件是伪造的。
This note is counterfeit, but that one's good.这张钞票是假的，那张是真的。
And eyes will be very difficult to counterfeit.而且眼睛将是非常难以仿造的。
It is against the law to counterfeit money.伪造货币是违法的。
She counterfeited alarm when he confessed his love.当他向她示爱时她假装惊讶的样子。

courteous

['kɜːtiəs], ['kɜːrtiəs]


Image Search

Bill is always a courteous youth.比尔是个有礼貌的青年。
He was very courteous and well spoken.他非常殷勤好客，说话又漂亮。

courthouse
