The Republicans had to come to the courthouse to register to vote.共和党人需要到法院大楼登记才能参加选举投票。

cram

[kræm], [kræm]


Image Search
v. 塞满；猛吃；仓促备考
n. 仓促备考；挤成一堆的人群
Cram.
n. 克拉姆(姓氏或男子名)
completely fill (a place or container) to the point that it appears to be overflowing.
force (people or things) into a place or container that is or appears to be too small to contain them.
(of a number of people) enter a place or space that is or seems to be too small to accommodate all of them.
study intensively over a short period of time just before an examination.
"the ashtray by the bed was crammed with cigarette butts"
"it's amazing how you've managed to cram everyone in"
"they all crammed into the car"
"lectures were called off so students could cram for finals"
This box is crammed with Christmas gifts.这个盒子里塞满了圣诞礼物。
He crammed as much candy into his pockets as they would hold.他把口袋都塞满了糖果。
I managed to cram down a few mouthfuls of food.我好歹狼吞虎咽地吃了几口东西。
The teacher tried to cram his pupils.老师试图用填鸭式教学把知识灌输给学生。
I have to cram up six subjects for my examinations.为了考试我得刻苦复习6门课程。
My son go to cram school every evening.我的儿子每晚都去上补习班。
There was such a cram in the church.教堂里挤得要命。
Cram ran a fine race to take the gold medal.克拉姆在赛跑中成绩突出夺得金牌。

credible

['kredəbl], ['kredəbl]


Image Search
adj. 可信的；可靠的
able to be believed; convincing.
capable of persuading people that something will happen or be successful.
"few people found his story credible"
"a credible threat"
It is hardly credible.这是难以置信的。
These denials are simply not credible.这些否认是不可信的。
So far, there is only one credible proposal.到目前为止，只有一个可靠的建议。
But I believe real things are more credible.但是我认为还是现实的东西比较可靠。

creed

[kriːd], [kriːd]


Image Search
n. 宗教信仰；信念
a system of Christian or other religious belief; a faith.
a formal statement of Christian beliefs, especially the Apostles' Creed or the Nicene Creed.
a set of beliefs or aims that guide someone's actions.
"people of many creeds and cultures"
"liberalism was more than a political creed"
People of all colors and creeds have come here to celebrate the holiday.各种肤色和各种宗教信仰的人聚集在这里欢度节日。
The laws apply to everyone irrespective of race, creed or colour.法律适用于所有的人,不分种族、 信仰或肤色。
This faith is the abiding creed of our fathers.这信念是我们祖先的永久的信念。
What is your political creed?你的政治信仰是什么？

cringe

[krɪndʒ], [krɪndʒ]


Image Search
vi. 畏缩；觉得尴尬不安或难为情；阿谀，奉承
n. 畏缩；阿谀，奉承
bend one's head and body in fear or in a servile manner.
experience an inward shiver of embarrassment or disgust.
an act of cringing.
"he cringed away from the blow"
"I cringed at the fellow's stupidity"
People often cringe when they hear the word "fat".人们常常听到“脂肪”这个词后会畏缩。
But just the thought of mentioning it to her made him cringe.可是一想到要向她表明这一想法，他就会犹豫、退缩。
It may be difficult to believe, but some people actually cringe when an opportunity presents itself.令人难以置信的是，有些人竟在机遇来临时畏缩。
His way of sleeping makes me cringe.他睡觉的方式令我生厌。
I cringe when I think of the poems I wrote then.每当我想起我那时写的诗歌就感到很难堪。
I cringe with embarrassment when I reread those first stories I wrote.我重读了我初期编写的故事

crotchety

['krɒtʃəti], ['krɑːtʃəti]


Image Search
adj. 思想奇怪的；脾气坏的
irritable.
"he was tired and crotchety"
His crotchety, even cruel behavior must be mischaracterized too. 他反复无常、甚至是残酷的行为一定也是由于复杂的性格原因。
It seems that he is in crotchety opposition to his father. 看起来，他对他爸爸火气很大，也很敌对。
It was one of thoes rare occasions when I ignored the crotchety old voice that spoiled my fun. 像这样无视那扼杀了我的乐趣的古怪声音，还真是屈指可数。
It's hardly surprising that this bold, or perhaps crotchety, proposal was instantly controversial. 不出所料，这个大胆，些许有些离奇的建议一经提出便立刻引起争议。
My character is the sort of crotchety Yankee show -me type, and I'm not there to actually do the cooking. 我的性格属于那种美国式的想入非非的自我展示型，我实际上不是真的在烹调。
Indeed they don't, Mother. My mother may be crotchety, Miss Potter, but she does have an eye for beautiful things. She was fascinated by your drawings. 是啊,大家都不听了。我母亲也许是有点神神叨叨,波特小姐,但是她可有双善于发现美丽的眼睛。她非常欣赏你的画。

crouch

[kraʊtʃ], [kraʊtʃ]


Image Search
v. 蹲下；屈膝
n. 蹲伏；蜷缩
adopt a position where the knees are bent and the upper body is brought forward and down, sometimes to avoid detection or to defend oneself.
a crouching stance or posture.
"we crouched down in the trench"
He crouched down among the tangled foliage.他蹲下把身子藏在紊乱的叶丛中。
They crouch, back to back, in a sort of hut of fate.他们彼此背靠着背，蹲在一种黑洞似的命运里。
They did not crouch under the oppression.他们受压迫而不屈服。
He chuckled, said, "Very convincing," and then suddenly sank into a crouch, his muscles coiled like a spring.他咯咯地笑着说,“很有说服力，”然后突然蹲伏下来，他的肌肉就像个收紧的弹簧。
They crouch in their corner and weave their web of pale hours, they count their coins sitting in the dust and call me back.他们蜷缩在角落里，编织着他们苍白的时间之网，他们坐在尘土中，数着他们的硬币，召唤我回去。
As he mounted higher, sometimes standing, sometimes clawing his way up in a scrabbling crouch, he peered out from the stairs.他一直向上爬着，有时直着身子，有时蜷缩着身子，挣扎着向上爬着，他从楼梯向四处张望。

crucial

['kruːʃl], ['kruːʃl]


Image Search
adj. 决定性的；关键的
decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something.
of great importance.
"negotiations were at a crucial stage"
"this game is crucial to our survival"
Her work has been crucial to the project's success.她的工作对项目的成功至关重要。
It is crucial that we get this right.我们把这个问题弄明白是极其重要的。
Trust is crucial for successful friendship.相互信任是维系友谊的关键。
The battle had reached a crucial stage.战斗已到了关键阶段。

crude

[kruːd], [kruːd]


Image Search
adj. 天然的；未加工的；粗鲁的；粗糙的；简陋的
n. 原油；天然的物质
in a natural or raw state; not yet processed or refined.
(of figures) not adjusted or corrected.
(of an estimate or guess) likely to be only approximately accurate.
constructed in a rudimentary or makeshift way.
(of an action) showing little finesse or subtlety and as a result unlikely to succeed.
(of language, behavior, or a person) offensively coarse or rude, especially in relation to sexual matters.
natural petroleum.
"crude protein"
"the crude mortality rate"
"a relatively crude nuclear weapon"
"the measure was condemned by economists as crude and ill-conceived"
"a crude joke"
"the ship was carrying 80,000 tons of crude"
China is a country rich in crude oil.中国是一个原油丰富的国家。
The price of crude oil has come down recently.最近原油的价格已经下降了。
This crude glycerin is from pure virgin vegetable oil.这是未加工的甘油，来自纯洁，原始的植物油。
It was crude of him to say that.他那样说太粗鲁了。
We turned upstream to find a crude wooden bridge.我们转向上游走，发现了一座粗糙的木桥。
Primitive man hunted wild animals with crude stone implements.原始社会的人用粗糙的石器猎取野兽。
The great man is said to have been born in a crude hut.据说那个伟人生于一个简陋的小屋里。
In fact, a speciality crude is suitable only for bitumen production.事实上，这种特性的原油只适宜于生产沥青。

culprit

['kʌlprɪt], ['kʌlprɪt]


Image Search
n. 罪犯；起因
a person who is responsible for a crime or other misdeed.
the cause of a problem or defect.
"viruses could turn out to be the culprit"
The hunt is on for the culprit.正在搜捕该罪犯。
The police are now on the scent of the culprit.警方已获得罪犯的线索。
The culprit will be whipped when he is found.那个罪犯找到后就要挨鞭子抽打。
High production costs are the main culprit.高生产成本是主要原因所在。

cumin

['kʌmɪn], ['kʌmɪn]


Image Search
n. 莳萝；小茴香（子）；孜然芹
the aromatic seeds of a plant of the parsley family, used as a spice, especially ground and used in curry powder.
the small, slender plant that bears cumin and grows from the Mediterranean to central Asia.
We want to buy Cumin, Coffee Beans, Peanut, Lentils and Cloves Coffee我们要采购时萝
The kebabs are spiced with cumin, chili pepper and garam masala.菜饼中还需加入孜然芹、辣椒粉、胡椒粉和格兰马撒拉等原料调味。
In this forest, trees are made of broccoli, with peas hanging as fruits and the highways are paved with cumin.在森林中，树是以甘蓝做成并吊著豆子当作果实，以及以小茴香铺成的道路。
After leveling the soil, does he not begin to sow caraway and scatter cumin, wheat and barley and put spelt as the border?当他把地弄平了以后，不是要撒上小茴香，播种大茴香，种植大麦和小麦，地边种玉蜀黍吗？

cunning

['kʌnɪŋ], ['kʌnɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 狡猾的；有眼光的；精巧的；可爱的
n. 【C】狡诈；灵巧
having or showing skill in achieving one's ends by deceit or evasion.
ingenious.
attractive; quaint.
skill in achieving one's ends by deceit.
ingenuity.
"a cunning look came into his eyes"
"plants have evolved cunning defenses"
"the baby will look cunning in that pink print"
"a statesman to whom cunning had come as second nature"
"what resources of energy and cunning it took just to survive"
Many politicians are cunning sophists.许多政客都是狡猾的诡辩家。
The fox is known for its cleverness and cunning.狐狸的机敏和狡猾是人所共知的。
She showed her cunning in the way she avoided answering the question.她对问题避而不答，显示出她很狡猾。
He devised a very cunning scheme to help her.他想出一个帮助她的很好的办法。
John happened to come up with a cunning marketing strategy.约翰突然提出了极富远见的市场策略。
The cunning workman does not quarrel with his tools.（谚）巧匠不挑剔工具。
It takes cunning workmen to make such elaborate furniture.能工巧匠才能制作如此精致的家俱。
What a cunning kitten!这只小猫多么逗人喜爱!
The fox is believed to have a great deal of cunning.人们相信狐狸十分狡猾。
A look of cunning came into her eyes.她的眼睛闪起一丝狡狯的神情。

dabble

['dæbl], ['dæbl]


Image Search
v. 喷洒；玩水；泼溅；涉猎；浅尝
immerse (one's hands or feet) partially in water and move them around gently.
(of a duck or other waterbird) move the bill around in shallow water while feeding.
take part in an activity in a casual or superficial way.
"they dabbled their feet in the rock pools"
"teal dabble in the shallows"
"he dabbled in writing as a young man"
She dabbled her hands in the fountain.她把手伸到喷泉中玩水。
Children like to dabble in water.孩子们喜欢玩水。
He just dabbles in politics.他仅仅是涉足政治而已。
I have to be careful, for I dabble with poisons a good deal.我不得不小心一点,因为我常和毒物接触。
She is a talented musician but is content to just dabble.她很有音乐天赋，但满足于浅尝。

dachshunds


Image Search
n. 腊肠犬（ dachshund的复数）
a dog of a short-legged, long-bodied breed.
Are dachshunds easy to housebreak? 腊肠容易破坏家吗？
A typical example of a long haired dachshund. 长有毛发的达克斯猎狗图片 Long haired dachshund.
Many people say it looks like a Dachshund dog. 很多人都说它像一个达克斯猎狗。
Hi, I am Bobo the Dachshund, do you know me? 你好,我你腊肠狗仔波波呀。
Keep up with the latest Dachshund news from around the world. 跟上最新消息世界各地。
Patience goes a long way with housebreaking a dachshund. 耐心会解决腊肠的破坏性。

data

['deɪtə], ['deɪtə]


Image Search
n. 数据；资料
名词datum的复数形式.
facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
the quantities, characters, or symbols on which operations are performed by a computer, being stored and transmitted in the form of electrical signals and recorded on magnetic, optical, or mechanical recording media.
things known or assumed as facts, making the basis of reasoning or calculation.
a piece of information.
an assumption or premise from which inferences may be drawn.
a fixed starting point of a scale or operation.
The data should be updated once a week.这些数据应该每星期更新一次。
In Name, type a name for the data source.在“名称”中,为数据源键入名称。
Very little data is available.现有的资料十分不足。
The data is still being analyzed.资料仍在分析中。

dawdle

['dɔːdl], ['dɔːdl]


Image Search
v. 磨蹭；浪费时间；闲逛
waste time; be slow.
move slowly and idly.
"I couldn't dawdle over my coffee any longer"
"Ruth dawdled back through the woods"
Look sharp! Do not dawdle about like that.快点！别这么磨磨蹭蹭了。
Look smart! Don't always dawdle about like that!快一点！别总是那么拖拖拉拉！
He dawdles the hours away watching television.他把时间都荒废在看电视上了。
Don't dawdle over your clothing. You're so beautiful already.不要再在衣着上花费时间了，你已经够漂亮的了。
Students scurry around campus during the bleak winter months; they rarely dawdle.萧瑟的冬季里,校园中学生行色匆匆,少有人漫游闲逛。

daze

[deɪz], [deɪz]


Image Search
vt. 使 ... 茫然； 使 ... 眩目
n. 恍惚； 晕眩
make (someone) unable to think or react properly; stupefy; bewilder.
a state of stunned confusion or bewilderment.
"she was dazed by his revelations"
"he was walking around in a daze"
We drove home in an absolute daze.我们茫然一片地驱车回家。
I've been in a complete daze since hearing the news.自从听到那消息，我一直茫然不知所措。
He had been in a daze all the way to New York.他去纽约途中一路恍惚。

debate

[dɪ'beɪt], [dɪ'beɪt]


Image Search
n. 辩论；讨论
vt. 争论；思考
vi. 辩论
a formal discussion on a particular topic in a public meeting or legislative assembly, in which opposing arguments are put forward.
an argument about a particular subject, especially one in which many people are involved.
argue about (a subject), especially in a formal manner.
consider a possible course of action in one's mind before reaching a decision.
"the national debate on abortion"
"the board debated his proposal"
"he debated whether he should leave the matter alone or speak to her"
After a long debate, the house of commons approved the bill.经过长时间的辩论，下议院通过了议案。
We had a long debate as to whether we should spend so much money on space technology.至于我们要否花那么多钱在太空技术上,我们辩论了很久。
Her resignation caused much public debate.她辞职一事引起群众议论纷纷。
There has been heated debate about whether the film should be allowed.关于这场电影是否该通过,人们展开了热烈的讨论。
I don't wish to debate my opinions with you.我不想就我的看法同你辩论。
He debated buying a new car, but didn't in the end.他思量很久是否买辆新汽车,但最后还是没买。
This is a question that they have often debated.这是个他们常讨论的问题。

debt

[det], [det]


Image Search
n. 债务；恩情；负债状态；义务；罪
something, typically money, that is owed or due.
the state of owing money.
a feeling of gratitude for a service or favor.
"I paid off my debts"
"the firm is heavily in debt"
"we owe them a debt of thanks"
He promised to pay his debt within a month.他保证在1个月内偿还债务。
If I pay all my debts I'll have no money.我若还请所有欠债就分文不剩了。
We owe you a debt of gratitude for you help.承蒙帮助，感恩不尽。
The company is deep in debt.这家公司正负债累累。
We'll run into debt if you spend more than our income.要是你花的比我们挣的还多，我们就要欠债了。
You have an obligation to pay your debt to society.你有义务偿还对社会的债务。
Liabilities are the obligatio or debt that a busine must pay in money or services at some time in the future.负债是指将来需用货币或服务偿还的债务或履行的义务。
He's in debt to the extent of200.请求为他犯的偷窃罪从轻量刑。
They said that they would drop the charges if we paid off the debt.他们说还清欠款就可以顶罪了。

debut

['deɪbjuː], [deɪ'bjuː]

the first appearance of a debutante in society.

"the film marked his debut as a director"
"the car makes its world debut"
"a debut album"
"the Rolling Stones debuted at the Marquee"
"the model is expected to debut at $19,000"
"the company is to debut new software"
His debut marks him out for future success.他的首次亮相预示了将来的成功。
He will make his debut for the first team this week.本周他将在第一支出场的队伍中首次亮相。
She made a successful debut.她初次登台获得成功。
The young actress made her debut in the new comedy.这位年轻的女演员在新上演的喜剧里首次登台演出。
A new product will debut next week.一种新产品将在下周面世。
He decided to debut with several other violinists.他决定与其他几名小提琴手一起首次登台演出。
The network will debut her new series next March.电视联播网将于明年三月首次放映她的新的连续剧。
Our company will debut the new phones during the expo.我们公司将在展览会期间首次推出新款电话机。

deceive

[dɪ'siːv], [dɪ'siːv]


Image Search
vt. 欺骗
vi. 行骗
(of a person) cause (someone) to believe something that is not true, typically in order to gain some personal advantage.
(of a thing) give a mistaken impression.
fail to admit to oneself that something is true.
be sexually unfaithful to (one's regular partner).
"I didn't intend to deceive people into thinking it was French champagne"
"the area may seem to offer nothing of interest, but don't be deceived"
"enabling the rulers to deceive themselves about the nature of their own rule"
It's not honorable to deceive them.欺骗他们是不光彩的。
He was foiled in his attempt to deceive us.他企图欺骗我们,但没有得逞。
He deceived me into signing the papers.他骗我在文件上签了字。
You are deceiving yourself if you still believe that she loves you.你如果还相信她爱你，你就是在欺骗自己。
Appearances can deceive.外表是有欺骗性的。
Who are ready to believe are easy to deceive.轻信的人容易受骗。

decline

[dɪ'klaɪn], [dɪ'klaɪn]


Image Search
v. 下降；减少；变弱；拒绝；倾斜
n. 衰微；跌落；晚年
(typically of something regarded as good) become smaller, fewer, or less; decrease.
diminish in strength or quality; deteriorate.
politely refuse (an invitation or offer).
politely refuse to do something.
(especially of the sun) move downward.
bend down; droop.
(in the grammar of Latin, Greek, and certain other languages) state the forms of (a noun, pronoun, or adjective) corresponding to cases, number, and gender.
a gradual and continuous loss of strength, numbers, quality, or value.
the gradual setting of the sun.
any disease in which bodily strength gradually fails, especially tuberculosis.
"the birth rate continued to decline"
"her health began to decline"
"Caroline declined the coffee"
"the company declined to comment"
"a serious decline in bird numbers"
I wish prices would decline.但愿物价下降。
The price of 14 inches TV set declined from 400 to 320 yuan each.14英寸的电视机每台从400元降到320元。
He spent his declining years in the country.他在乡间度过晚年。
I must regretfully decline your kind invitation.我很抱歉必须拒绝你的盛情邀请。
The wall declined slightly on account of the earthquake.墙壁因地震而倾斜。
This decline in vigour with the passing of time is called ageing.这种随着时间流逝的活力衰退就叫做衰老。
There is a sharp decline in unemployment.失业率急剧下跌。
The decline of sales embarrassed the company.销路下降使公司陷于财政困难。

decree

[dɪ'kriː], [dɪ'kriː]


Image Search
n. 法令；判决
v. 颁布；裁定；注定
an official order issued by a legal authority.
the issuing of a decree.
a judgment or decision of certain law courts.
order (something) by decree.
"the king ruled by decree"
"the government decreed a ban on any contact with the guerrillas"
This decree obliges unions to delay strikes .这项法令使协会不得不推迟罢工。
The decree imposed strict censorship of the media.这个法令强制实行严格的媒体审查制度。
The final decree dissolved their marriage.最后的判决解除了他们的婚姻关系。
This decree has the force of law behind it.这一裁决有法律的力量作后盾。
The dictator decreed that his birthday would be a public holiday.该独裁者发布命令，将其生日定为公众假期。
The court decreed that he should be transported to Australia.法院判决将他流放到澳洲。
Fate decreed that Ulysses should travel long and far.命运注定尤里西斯要作长途跋涉的旅行。

She wanted to buy his love with her dedication to him and his work.她想通过自己对他及其工作的奉献来换取他的爱。
His talent and dedication will insure his success.他的才气和执着将确保他成功。
The book's dedication reads "To Mother".本书献词写道：“献给母亲”。
This was the dedication of the altar, after that it was anointed.这就是用膏抹坛之后，为行奉献坛之礼所献的。

defensive

"he was very defensive about that side of his life"

Our troops took up defensive positions on high ground overlooking the river.我部队在临河高地上占据了防御阵地。
When asked to explain her behavior, she gave a very defensive answer.当问她为什么要这样做时，她极力为自己辩护。
She's very defensive about her part in the affair.她极力掩盖她在此事中充当的角色。
They put entirely on the defensive.他们被迫完全处于守势。

defiant

Image Search

Correspondents say the appointment seems intended to send a defiant message to South Korea.通讯员称该任命似乎意在向韩国发出挑衅的信号。

deficient

[dɪ'fɪʃnt], [dɪ'fɪʃnt]

"they trashed the legislation as deficient"
We are deficient in hands.我们人手不够。
The crops are suffering from deficient rain.庄稼因雨量不足而遭受损害。
Our knowledge of the matter is deficient.我们对此事了解不足。
A mentally deficient person is one who is weak-minded.一个智力上不足的人是个低能的人。
The evidence he gave us was deficient.他提供给我们的证据不充分。
His training in linguistics is deficient.他在语言学方面受到的训练是有缺陷的。
He couldn't join the army because of his deficient sight.由于视力缺陷，他没办法参军。

[dɪ'flekt], [dɪ'flekt]


Image Search

(of an object) change direction after hitting something.
cause (someone) to deviate from an intended purpose.
cause (something) to change orientation.
"the bullet was deflected harmlessly into the ceiling"
"the ball deflected off his body"
"she refused to be deflected from anything she had set her mind on"
"the compass needle is deflected from magnetic north by metal in the aircraft"
The missile deflected from its trajectory.导弹已偏离轨道。
The bullet hit a wall and was deflected from its course.子弹击中墙壁而改变了方向。
Don't try to deflect me from my intention!别想改变我的意图。

deft

Image Search

"a deft piece of footwork"

She is deft at dealing with reporters.她善於与记者周旋。
Sister Irene was a tall, deft woman in her early thirties.艾琳修女是个三十出头、精明能干的高个妇女。
With deft fingers she untangled the wire.她用灵巧的手指解开了金属线。
My sister is a clever and deft person who can make pretty dresses.姐姐是个心灵手巧的人，做的衣服很漂亮。

dejection

[dɪ'dʒekʃn], [dɪ'dʒekʃn]


Image Search
n. 沮丧；[医]排泄(物)
a sad and depressed state; low spirits.
"he was slumped in deep dejection"
Your dejection will do no good to your health.你的沮丧情绪对你的身体不利。
She walked about listlessly, humming to herself in dejection.她没精打采地走来走去，沮丧地低声哼着。
People don't have to worry too much about getting bird flu if they haven't touched living fowls or sparrows and their dejection before.人如果没有接触受感染的活家禽、雀鸟及其粪便就无须过分担心会患上禽流感。

deliberate

[dɪ'lɪbərət], [dɪ'lɪbərət]


Image Search
adj. 深思熟虑的；故意的；从容不迫的
v. 仔细考虑；研讨
done consciously and intentionally.
fully considered; not impulsive.
done or acting in a careful and unhurried way.
engage in long and careful consideration.
consider (a question) carefully.
"a deliberate attempt to provoke conflict"
"a deliberate decision"
"a careful and deliberate worker"
"she deliberated over the menu"
"jurors deliberated the fate of those charged"
She has a slow, deliberate way of talking.她谈话的方式缓慢而审慎.
He told us a deliberate lie.他存心说谎。
It had more the appearance of a deliberate crime than an accident.那很像是蓄意的罪行，而不像是意外的事故。
He entered the room with deliberate steps.他从容不迫地走进室内。
We had no time to deliberate on the problem.我们没有时间仔细思考这个问题.
How long did it take you to deliberate about the problem?你们花了多长时间来讨论那个问题?

delicate

['delɪkət], ['delɪkət]


Image Search
adj. 微妙的；精美的；纤细的；脆弱的；敏锐的；美味的
very fine in texture or structure; of intricate workmanship or quality.
(of a color or a scent) subtle and subdued.
(of food or drink) subtly and pleasantly flavored.
easily broken or damaged; fragile.
(of a person, animal, or plant) susceptible to illness or adverse conditions.
(of a state or condition) easily upset or damaged.
requiring sensitive or careful handling.
(of a person or an action) tactful and considerate.
skillful and finely judged; deft.
(of an instrument) highly sensitive.
a delicate fabric or garment made of such fabric.
"a spider's web, strong yet delicate"
"delicate pastel shades"
"a delicate cream sauce"
"delicate china"
"his delicate health"
"owls have a delicate balance with their habitat"
"delicate negotiations"
"the most delicate tact was called for"
"his delicate ball-playing skills"
The international situation is very delicate at present.目前的国际形势极其微妙。
He persecuted me with various delicate questions.他用种种微妙的问题把我难倒了。
She wears a dress with delicate lace.她穿了一件带有精致花边的裙子。
Don't grasp at the delicate branch, or you may break it.不要去抓这嫩枝,你会把它折断的。
The scientist needs some delicate instruments.这位科学家需要一些精密的仪器。
He has a delicate sense of smell.他嗅觉灵敏。
They are the most delicate morsels.这些确是最好吃的部分。

delude

[dɪ'luːd], [dɪ'luːd]


Image Search
v. 欺骗；迷惑；蛊惑
impose a misleading belief upon (someone); deceive; fool.
"too many theorists have deluded the public"
He deluded her with empty promises.他用虚假的诺言哄骗了她。
She deluded herself with false hopes.她以虚幻的希望欺骗自己。
You must not delude him into believing it.你不可误导他相信那件事。
Candidates running for president often delude the voters with election promises.参加总统竞选的候选人往往以竞选许诺来蛊惑选民。

deluge

['deljuːdʒ], ['deljuːdʒ]


Image Search
n. 大洪水；暴雨；泛滥
v. 泛滥；大量涌入
a severe flood.
the biblical Flood (recorded in Genesis 6–8).
a heavy fall of rain.
a great quantity of something arriving at the same time.
inundate with a great quantity of something.
flood.
"a deluge of rain hit the plains"
"a deluge of complaints"
"he has been deluged with offers of work"
"the country was deluged with rain"
Disturbed by the sounds of mankind, the gods, led by Enlil, set forth a deluge.被人类的声音所扰乱，众神，在恩利尔的带领下，发起了一场大洪水。
You could see him now, in this deluge of distraction.现在你在这混乱的暴雨中，能够看见他。
Hundreds of children were crushed as the floors collapsed in a deluge of falling bricks and concrete.随着楼层的垮塌，数以百计的儿童被掩埋在如暴雨般跌落的砖块和水泥之下。
The deluge of spare cash has two main sources.游资泛滥的原因有两点。
The spring thaw caused the river to deluge the region.春天冰雪融化，使河水泛滥淹没了那地区。
The deluge of spare cash has two main sources.游资泛滥的原因有两点。
The spring thaw caused the river to deluge the region.春天冰雪融化，使河水泛滥淹没了那地区。

denounce

[dɪ'naʊns], [dɪ'naʊns]


Image Search
v. 谴责；告发；通告废除
publicly declare to be wrong or evil.
inform against.
"the Assembly denounced the use of violence"
"some of his own priests denounced him to the King for heresy"
The minister's action was denounced in the newspaper.部长的行为受到报界的指责。
American trade policies have been denounced by some European governments.一些欧洲政府指责美国的贸易政策。
They denounced him to the police as a criminal.他们向警方告发他是罪犯。
Somebody denounced him to the military police as a spy.有人向宪兵队告发他为间谍。
Each State Party to this Convention may denounce the Convention.本公约缔约国均可通告废除本公约。

depict

[dɪ'pɪkt], [dɪ'pɪkt]


Image Search
vt. 描述；描绘；画
show or represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form.
portray in words; describe.
"youth is depicted as a time of vitality and good health"
Her novel depicts life in modern London.她的小说描写的是伦敦现代的生活。
The book depicts him as a rather unpleasant character.这本书把他刻画成一个相当令人讨厌的人物。
This painting depicts the birth of Venus.这幅画描绘的是维纳斯的诞生。
It's a picture depicting him as a clown.这是一幅把他画成小丑的画。

deportment

[dɪ'pɔːtmənt], [dɪ'pɔːrtmənt]


Image Search
n. 风度；举止
a person's behavior or manners.
"there are team rules governing deportment on and off the field"
He maintained a hard, careless deportment.他保持一种严酷的，漠不关心的态度。
The old housekeeper, with a gracious severity of deportment , waves her hand towards the great staircase.老管家带着一种庄重严肃的态度，朝那座大楼梯挥了一下手。
He is austere and grave in deportment.他举止庄重严肃。
Young ladies used to have lessons in deportment.少女以前要上仪态课。

designate

['dezɪɡneɪt], ['dezɪɡneɪt]


Image Search
vt. 指定；标明；把...定名为；选派
adj. 指定的
appoint (someone) to a specified position.
officially assign a specified status or ascribe a specified name or quality to.
signify; indicate.
appointed to an office or position but not yet installed.
"he was designated as prime minister"
"certain schools are designated “science schools”"
"the term “brainstem” designates the medulla, pons, and mesencephalon"
"the Director designate"
She was designated sportswoman of the year.她被指定为本年度的体坛明星。
The chairman has designated that boy as his successor.主席已经指定那个男孩作他的继承人。
Black lines designate boundaries on this map.在这幅地图上黑线标示疆界。
The ruler of a kingdom is designated a king.王国的统治者称作国王。
He was designated to lead the expedition.他被指派率领远征队。
The ambassador designate is going to meet honored foreign guests.大使指定人选将要迎接外国贵客。

desolate

['desələt], ['desələt]


Image Search
adj. 荒凉的；荒芜的；孤单寂寞的
(of a place) deserted of people and in a state of bleak and dismal emptiness.
feeling or showing misery, unhappiness, or loneliness.
make (a place) bleakly and depressingly empty or bare.
make (someone) feel utterly wretched and unhappy.
"a desolate moor"
"I suddenly felt desolate and bereft"
"the droughts that desolated the dry plains"
"he was desolated by the deaths of his treasured friends"
We saw few houses in the desolate valley.在这荒凉的山谷里,我们很少见到房子。
The railway station became desolate in the war.战争期间，这个火车站变得荒凉了。
Heavy rain will wash away the soil from desolate hills.大雨将把泥土从荒凉的山丘上冲走。
This place is desolate of all vegetation.这个地方不长草木。
They planted grass seed on the desolate hills.他们在那些荒芜的山丘上撒播草籽。
I felt so desolate and so angry.我感到异常孤愤。
He has been desolate since his wife died.自从妻子去世后, 他一直很孤独。

despair

[dɪ'speə(r)], [dɪ'sper]


Image Search
n. 绝望；失望
vi. 失望
the complete loss or absence of hope.
lose or be without hope.
"driven to despair, he throws himself under a train"
"we should not despair"
A person is most disappointed when he is in despair.一个人在绝望时最失望。
He has been in the abyss of despair.他已陷入绝望的深渊。
He fluctuated between hope and despair.他时而充满希望时而失望。
He is the despair of all other pianists.他使其他所有的钢琴家都感到失望。
We cannot despair of humanity, since we are ourselves human beings.身为人类,我们不能对人性失望。
They despaired of winning the game.他们不抱比赛得胜的希望。

desperately

['despərətli], ['despərətli]


Image Search
adv. 拼命地；绝望地；极严重地；孤注一掷地
in a way that shows despair.
used to emphasize the extreme degree of something.
"he looked around desperately"
"he desperately needed a drink"
I desperately want to keep my teeth.我拼命地想保住我的牙齿。
He cut desperately at me rope in an attempt to free his foot.他拼命地割那根绳子，以摆脱脚上的束缚。
He desperately saw her disappear into the crowd.他绝望地看着她消失在人群中。
The wild boar had its tusk sunk deeply into a tree and howled desperately.野猪的獠牙陷在了树里，绝望地嗥叫着。

deter

[dɪ'tɜː(r)], [dɪ'tɜːr]


Image Search
vt. 阻止；威慑；威吓
discourage (someone) from doing something, typically by instilling doubt or fear of the consequences.
prevent the occurrence of.
"only a health problem would deter him from seeking re-election"
"strategists think not only about how to deter war, but about how war might occur"
No difficulty can deter us from trying it again.没有困难可以阻止我们再试一次。
The extreme cold deterred him from going out.极度寒冷使他打消外出的念头。
It's this edge that gives newclear weapons their power to deter.正是这个优势赋予了核武器威慑力量。
The fact that we have the big bombs will deter our enemies from attacking us我们拥有这种重型炸弹的事实威慑住敌人不敢向我们进攻。
A cloudy sky may deter a man from undertaking a journey.阴暗天色有时使人不敢启程。

detest

[dɪ'test], [dɪ'test]


Image Search
v. 厌恶；痛恨
dislike intensely.
"of all birds the carrion crow is the most detested by gamekeepers"
I detest all affectation.我厌恶一切矫揉造作的行为。
She detests having to talk to people at parties.她讨厌在宴会上为应酬而和人交谈。
I detest people who tell lies.我痛恨撒谎的人。
I detest violence with my whole being.我毕生谴责暴力行为。

detract

[dɪ'trækt], [dɪ'trækt]


Image Search
vi. 减损
vt. 转移
reduce or take away the worth or value of.
deny or take away (a quality or achievement) so as to make its subject seem less impressive.
divert or distract (someone or something) away from.
"these quibbles in no way detract from her achievement"
"it detracts not one iota from the credit due to them"
"the complaint was timed to detract attention from the ethics issue"
His bad manners detract from his good character.他的不礼貌减损了他的品质。
Pointing fingers will merely take up more time and detract from the argument for practicality.用手指指向对方只会浪费更多的时间，并减损实用性的根据。

detrimental

[ˌdetrɪ'mentl], [ˌdetrɪ'mentl]


Image Search
adj. 有害的
n. 有害的人或事
tending to cause harm.
"releasing the documents would be detrimental to national security"
Lack of sleep is detrimental to one's health.缺乏睡眠有害健康。
Smoking is detrimental to health.吸烟封健康是有害的。
He works long hours to the detriment of his health.他长时间的工作，有损健康。

devastate

['devəsteɪt], ['devəsteɪt]


Image Search
vt. 毁坏；使荒芜；使震惊
destroy or ruin (something).
cause (someone) severe and overwhelming shock or grief.
"the city was devastated by a huge earthquake"
"she was devastated by the loss of Damian"
They intended to devastate the town at one stroke.他们企图一举摧毁全城。
Our Embassy was devastated by three bombs of NATO.我们的使馆被北约的三枚炸弹炸毁了。
The country was devastated by a long war.该国因遭到长期战争的破坏而荒废。
I was devastated by the news of the wreck.我获悉失事的消息感到十分震惊。

devastated

['devəsteɪt], ['devəsteɪt]


Image Search
vt. 毁坏；使荒芜；使震惊
destroy or ruin (something).
cause (someone) severe and overwhelming shock or grief.
"the city was devastated by a huge earthquake"
"she was devastated by the loss of Damian"
They intended to devastate the town at one stroke.他们企图一举摧毁全城。
Our Embassy was devastated by three bombs of NATO.我们的使馆被北约的三枚炸弹炸毁了。

I was devastated by the news of the wreck.我获悉失事的消息感到十分震惊。

deviate

['diːvieɪt], ['diːvieɪt]


Image Search
v. 偏离；脱离
n. 叛离者；偏差；不正常的人或物
adj. 离经叛道的
depart from an established course.
depart from usual or accepted standards.
old-fashioned term for deviant.
"you must not deviate from the agreed route"
"those who deviate from society's values"
Don't always deviate to minor issues.不要老是偏离到次要问题上去。
You will not deviate from your present course.你不能偏离目前航线
His remarks usually deviate from truth.他的话通常都与事实不符。
Do not deviate from the beaten track.不要逸出常轨。

devotion

[dɪ'vəʊʃn], [dɪ'voʊʃn]


Image Search
n. 虔诚；献身；奉献；热爱
love, loyalty, or enthusiasm for a person, activity, or cause.
religious worship or observance.
prayers or religious observances.
"Eleanor's devotion to her husband"
"the order's aim was to live a life of devotion"
Through great effort perhaps he is just cultivating a little devotion.尽管经过了很大的努力，他也许只是培养出少许的虔诚。
We were deeply moved by their devotion.我们为他们的献身精神所感动。
His devotion to science is well known.他对科学的献身精神为人熟知。
His devotion led him to the priesthood.他的信仰使他成为祭司。
A career needs our devotion all our lives.一项事业需要我们毕生的奉献。
His devotion to music is plain to see.他对音乐的挚爱是显而易见的。
We' re moved by his devotion to his students.他热爱自己的学生，我们很受感动。

diabetes

[ˌdaɪə'biːtiːz], [ˌdaɪə'biːtiːz]


Image Search
a disease in which the body’s ability to produce or respond to the hormone insulin is impaired, resulting in abnormal metabolism of carbohydrates and elevated levels of glucose in the blood and urine.
The poor old man was afflicted with diabetes.那可怜的老人受到糖尿病的折磨。
The doctor diagnosed her illness as diabetes.医生诊断她的病是糖尿病。
What determines when type 1 diabetes develops?什么导致了1型糖尿病?
What is so different about diabetes in children?为什么儿童糖尿病差异如此巨大?
Your vision is also a result of diabetes.你的视力也是糖尿病的结果。
Diabetes can cause many complications.糖尿病的合并症很多。

dichotomy

[daɪ'kɒtəmi], [daɪ'kɑːtəmi]


Image Search
n. 两分；分裂；二分法
a division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
repeated branching into two equal parts.
"a rigid dichotomy between science and mysticism"
But perhaps instead it is time to ask whether the dichotomy between banks and markets might be false.不过，与之相反，现在或许正是我们反思银行和市场两分法是否正确的时机。
This dichotomy has its uses, but it can cause problems if taken too literally.这种二分法有它的用途，但如果死板地应用也会引发一些问题。
We also find an interesting dichotomy in the impact of these shareholders depending on the business group affiliation of firms.我们也发现这些股东对商业集团从属公司的依赖性的影响有有趣的二分法。

differentiate

[ˌdɪfə'renʃieɪt], [ˌdɪfə'renʃieɪt]


Image Search
vt. 区分；使差异；求导数
vi. 区别；产生差别；区别对待
recognize or ascertain what makes (someone or something) different.
identify differences between (two or more things or people).
make (someone or something) appear different or distinct.
make or become different in the process of growth or development.
transform (a function) into its derivative.
"children can differentiate the past from the present"
"he is unable to differentiate between fantasy and reality"
"Twain was careful to differentiate Huck's speech from that of other white people"
"the receptors are developed and differentiated into sense organs"
Can you differentiate one variety from the other?你能将这两个品种区别开来吗?
He cannot differentiate the two flowers.他无法辨认这两种花。
The only way to differentiate yourself from the competition is through service.只有服务才能真正使你在竞争中凸显。
I cannot differentiate between these two things.我无法区别这两个东西。
This genus of plants differentiates into many species.这种植物可分为许多种类。
It's wrong to differentiate between boys and girls.男女孩区别相待是错误的。

dignity

['dɪɡnəti], ['dɪɡnəti]


Image Search
n. 尊严；高贵；端庄
the state or quality of being worthy of honor or respect.
a composed or serious manner or style.
a sense of pride in oneself; self-respect.
a high or honorable rank or position.
"a man of dignity and unbending principle"
"he bowed with great dignity"
"it was beneath his dignity to shout"
"he promised dignities to the nobles in return for his rival's murder"
He would do nothing beneath his dignity.他决不愿意干任何有损自身尊严的事。
The real dignity of a man lies in what he is, not in what he has.一个人的真正尊严在于他的品格，而非他的财富。
A man's dignity depends not upon his wealth but upon his character.人高尚与否不取决於他的财富,而取决於他的品格。
She bears herself with dignity.她举止庄重大方。
There was something impressive about Julia's quiet dignity.朱丽亚的宁静端庄给人印象很深。

dilemma

[dɪ'lemə], [dɪ'lemə]


Image Search
n. 困境；进退两难
a situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives, especially equally undesirable ones.
a difficult situation or problem.
an argument forcing an opponent to choose either of two unfavorable alternatives.
"the people often face the dilemma of feeding themselves or their cattle"
"the insoluble dilemma of adolescence"
In the process of modern urban development, we often find ourselves in a dilemma.在都市的发展中,我们往往会陷入困境。
The bad weather put us in a dilemma——shall we move on or go back?糟糕的天气使我们进退两难——是继续前进呢,还是打道回府？

dill

[dɪl], [dɪl]


Image Search
n. 莳萝；小茴香
an aromatic annual herb of the parsley family, with fine blue-green leaves and yellow flowers. The leaves and seeds of dill are used for flavoring and for medicinal purposes.
Coming out of a cave,I saw a dill.从洞口出来，我看到一棵莳萝草。

dilute

[daɪ'luːt], [daɪ'luːt]


Image Search
vt. 稀释；冲淡
adj. 冲淡的；稀释的
make (a liquid) thinner or weaker by adding water or another solvent to it.
make (something) weaker in force, content, or value by modifying it or adding other elements to it.
reduce the value of (a shareholding) by issuing more shares in a company without increasing the values of its assets.
(of a liquid) made thinner or weaker by having had water or another solvent added to it.
(of a solution) having a relatively low concentration of solute.
(of color or light) weak or low in concentration.
"bleach can be diluted with cold water"
"the reforms have been diluted"
"a dilute solution of potassium permanganate"
"a short measure of dilute sun"
Dilute the bleach in a gallon of water.用一加仑水稀释漂白粉。
The fragrances are highly diluted.芳香剂被高度稀释了。
The nurse diluted the drug with saline water.护士用生理盐水把药加以稀释。
He thought Rear Admiral Henry's presence might dilute the tension of the dinner.他认为亨利少将的参加也许可以冲淡这顿晚餐的紧张气氛。
Readers feel dilute after reading Wei Yingwu's poetry, in reality, the poet concealed his solitude under this kind dilute style.韦应物诗歌给人以冲淡的感觉，其实在这种冲淡的风格下隐含着诗人性格的孤独因素。
The doctor told him to bathe his eyes with a very dilute solution of boric acid.医生叮嘱他用稀释的硼酸溶液洗他的眼睛。

disavow

[ˌdɪsə'vaʊ], [ˌdɪsə'vaʊ]


Image Search
v. 否认；不赞成
deny any responsibility or support for.
"he appears to be in denial of his own past, which he continually disavows"
I disavow all responsibility for you.我不承认对你有任何责任。
She disavows any part (ie says she was not involved) in the plot.她否认参与了这一密谋。

discard

[dɪs'kɑːd], [dɪs'kɑːrd]


Image Search
vt. 丢弃；抛弃
vi. 丢牌
n. 丢牌；废牌
get rid of (someone or something) as no longer useful or desirable.
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play (a card that is neither of the suit led nor a trump), when one is unable to follow suit.
a person or thing rejected as no longer useful or desirable.
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) a card played which is neither of the suit led nor a trump, when one is unable to follow suit.
"Hilary bundled up the clothes she had discarded"
He discarded his winter clothing.他把冬天穿的衣服都丢弃了。
My mother-in-law would discard them on the spot.我的岳母是会当场把它们扔掉的。
History discarded him.他被历史所抛弃。
You've got to discard before you can pick up another card.你得先打出一张牌，才能拿另一张牌。

discern

[dɪ'sɜːn], [dɪ'sɜːrn]


Image Search
v. 辨别；看出；察觉
perceive or recognize (something).
distinguish (someone or something) with difficulty by sight or with the other senses.
"I can discern no difference between the two policies"
"she could faintly discern the shape of a skull"
Sometimes it's not easy to discern between the true and the false.有时辨别真伪并不容易。
He was just able to discern the road in the dark.他在黑暗中勉强能辨出道路。
They can discern me in spite of the fog.虽然有雾，但他们能认得出我。
I soon discerned that the man was lying.我马上察觉出那人在撒谎。
We could discern from his appearance that he was upset.我们从他的样子可以察觉出他不快。

discharge

[dɪs'tʃɑːdʒ], [dɪs'tʃɑːrdʒ]


Image Search
v. 排出；释放；解雇；放电；解除；清偿债务
n. 卸货；释放；发射；放电；准许离开；排出物
tell (someone) officially that they can or must leave, in particular.
send (a patient) out of the hospital because they are judged fit to go home.
dismiss or release (someone) from a job, especially from service in the armed forces or police.
release (someone) from the custody or restraint of the law.
relieve (a juror or jury) from serving in a case.
relieve (a bankrupt) of liability.
release (a party) from a contract or obligation.
allow (a liquid, gas, or other substance) to flow out from where it has been confined.
(of an orifice or diseased tissue) emit (pus, mucus, or other liquid).
release or neutralize the electric charge of (an electric field, battery, or other object).
(of a person) fire (a gun or missile).
(of a firearm) be fired.
(of a person) allow (an emotion) to be released.
unload (cargo or passengers) from a ship.
do all that is required to fulfill (a responsibility) or perform (a duty).
pay off (a debt or other financial claim).
(of a judge or court) cancel (an order of a court).
cancel (a contract) because of completion or breach.
the action of discharging someone from a hospital or from a job.
an act of releasing someone from the custody or restraint of the law.
the action of relieving a bankrupt from residual liability.
the action of discharging a liquid, gas, or other substance.
a substance that has been discharged.
the release of electricity from a charged object.
a flow of electricity through air or other gas, especially when accompanied by emission of light.
the action of firing a gun or missile.
the action of unloading a ship of its cargo or passengers.
the action of doing all that is required to fulfill a responsibility or perform a duty.
the payment of a debt or other financial claim.
the action of canceling an order of a court.
"he ordered that 1,671 prisoners of war be discharged from prison"
"the insurer is discharged from liability from the day of breach"
"industrial plants discharge highly toxic materials into rivers"
"the swelling will eventually break down and discharge pus"
"the electrostatic field that builds up on a monitor screen can be discharged"
"when you shoot you can discharge as many barrels as you wish"
"there was a dull thud as the gun discharged"
"he discharged his resentment in the harmless form of memoirs"
"the ferry was discharging passengers"
"an existing mortgage to be discharged on completion"
"his discharge from the hospital"
"four days in jail and one year conditional discharge"
"those germs might lead to vaginal discharge"
"large volumes of sewage discharge"
"slow discharge of a condenser is fundamental to oscillatory circuits"
"a sizzling discharge between sky and turret"
"a police permit for discharge of an air gun"
"directors must use skill in the discharge of their duties"
"money paid in discharge of a claim"
The Nile discharge itself into the Mediterranean.尼罗河水注入地中海。
The water pipe doesn't discharge freely.水管排水不畅。
The judge discharged the prisoner.法官把囚犯释放了。
I am going to discharge our chauffeur.我要解雇我们的司机。
Severe variations deform the discharge curves.严重者使放电曲线发生畸变。
Thus, the discharge lamp starts with certainty.如此，可以确定地启动放电灯。
The carrier may discharge the goods into any depot.承运人可将货物卸入任何仓库。
We have to discharge our debts.我们必须偿还债务。
How long will the discharge of the cargo take?卸货需要多久？
The prisoner was glad to get his discharge.囚犯获准释放,感到很高兴。
The simultaneous discharge of these guns destroyed enemy's defence.这些枪炮的同时开火,摧毁了敌人人防守。
According to the electron collision ionization theory of Townsend, the electron avalanche is the basic process in gas discharge.根据汤逊电子碰撞电离理论,电子崩是气体放电最基本的过程。
So far,China has designated 34 dumping areas for dredged materials of the third category and four areas for midair oil discharge.到目前为止，中国已建立了34个三类疏浚物倾倒区，4个空中放油区。

discomfort

[dɪs'kʌmfət], [dɪs'kʌmfərt]


Image Search
n. 不便之处；不适
v. 使不适
slight pain.
a state of mental unease; worry or embarrassment.
lack of physical comfort.
make (someone) feel uneasy, anxious, or embarrassed.
cause (someone) slight pain.
"the patient complained of discomfort in the left calf"
"his remarks caused her discomfort"
"the discomforts of too much sun in summer"
"she liked to discomfort my mother by her remarks"
"the patient's condition has discomforting symptoms"
One has to bear a little discomfort while travelling.旅行中总要忍受一点不便。
The homes were pushed outwards even at the cost of the discomfort of commuting.很多家庭甚至不惜忍受往返的不便,把家往城外搬。
I was unhappy because of the discomforts of travel.我因为旅行的不适而感到不快。
She still suffers considerable discomfort from her injury.她因那次受伤至今仍感不适。
The tart reply did not discomfort him.那尖刻的回答并没有使他难过。

disconcert

[ˌdɪskən'sɜːt], [ˌdɪskən'sɜːrt]


Image Search
v. 使困惑；使仓皇失措；使尴尬
disturb the composure of; unsettle.
"the abrupt change of subject disconcerted her"
He was disconcerted to find the other guests formally dressed.他看到其他客人都穿得正正经经的，觉得很尴尬。

discredit

[dɪs'kredɪt], [dɪs'kredɪt]


Image Search
v. 败坏…的名声；怀疑；不信
n. 丧失名誉；怀疑；不信任；丢脸
harm the good reputation of (someone or something).
cause (an idea or piece of evidence) to seem false or unreliable.
loss or lack of reputation or respect.
a person or thing that is a source of disgrace.
"his remarks were taken out of context in an effort to discredit him"
"recent attempts to discredit evolution"
"they committed crimes that brought discredit upon the administration"
"the ships were a discredit to the country"
They concocted a plot to discredit the governor.他们捏造了一个故事来败坏州长的名誉。
There was good reason to discredit the witness有充足的理由怀疑证人。
There was good reason to discredit the witness.有充分理由不相信那位证人。
There is no reason to discredit what she says.没理由不信她说的话.
That brought discredit on his name.那件事使他的名誉受损。
This will bring the store into discredit.这会使那家商店失去信用。
Violent fans bring discredit on their teams.粗野的球迷给他们的球队丢脸。
Don't be a discredit to the collective.别给集体丢脸。

discreet

[dɪ'skriːt], [dɪ'skriːt]


Image Search
adj. 谨慎的；不引人注意的；朴素的，简易的
careful and circumspect in one's speech or actions, especially in order to avoid causing offense or to gain an advantage.
intentionally unobtrusive.
"we made some discreet inquiries"
"a discreet cough"
It was not discreet of you to say that.你那样说有欠考虑。
Be more discreet or you'll get yourself talked about.要更谨慎些－－否则你就会成为人们的话柄。
I'll certainly be most discreet in my conversation.我在谈话中当然会十分小心的。
It was a discreet apartment in a quiet street.那是间位於一条僻静的街上不引人注意的公寓房间。

discretion

[dɪ'skreʃn], [dɪ'skreʃn]


Image Search
n. 谨慎；慎重；自行决定
the quality of behaving or speaking in such a way as to avoid causing offense or revealing private information.
the freedom to decide what should be done in a particular situation.
"she knew she could rely on his discretion"
"it is up to local authorities to use their discretion in setting the charges"
We reposed great trust in his tact and discretion.我们极为信任他的机智和谨慎。
You must choose you friends with discretion.你一定要慎重地择友。
I won't tell you what time to leave, you're old enough to use your own discretion.我不告诉你什么时候离开，你已经长大了，该自己作出决定。
The hours of the meetings will be fixed at the monitor's discretion.开会时间将由班长自行决定。

disgraced

[dɪs'ɡreɪs], [dɪs'ɡreɪs]


Image Search
n. 耻辱
v. 耻辱；丢脸
having fallen from favor or a position of power or honor; discredited.
bring shame or discredit on (someone or something).
fall from favor or lose a position of power or honor.
"the disgraced Wall Street financier"
"you have disgraced the family name"
"he has been publicly disgraced for offenses of which he was not guilty"
The dirty classrooms are a disgrace to the school.肮脏的教室是学校的耻辱。
Her actions brought disgrace on his family.她的行为给她的家庭带来了耻辱。
You will bring disgrace on yourself by doing this.你这样做会给自己带来耻辱。
He quit in disgrace over the bribe.他因受贿而不光彩地辞职了。
He fell into disgrace with his companions.他的朋友都看不起他。
He will die before he shall disgrace himself.他宁肯死而决不受侮辱。
Harry is in disgrace because of his behaviour.哈里因为行为失检而丢脸。
Her son's disgrace broke her heart.她儿子丢脸的事让她很难过。

disinterested

[dɪs'ɪntrəstɪd], [dɪs'ɪntrəstɪd]


Image Search
adj. 不感兴趣的；无私欲的；公平的；公正的
动词disinterest的过去式和过去分词形式.
not influenced by considerations of personal advantage.
having or feeling no interest in something.
"a banker is under an obligation to give disinterested advice"
"her father was so disinterested in her progress that he only visited the school once"
But, the mere idea of having that much money is enough to make even the most disinterested students pay attention in a social studies class.可是，哪怕仅仅是想到有这么一大笔钱，已经足够使那些对此最不感兴趣的学生也关注起这门社会学课程。
He is a disinterested person.他是一个没有私心的人。
The God makes everyone disinterested.上帝对每个人都是公平的！
The judge gave a disinterested verdict.法官作出了公正的判决

dismayed


Image Search
adj. 惊慌的；灰心的
动词dismay的过去式和过去分词.
cause (someone) to feel consternation and distress.
"they were dismayed by the U-turn in policy"
I picked up the reciver between two sticky fingers and was dismayed when I recognized the voice of Mrs Bates.我用两只粘着面糊的手指夹起听筒，当听出是Bates太太的声音时，我茫然不知所措。
He was dismayed at his lack of understanding.他对自已的无知感到沮丧。
We were all dismayed at his refusal to co-operate.他不肯合作使我们感到非常失望。
It dismayed us that the project had been canceled.那个计划取消了，这让我们非常惊讶。

disparage

[dɪ'spærɪdʒ], [dɪ'spærɪdʒ]


Image Search
vt. 蔑视；贬损
regard or represent as being of little worth.
"he never missed an opportunity to disparage his competitors"
The Arya Samaj did much to encourage Hindu nationalism, but it did not disparage the knowledge of the West, and it established many schools and colleges.雅利安社大力地鼓励了印度的民族主义，但它并没有蔑视西方的知识，也建立了很多学校和大学。

dispatch

[dɪ'spætʃ], [dɪ'spætʃ]


Image Search
v. 派遣；发送；迅速完成；处死
n. 急件；派遣；发送；新闻报道
send off to a destination or for a purpose.
deal with (a task, problem, or opponent) quickly and efficiently.
kill.
the sending of someone or something to a destination or for a purpose.
speed in action.
an official report on state or military affairs.
a report sent in by a newspaper's correspondent from a faraway place.
the killing of someone or something.
"he dispatched messages back to base"
"they dispatched the opposition"
"he dispatched the animal with one blow"
"a resolution authorizing the dispatch of a peacekeeping force"
"the situation might change, so he should proceed with dispatch"
"in his battle dispatch he described the gunner's bravery"
"the legendary dispatch of villains by a hero"
A messenger was dispatched to take the news to the soldiers at the front.一名通讯员被派去给前线士兵送消息。
We have to ask you to dispatch the consignment immediately.我们得要求你立即发送该批货物。
We soon dispatched the chocolate cake.我们很快就吃完了那个巧克力蛋糕。
The criminal will be dispatched today.那名罪犯将于今日被处决。
I threw the dispatch to him and asked him to take prompt actions.我把那份急件扔给他,让他立刻采取措施。
We welcome the dispatch of the peace-keeping force.我们队派出维和部队此举表示欢迎。
Please hurry up the dispatch of these telegrams.请赶快将这些电报发出去。
We've got a dispatch sent from New York to Beijing by Wang Gang.我们收到了王刚从纽约发回北京的新闻报道。

dispel

[dɪ'spel], [dɪ'spel]


Image Search
v. 驱散；消除
make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear.
"the brightness of the day did nothing to dispel Elaine's dejection"
It is the task of a fighter to dispel darkness.驱散黑暗，这是战士的任务。
Nothing could dispel the torpidity of the indifferent audience.任何东西都无法驱散那些冷漠观众的困倦。
I thought,if I had caused the cloud,it was my duty to make an effort to dispel it.我想，如果是我引起了这块乌云，那我就该负责努力驱散它。
The wind soon dispelled the fog.风很快就把雾吹散了。
We are trying to dispel his doubts.我们正试图消除他的疑虑。

disperse

[dɪ'spɜːs], [dɪ'spɜːrs]


Image Search
v. 分散；散开
distribute or spread over a wide area.
go or cause to go in different directions or to different destinations.
(with reference to gas, smoke, mist, or cloud) thin out or cause to thin out and disappear.
divide (light) into constituents of different wavelengths.
distribute (small particles) uniformly in a medium.
denoting a phase dispersed in another phase, as in a colloid.
"storms can disperse seeds via high altitudes"
"the crowd dispersed"
"the earlier mist had dispersed"
"emulsions should be examined after storage for droplet size of the disperse phase"
The police dispersed the crowd.警方驱散群众。
The wind dispersed the cloud from the sky.风吹散了天上的云。
The enemy had to disperse and hide in caves.敌人不得不分散藏身于洞穴之中。
The crowd dispersed.人群纷纷散开。
The children disperse for the holidays.孩子们放假了。
You disperse money too liberally.你的钱花得太大手大脚了。
The police fired into the air in an attempt to disperse the crowd.警察朝天开枪，企图驱散人群。

display

[dɪ'spleɪ], [dɪ'spleɪ]


Image Search
n. 显示；陈列；炫耀
vt. 显示；表现；夸示
make a prominent exhibition of (something) in a place where it can be easily seen.
(of a computer or other device) show (information) on a screen.
give a conspicuous demonstration of (a quality, emotion, or skill).
(of a male bird, reptile, or fish) engage in a specialized pattern of behavior that is intended to attract a mate.
a performance, show, or event intended for public entertainment.
a collection of objects arranged for public viewing.
a notable or conspicuous demonstration of a particular type of behavior, emotion, or skill.
conspicuous or flashy exhibition; ostentation.
a specialized pattern of behavior by the males of some species of birds, reptiles, and fish that is intended to attract a mate.
the arrangement and choice of type in a style intended to attract attention.
an electronic device for the visual presentation of data.
the process or facility of presenting data on a computer screen or other device.
the data shown on a computer screen or other device.
"the palace used to display a series of Flemish tapestries"
"the aggressive kind of baseball he displayed as a player"
"she photographed the peacock, which chose that moment to display"
"a display of fireworks"
"the museum houses an informative display of rocks"
"a display of great virtuosity"
"a flagrant display of wealth"
"the teal were indulging in delightful courtship displays"
"a 17-inch color display"
"the processing and display of high volumes of information"
Let's display the figures and see what we have.通过显示一下数字看看我们能看到什么。
The bottles of whisky on display are all dummies.所陈列的威士忌酒都是假的。
There will be a display of bronze statuary in this museum next week.下星期这个博物馆将举办一个青铜雕塑作品展览。
He made a display of his learning.他夸耀自己有学问。
I have rarely seen her display any sign of emotion.我难得见到她将喜怒形于色。
He had an opportunity to fully display his talents.他有了大显身手的机会。

disputed

[dɪsp'juːtɪd], [dɪsp'juːtɪd]


Image Search

argue about (something); discuss heatedly.

compete for; strive to win.
resist (a landing or advance).
"I disputed the charge on the bill"
"the accusations are not disputed"
"the two drivers crashed while disputing the lead"
"I formed my line and prepared to dispute the advance of the foe"
The authorship of the discovery is disputed.这一发现归谁尚有争议。
There was a disputed call in the second set.第二盘比赛有一个有争议的判决。

disquieting

[dɪs'kwaɪətɪŋ], [dɪs'kwaɪətɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 引起不安的
动词disquiet的现在分词.
inducing feelings of anxiety or worry.

"he found Jean's gaze disquieting"
"she felt disquieted at the lack of interest the girl had shown"
The president's speech caused considerable disquiet in some european capital.总统的演说在一些欧洲国家首都引起很大不安。
The strength of the dollar is causing considerable disquiet on the stock exchange.美元表现坚挺在证券交易所中引起很大的不安。

disregard

[ˌdɪsrɪ'ɡɑːd], [ˌdɪsrɪ'ɡɑːrd]


Image Search
vt. 不顾；忽视
n. 漠视；不理会
pay no attention to; ignore.
the action or state of disregarding or ignoring something.
"the body of evidence is too substantial to disregard"
"blatant disregard for the law"
We cannot disregard his coming late to work so often.对他上班经常迟到,我们不能不管。
He doesn't disregard the footnotes.他并没有不注意脚注。
He disregarded his doctor's advice.他无视医生的劝告。
You can't just disregard the security problem.你可不能忽视安全问题。
The official has shown a total disregard for the needs of the poor.这个官员对穷人的需求表现出完全漠视的态度。
He shows ruthless disregard for other people's feelings.他对别人的感情漠不关心。
He has the greatest disregard all formality.他全然不顾一切礼节。
This order is in disregard of the constitution.这项命令置宪法于不顾。
They adopted the decision in disregard of our repeated warnings.他们置我们的多次警告于不顾，采纳了该项决定。

dissect

[dɪ'sekt], [dɪ'sekt]


Image Search
v. 解剖；切细；仔细研究；详细分析
methodically cut up (a body, part, or plant) in order to study its internal parts.
analyze (something) in minute detail.
"novels that dissect our obsession with cities and urban angst"
In biology class we had to dissect a frog.上生物课时我们得解剖青蛙。
In spite of this some brave scientists did dissect bodies.尽管如此，一些勇敢的科学家仍坚持解剖人体。

dissemination

[dɪˌsemɪ'neɪʃn], [dɪˌsemɪ'neɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 传播；宣传；传染
the act of spreading something, especially information, widely; circulation.
"dissemination of public information"
This conforms to the light straight line dissemination rule.这符合光的直线传播规律。
Disease and coincident dissemination of virus may occur to produce an epidemic.本病及同时传播着的病毒即可引起一次流行。
He was fully bent upon the dissemination of Chinese culture all over the world.他一心致力于向全世界宣传中国文化。
To attract consumers, many real estate companies use various means marketing, the developers have not attended widespread dissemination of information sent clerk Shan.为吸引消费者，许多房地产公司采用各种手段进行促销，一些没有参会的开发商则派业务员到处散发宣传单。

dissent

[dɪ'sent], [dɪ'sent]


Image Search
n. 异议
v. 持异议
the expression or holding of opinions at variance with those previously, commonly, or officially held.
refusal to accept the doctrines of an established or orthodox church; Nonconformity.
hold or express opinions that are at variance with those previously, commonly, or officially expressed.
separate from an established or orthodox church because of doctrinal disagreement.
"there was no dissent from this view"
"two members dissented from the majority"
They expressed their dissent from official policy.他们对官方的政策表示出异议。
It is too late to make any dissent.现在提出异议太晚了。
The right to dissent is part of our political system.有持异议的权利是我们政治体制的组成部分。
If enough members dissent, the new bill won't be approved.假如持异议的会员够多，新法案就不会被核准。

distasteful

[dɪs'teɪstfl], [dɪs'teɪstfl]


Image Search
adj. 味道差的；令人反感的；讨厌的；不合意的
causing dislike or disgust; offensive; unpleasant.
"customers complained about the distasteful odor"
The medicine is distasteful but good for you.这药虽难吃,但对你身体有好处。
His behavior was distasteful to everyone.他的行为令大家反感。
Smoking is distasteful to my family.我一家都不喜欢抽烟。
I find his attitude highly distasteful.我觉得他的态度很令人厌恶。
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby.这个建议不合盖茨比的口胃。

distinction

[dɪ'stɪŋkʃn], [dɪ'stɪŋkʃn]


Image Search
n. 荣誉；差别；优秀；对比；区分
a difference or contrast between similar things or people.
the separation of things or people into different groups according to their attributes or characteristics.
excellence that sets someone or something apart from others.
a decoration or honor awarded to someone in recognition of outstanding achievement.
recognition of outstanding achievement, such as on an examination.
"there is a sharp distinction between domestic politics and international politics"
"these procedures were to be applied to all births, without distinction"
"a novelist of distinction"
"he gained the highest distinction awarded for excellence in photography"
"I made a distinction in Greek"
These are the highest distinctions that have ever been given by our government.这些是我国政府迄今授予的最高荣誉称号。
Keller received many awards of great distinction.凯勒被授予很多殊荣奖。
He had the distinction of being the first man to walk on the moon.他以月球上第一个行走而闻名于世。
There is a fine distinction between the two words.这两个字之间有细微区别。
He passed the examination with distinction.他以优异成绩通过考试。
She had the distinction of being the first woman to swim the Channel.她卓尔不群,因为她是第一个横渡英吉利海峡的女子。
This is a refrigerator of distinction.这是一台优质电冰箱。
There is a distinction between what he says and what he does.他言行不一。
I don't understand your distinction: surely all painting is art?我不明白你为什麽要有所区分,所有的绘画不都是艺术吗?

distort

[dɪ'stɔːt], [dɪ'stɔːrt]


Image Search
vt. 歪曲；扭曲；变形
vi. 歪曲
pull or twist out of shape.
become twisted out of shape.
give a misleading or false account or impression of.
change the form of (an electrical signal or sound wave) during transmission, amplification, or other processing.
"a grimace distorted her fine mouth"
"the pipe will distort as you bend it"
"many factors can distort the results"
"you're distorting the sound by overdriving the amp"
The reporter distorted the facts.记者们歪曲了事实。
How dare he distort the facts so brazenly!他怎么敢如此肆无忌惮地歪曲事实！
The government was accused of having systematically distorted the protester's case.政府因为有计划地歪曲抗议者的观点而受到责难。
This journalist distorted the spokesman's remarks.这名记者曲解了该发言人的话。
Arthritis had distorted her fingers.关节炎使她手指变形了。
The loudspeaker seemed to distort his voice.他的声音从喇叭里传出来好像失真了。
The bias of a reporter can easily distort the news.记者的偏见很容易歪曲新闻的报导。
Some newspapers distort news to make it seem more exciting.一些报纸为了使新闻看起来更令人兴奋而歪曲事实。

distress

[dɪ'stres], [dɪ'stres]


Image Search
n. 不幸；危难；苦恼；痛苦
vt. 使苦恼；使痛苦
extreme anxiety, sorrow, or pain.
the state of a ship or aircraft when in danger or difficulty and needing help.
suffering caused by lack of money or the basic necessities of life.
a state of physical strain, exhaustion, or, in particular, breathing difficulty.
another term for distraint.
cause (someone) anxiety, sorrow, or pain.
give (furniture, leather, or clothing) simulated marks of age and wear.
"to his distress he saw that she was trembling"
"vessels in distress on or near the coast"
"the poor were helped in their distress"
"they said the baby was in distress"
"I didn't mean to distress you"
"the manner in which leather jackets are industrially distressed"
I pray that you will have pity on my distress.我请求你可怜可怜我的不幸遭遇。
I gripe more from habit than from genuine distress.我抱怨是出于我的习惯，并非遭遇真正的不幸。
They sent a distress rocket.他们发出了一枚呼救信号火箭。
His wild behavior was a great distress to his mother.他的放荡的行为使他的母亲极为苦恼。
What are you looking so distressed for?什么事情使你看起来如此烦恼？
The sick man showed signs of distress.那个生病的男人表现出痛苦的迹象。
Two in distress make sorrow less.灾难二人共，痛苦可减轻。
Don't distress yourself about it.别为那件事苦恼了。
He couldn't distress her with his own terrible dilemma.他不能用自己糟糕的困境来折磨她。

diver

['daɪvə(r)], ['daɪvər]


Image Search
n. 跳水者；潜水员
a person or animal that dives, in particular.
a person who dives as a sport.
a person who wears a diving suit to work under water.
British term for loon1.
"an Olympic diver"
"a diver at the oil terminal"
The diver first drew a deep breath.跳水员先深深地吸了一口气。
The diver poised on the edge of the high board.跳水运动员在高台边上站稳。
The young diver is working under the water with a diving suit.潜水员穿着潜水衣正在水下工作。

diversity

[daɪ'vɜːsəti], [daɪ'vɜːrsəti]


Image Search
n. 多样性；差异
the state of being diverse; variety.
a range of different things.
"there was considerable diversity in the style of the reports"
"newspapers were obliged to allow a diversity of views to be printed"
We should get a thorough understanding about the cultural diversity of the United States.我们应该对美国文化的多样性有一个全面的了解。
Diversity is conducive to the learning environment.多样化对学习环境确有益处。
India has huge diversity and could evolve into a trading club and become rich.印度国内差异巨大,完全可能演变成一个自由贸易俱乐部,最终实现致富。

docile

['dəʊsaɪl], ['dɑːsl]


Image Search
adj. 容易控制的；温顺的
ready to accept control or instruction; submissive.
"a cheap and docile workforce"
In every sense she is docile and obedient to him.她对他可谓百依百顺。
He trembled lest he himself should lose a docile pupil.他担心自己会失去一个听话的学生。
The house faces a docile body of water.这幢房子面朝一泓平静的湖水。
Giant pandas have very docile temperaments.大熊猫的性情很温顺。
Dan is easy to teach, but his brother is not so docile.丹很容易教，但是他弟弟就不这么温顺了。

dogged

['dɒɡɪd], ['dɔːɡɪd]


Image Search
adj. 顽固的；顽强的
动词dog的过去式和过去分词.
having or showing tenacity and grim persistence.
follow (someone or their movements) closely and persistently.
(of a problem) cause continual trouble for.
act lazily; fail to try one's hardest.
grip (something) with a mechanical device.
"success required dogged determination"
"photographers seemed to dog her every step"
"their finance committee has been dogged by controversy"
"she has dogged the door shut"
His dogged pursuit of the presidency was turning into a national joke.他执拗地谋求总统职位的行为变成了全国的笑柄。
He did it with dogged determination.他以顽强的决心做了这件事。
They are met with dogged resistances.他们遭受到顽强的抵抗.
Although he's less talented, he won by sheer dogged persistence.他虽天赋不高，但全凭坚韧的毅力赢得了胜利。

dole

[dəʊl], [doʊl]


Image Search
vt. 发放救济
n. 施舍品；失业救济金
n. <古>悲伤
benefit paid by the government to the unemployed.
a charitable gift of food, clothes, or money.
a person's lot or destiny.
distribute shares of something.
sorrow; mourning.
"she is drawing on the dole"
"the scanty portions of food doled out to them"
I doled out the food to all the children.我把食品发放给所有的孩子们。
You can't expect us to dole out money like a public charity.你们不能指望我们像慈善机构一样分钱。
Life on the dole brings sadness to the soul.靠人施舍过活，精神不会好受。
He received the fixed dole every month.他每个月都能领到固定的救济金。
After she lost a leg, she went on the dole.在她失去一条腿后，她开始登记领取救济金。

domestic

[də'mestɪk], [də'mestɪk]


Image Search
adj. 家庭的；国内的；驯养的
n. 佣人；家仆
relating to the running of a home or to family relations.
of or for use in the home rather than in an industrial or office environment.
(of a person) fond of family life and running a home.
(of an animal) tame and kept by humans.
existing or occurring inside a particular country; not foreign or international.
a person who is paid to help with menial tasks such as cleaning.
a product not made abroad.
a stout seed- or fruit-eating bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, typically having gray and white plumage.
a pigeon descended from the wild rock dove, kept for racing, showing, and carrying messages, and common as a feral bird in towns.
"domestic chores"
"domestic appliances"
"she was not at all domestic"
"domestic cattle"
"the current state of US domestic affairs"
The store deals in objects of domestic utility.那家商店出售家庭用品。
My value for domestic tranquility should much exceed theirs.我应该远比他们重视家庭的平静生活。
Washington responded by freezing the price of domestic oil.华盛顿作出的反应是冻结国内的石油价格。
We adopt an active attitude towards drawing on overseas fund to make up for domestic fund shortage.我们采取积极的态度吸引海外资金以弥补国内资金短缺。
She likes keeping domestic birds.她喜欢饲养家禽。
His domestics are all in years.他的佣人全都上了年纪。
The working conditions of domestics have received media attention.家仆的工作状况得到了新闻媒介的关注。

dominate

['dɒmɪneɪt], ['dɑːmɪneɪt]


Image Search
v. 支配；控制；统治；占优势；俯视；高耸于
have a commanding influence on; exercise control over.
be the most important or conspicuous person or thing in.
(of something tall or high) have a commanding position over; overlook.
"the company dominates the market for operating system software"
"the race was dominated by the 1992 champion"
"a picturesque city dominated by the cathedral tower"
That way, he can dominate the game.那样他才能支配比赛。
He desires to dominate over others.他很想支配别人。
He has authority, but he doesn't try to dominate (others).他有权威
They had the ambition to dominate this small country.他们有控制这个小国的野心。
The strong usually dominate the weak .强者通常统治弱者。
Sports, though important, should not dominate our schools.运动虽然重要,但不应在学校中占首要地位。
The two new buildings dominate the whole town.这两座新建筑俯瞰整个城市。
The Acropolis dominates the city of Athens.雅典的卫城高耸于雅典全城之上。

dormant

['dɔːmənt], ['dɔːrmənt]


Image Search
adj. 休眠的；睡眠的；静止的；潜伏的；匿名的；（动物等）冬眠的
(of an animal) having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep.
(of a plant or bud) alive but not actively growing.
(of a volcano) temporarily inactive.
(of a disease) causing no symptoms but not cured and liable to recur.
(of an animal) depicted lying with its head on its paws.
"dormant butterflies"
Many living things are dormant in winter.很多生物到了冬季都休眠。
The professor would try to awake their dormant and sluggish faculties.这位教授应该试图唤醒他们沉睡和懒散的天赋。
A dormant volcano may erupt after an interval.睡眠状态的火山经过一段时间后还会喷发。
Many dormant branches of our organization are now springing to active life.我们组织中有许多沉寂的部门现在突然活跃起来。
As soon as they meet again his dormant love for her is rekindled.他们一见面,他对她的旧情如干柴烈火般又重新燃起。

doubtful

['daʊtfl], ['daʊtfl]


Image Search
adj. 可疑的；怀疑的；不确定的
feeling uncertain about something.
not known with certainty.
improbable.
not established as genuine or acceptable.
"he looked doubtful, but gave a nod"
"the fire was of doubtful origin"
"it is doubtful whether these programs have any lasting effect"
"of doubtful legality"
It is doubtful whether it is true or not.这件事的真假是可疑的。
The fact that he won the first place is doubtful.他得了第一名是让人可疑的。
He is an author of doubtful reputation.他是一位名声不太好的作家。
The ethics of his decision are doubtful.他的这一决定是否合乎道德规范值得怀疑。
I am doubtful about the propriety of granting such a request.我怀疑答应这项要求是否合适。
It is doubtful whether the old man will recover from the operation.那老人手术后是否会康复难以确定。

drag

[dræɡ], [dræɡ]


Image Search
v. 拖；拉；迫使；缓慢行进；进行过久；扯进；打捞
n. 拖；拉；累赘；阻力
n. 男子穿的女子服装
pull (someone or something) along forcefully, roughly, or with difficulty.
take (someone) to or from a place or event, despite their reluctance.
go somewhere wearily, reluctantly, or with difficulty.
move (an icon or other image) across a computer screen using a tool such as a mouse.
(of a person's clothes or an animal's tail) trail along the ground.
catch hold of and pull (something).
engage in a drag race.
(of a ship) trail (an anchor) along the seabed, causing the ship to drift.
(of an anchor) fail to hold, causing a ship or boat to drift.
search the bottom of (a river, lake, or the sea) with grapnels or nets.
deliberately mention an unwelcome or unpleasant fact.
involve someone or something in (a situation or matter), typically when such involvement is inappropriate or unnecessary.
introduce an irrelevant or inappropriate subject.
bring someone or something to a lower level or standard.
(of time, events, or activities) pass slowly and tediously.
(of a process or situation) continue at tedious and unnecessary length.
protract something unnecessarily.
(of a person) inhale the smoke from (a cigarette).
the action of pulling something forcefully or with difficulty.
the longitudinal retarding force exerted by air or other fluid surrounding a moving object.
a person or thing that impedes progress or development.
unnatural motion of a fishing fly caused by the pull of the line.
an iron shoe that can be applied as a brake to the wheel of a cart or wagon.
a boring or tiresome person or thing.
an act of inhaling smoke from a cigarette.
clothing more conventionally worn by the opposite sex, especially women's clothes worn by a man.
short for drag race.
a street or road.
a private vehicle like a stagecoach, drawn by four horses.
a thing that is pulled along the ground or through water, in particular.
a harrow used for breaking up the surface of land.
an apparatus for dredging a river or for recovering the bodies of drowned people from a river, a lake, or the sea.
another term for dragnet.
influence over other people.
a strong-smelling lure drawn before hounds as a substitute for a fox or other hunted animal.
a hunt using a strong-smelling lure.
one of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of a stroke preceded by two grace notes, which are usually played with the other stick.
"we dragged the boat up the beach"
"my girlfriend is dragging me off to Atlantic City for a week"
"I have to drag myself out of bed each day"
"the nuns walked in meditation, their habits dragging on the grass"
"desperately, Jinny dragged at his arm"
"they were caught dragging on Francis Lewis Blvd"
"frogmen had dragged the local river"
"pieces of evidence about his early life were dragged up"
"he had no right to drag you into this sort of thing"
"politics were never dragged into the conversation"
"the economy will be dragged down by inefficient firms"
"the day dragged—eventually it was time for bed"
"the dispute between the two families dragged on for years"
"he dragged out the process of serving them"
"the drag of the current"
"Larry was turning out to be a drag on her career"
"working nine to five can be a drag"
"he took a long drag on his cigarette"
"a fashion show, complete with men in drag"
"the main drag"
"they had the education but they didn't have the drag"
He dragged the heavy case across the floor.他在地板上拖着那个沉重的箱子。
shrug aside不予理会
She dragged herself out of bed, still half asleep.她挣扎着起了床,还是睡眼惺忪。
She always drags behind us.她总是在我们后面吃力地跟着。
The first hour of the movie really dragged.那部电影的前一个小时真的是过得很慢。
I don't want to drag out this argument any further.我不想再就这场争论进一步拖长下去。
She dragged up that incident just to embarrass me.她又扯起那件事故意想使我难堪。
They dragged the canal for the missing child.他们用拖网沿运河打捞失踪孩子的尸体。
The cat is really excited by the drag of the basket on the floor.在地板上来来回回拖着篮子可着实让那只猫兴奋了一回。
The drag of the his son up to top of the mountain exhausted him.把他的儿子拉上山顶可真累坏了他。
Walking is a drag--let's take the car.走路太费事了——我们坐汽车吧。
High interest rates are a drag on the housing market.高利率是住房市场上的一个阻力。

drastic

['dræstɪk], ['dræstɪk]


Image Search

drawback

['drɔːbæk], ['drɔːbæk]


Image Search
n. 缺点；退税；退款；不利条件；弊
a feature that renders something less acceptable; a disadvantage or problem.
an amount of excise or import duty remitted on imported goods that the importer re-exports rather than sells domestically.
"the main drawback of fitting catalytic converters is the cost"
The great drawback to living near a main road is noise.住在大街旁最大的缺点是噪音。
Everything has its drawbacks.凡事都有不足之处。
Many people are talking about the impact of export drawback system reform on the economy in China these days.这些天来许多人都在讨论出口退税制度改革对我国经济的影响。
Illness is a great drawback to a learner.患病对学生来说是大为不利的。
The bad weather is a major drawback.恶劣天气是一个主要的障碍。
The only drawback to the plan is its expense.该计划实施的唯一障碍是经费问题。

[dred], [dred]

a person with dreadlocks.

greatly feared; dreadful.

I dread to think what will happen if she finds out the truth.我不敢去想她知道真相后会怎么样。
Much of what we dread is really due to indistinctness of outline.畏生于不明，大抵如此。
The Jews lived in dread of being caught.这些犹太人生活在会遭到拘捕的恐惧之中。
My greatest dread is that my parents will find out.我最担心的就是父母会察觉出来。
A raid from the north, on the other hand, must have been a matter for dread.另一方面,来自北部的袭击必然是一件可怕的事。
The countryside lay as under some dread enchantment.乡村好像躺在某种可怖的魔法之下。

duration

He finished the work of three years' duration.他用三年的时间完成了这项工作。
The duration of marriage is related most obviously to the expectation of life.很明显，婚姻生活的持续时间与人的预期寿命有关。
Well, I'm stuck here for the duration.哎，这段时间我只得呆在这儿了。
Let's hope the gunmen will hold off for the duration of the cease-fire.但愿持枪歹徒在停火期间能约束自己的行动。

economical

[ˌiːkə'nɒmɪkl], [ˌiːkə'nɑːmɪkl]

requiring fewer resources or costing less money.
"the government's economic policy"
"economic history"
"many organizations must become larger if they are to remain economic"
"solar power may provide a more economic solution"
She is an economical housekeeper and feeds her family cheaply.她是一个节俭的家庭主妇，她全家的花销不大。
We are advocate economical life.我们提倡俭朴的生活。
This is not an economical method of heating.这不是一种经济的取暖方式。
She writes novels with economical style.她以简练的风格写小说。
She is economical in her use of salt when cooking.她烹饪时用盐很少。
A monthly is more economical than 4 weeklies.一张月票比四张周票上算。
When we had done the costings on the project, it was clear it would not be economical to go ahead with it.我们计算了成本，清楚表明这项工程不合算。

[ɪ'kɒnəmaɪz], [ɪ'kɑːnəmaɪz]

=economise（英）

Our electricity bills are higher than we can afford–we must start to economize.我们的电费已经高得付不起了——得节省些了。

eerie

['ɪəri], ['ɪri]


Image Search
adj. 怪诞的；可怕的；奇异的；害怕的
strange and frightening.
"an eerie green glow in the sky"
The eerie glow filled the cabin as the pressure built around them.当压力在他们周围建造的时候，怪诞的赤热装满了小屋。
The sky had an eerie yellow-orange hue, with the sun glowing behind a peculiar haze.天空呈现出怪诞的橘黄色调，太阳隐在一层奇异的雾霭后透出昏黄的光晕。
Near an ear, a nearer ear, a nearly eerie ear.靠近一只耳朵，一只近一些的耳朵，一只近乎可怕的耳朵。
So what's so eerie about this name?但这名字有什麽可怕的呢？
An eerie wind blew through the assembled throng.一阵奇异的风吹过拥挤的人群。
Churning mist adds an eerie ambiance to your Halloween table.搅动的薄雾给你的万圣节餐桌添加了一种奇异的气氛。

['eɡplɑːnt], ['eɡplænt]


Image Search
n. <美>茄子；黑紫色
the large egg-shaped fruit of an Old World plant, eaten as a vegetable. Its skin is typically dark purple, but the skin of certain cultivated varieties is white or yellow.
a dark purple color like the skin of the eggplant.
the large plant of the nightshade family that bears the eggplant fruit.
The braised eggplant is delicious today.今天的红烧茄子很好吃。

egotist

['iːɡətɪst], ['iːɡətɪst]


Image Search
n. 自大者；自我中心的人
a person who is excessively conceited or self-absorbed; self-seeker.
"he is a self-absorbed egotist"
You need to be an egotist to succeed in politics. 要在政治上成功就必须自负。
I think you mean egotist， Tom said. 我想是你把我看成自我主义者了。
Richter：Because I'm an egotist. 李希特：因为我很自我中心。
If your club tries to big itself up, you are a monstrous egotist. 如果你的俱乐部想要充大，那你也是一个恶魔般的自我中心论者。
If you're proud of your achievements, you're an egotist. 如果你送花给她，你是在追求点什么。
But he was too much the egotist to reach the polish which Hurstwood possessed. 不过他过于自顾自，没有赫斯渥所具有的那种修养。

egress

v. 外出
the action of going out of or leaving a place.
a way out.
the right or freedom to come out or go out.
another term for emersion.
go out of or leave (a place).
"direct means of access and egress for passengers"
"a narrow egress"
"they'd egress the area by heading southwest"
