The act or an instance of mystifying.神秘化神秘化的行为或事例

myth

[mɪθ], [mɪθ]


Image Search
n. 神话；虚构的故事
a traditional story, especially one concerning the early history of a people or explaining some natural or social phenomenon, and typically involving supernatural beings or events.
traditional stories or legends collectively.
a widely held but false belief or idea.
a misrepresentation of the truth.
a fictitious or imaginary person or thing.
an exaggerated or idealized conception of a person or thing.
mythological or mythology.
"the heroes of Greek myth"
"he wants to dispel the myth that sea kayaking is too risky or too strenuous"
"attacking the party's irresponsible myths about privatization"
"the book is a scholarly study of the Churchill myth"
This is the story of a myth of our times.这是一个关于我们这个时代的神话故事。
Venus is one of the goddess in Greek myth.维纳斯是希腊神话中的女神之一。
The rich uncle of whom he boasts is only a myth.他吹嘘的那个有钱的叔叔只是个乌有翁。
His story about is very wealthy is a complete myth.关于他非常富有的说法完全是捏造出来的。
I don't believe in the myth of love at the first sight.我不相信一见钟情的说法。

nag

[næɡ], [næɡ]


Image Search
vt. 不断唠叨；指责；困扰，使…烦恼
n. 小马；驽马；竞赛马
annoy or irritate (a person) with persistent fault-finding or continuous urging.
be persistently painful, troublesome, or worrying to.
a person who nags someone.
a persistent feeling of anxiety.
a horse, especially one that is old or in poor health.
a horse suitable for riding as opposed to a draft animal.
"she constantly nags her daughter about getting married"
"something nagged at the back of his mind"
"he felt once again that little nag of doubt"
Don't nag me!别在我面前唠叨！
She nagged him into doing what she wanted.她向他唠叨，使他不得不去做她所要的事。
The problem had been nagging me for weeks.那问题把我困扰了几个星期.
I have never seen a nag like this one.我从来没见过这样的矮小马。
The nag has been with Henry for so many years that it is hard for him to part from it.这匹老马跟随亨利这么多年了,亨利很难与它分离。

navigate

['nævɪɡeɪt], ['nævɪɡeɪt]


Image Search
vi. 航行；驾驶；操纵
vt. 航行；驾驶；横渡；<口>设法穿过，走过，经过
plan and direct the route or course of a ship, aircraft, or other form of transportation, especially by using instruments or maps.
travel on a desired course after planning a route.
(of an animal) find its way, especially over a long distance.
(of a passenger in a vehicle) assist the driver by reading the map and planning a route.
(of a ship or boat) sail; proceed.
sail or travel over (a stretch of water or terrain), especially carefully or with difficulty.
guide (a vessel or vehicle) over a specified route or terrain.
move from one accessible page, section, or view of a file or website to another.
"they navigated by the stars"
"he taught them how to navigate across the oceans"
"whales use their own inbuilt sonar system to navigate"
"we'll go in my car—you can navigate"
"we sailed out surrounded by loose ice while navigating around larger grounded icebergs"
"ships had been lost while navigating the narrows"
"she navigated the car safely through the traffic"
"the new layout makes it easier to navigate through their atlas of world maps"
The river became too narrow and shallow to navigate.河道变得又窄又浅，无法航行。
Many captains depend on electronic devices to navigate their ships.许多船长依靠电子仪器来驾驶他们的船。
Hyperlinks make it much easier to navigate through a document.超链接使到你在文档中更容易的操纵。
The large ship could not navigate the river.那艘大轮船不能在河里航行。
Many captains depend on electronic devices to navigate their ships.许多船长依靠电子仪器来驾驶他们的船。
The city's organic growth hasn't exactly made it the easiest place to navigate.这个城市有组织的发展并没有使得其成为易于驾驶的地方。
He was the first man to navigate the Atlantic alone.他是第一位单独横渡大西洋的人。
We next had to navigate a complex network of committees.我们下一步必须设法使各级委员会予以通过。
I don't like having to navigate London's crowded streets.我不愿意在伦敦拥挤的街道上穿行。

nefarious

[nɪ'feəriəs], [nɪ'feriəs]


Image Search
adj. 违法的；邪恶的
(typically of an action or activity) wicked or criminal.
"the nefarious activities of the organized-crime syndicates"
He guarded his nefarious doings from view.他不让自己的罪恶行径给人看到。
He was universally feared because of his many nefarious deeds.因为他干了许多罪恶的勾当, 所以人人都惧怕他。
The EU reckons that Intel's use of such rebates was nefarious.欧盟认为，英特尔利用返点促销用意恶毒。

negate

[nɪ'ɡeɪt], [nɪ'ɡeɪt]


Image Search
vt. 否定；否认；使无效
nullify; make ineffective.
make (a clause, sentence, or proposition) negative in meaning.
deny the existence of (something).
"alcohol negates the effects of the drug"
"negating the political nature of education"
How can you negate God?你怎么能否定上帝的存在?
These facts negate your theory.这些事实否定了你的理论。
This power is always conceived in relation to men; it is not the power to do but the power to attract. It is a power that negates itself. (cf. Beauty, Susan Sontag)这种力量也常常被认为和男性有关；这不是一种行动力而是一种吸引力。这是一种否定自身的力量。
The story negated the trade supported by the government.该项报道否认了此项贸易受到政府的支持。
Efforts to expand the tourist industry could be negated by reports that the sea is highly polluted.这片海被严重污染的报道使扩大旅游业的努力化为乌有。

negative

['neɡətɪv], ['neɡətɪv]


Image Search
adj. 否定的；消极的；负面的；负的
n. 否定；反面意见；底片；[数]负数
vt. 否定
consisting in or characterized by the absence rather than the presence of distinguishing features.
(of a statement or decision) expressing or implying denial, disagreement, or refusal.
(of the results of a test or experiment) indicating that a certain substance or condition is not present or does not exist.
(of a person) not having a specified condition or showing traces of a specified substance in their body.
denoting a complete lack of something.
(of a word, clause, or proposition) expressing denial, negation, or refutation; stating or asserting that something is not the case.
(of a person, attitude, or situation) not desirable or optimistic.
(of a quantity) less than zero; to be subtracted from others or from zero.
denoting a direction of decrease or reversal.
of, containing, producing, or denoting the kind of electric charge carried by electrons.
(of a photographic image) showing light and shade or colors reversed from those of the original.
relating to or denoting any of the earth or water signs, considered passive in nature.
a word or statement that expresses denial, disagreement, or refusal.
a bad, unwelcome, or unpleasant quality, characteristic, or aspect of a situation or person.
a word, affix, or phrase expressing negation.
another term for negation.
a photographic image made on film or specially prepared glass that shows the light and shade or color values reversed from the original, and from which positive prints can be made.
a result of a test or experiment indicating that a certain substance is not present or a certain condition does not exist.
the part of an electric circuit that is at a lower electrical potential than another part designated as having zero electrical potential.
a number less than zero.
no (usually used in a military context).
reject; refuse to accept; veto.
disprove; contradict.
render ineffective; neutralize.
"that, I take it, was a negative answer"
"a negative test result"
"so far all the patients have tested negative for TB"
"they were described as having negative vulnerability to water entry"
"the new tax was having a very negative effect on car sales"
"the industry suffered negative growth in 1992"
"she replied in the negative"
"confidence will not be instilled by harping solely on the negative"
"the percentage of false negatives generated by a cancer test was of great concern"
"“Any snags, Captain?” “Negative, she's running like clockwork.”"
"the bill was negatived by 130 votes to 129"
"the insurer's main arguments were negatived by Lawrence"
"should criminal law allow consent to negative what would otherwise be a crime?"
Now I am afraid of getting a negative response.现在真害怕收到否定的答复。
You can't learn anything with negative attitude.你用消极的态度什么也学不到。
He conducted a negative campaign against his opponent.他对他的对手进行了负面打击。
This negative pressure phase is of short duration.负压周期的延续时间很短。
The answer to my request was in the negative.对我的请求的答复是否定的。
The negative won the debate.持反对意见的一方在辩论中获胜。
I need five enlargements from this negative.我要把这张底片放大5张。
Many students find it difficult to deal with negatives in maths than positives很多学生觉得在数学中负数要比正数难处理。
The government negatived our request for financing.政府否决了我们融资的请求。

neglect

[nɪ'ɡlekt], [nɪ'ɡlekt]


Image Search
vt. 忽略；忽视；疏忽
n. 疏忽；忽视
fail to care for properly.
not pay proper attention to; disregard.
fail to do something.
the state or fact of being uncared for.
the action of not taking proper care of someone or something.
failure to do something.
"the old churchyard has been sadly neglected"
"you neglect our advice at your peril"
"he neglected to write to her"
"animals dying through disease or neglect"
"she was accused of child neglect"
"he was reported for neglect of duty"
You shouldn't neglect your health.你不该忽略你的健康。
No country can afford to neglect education.任何国家都不容忽视教育。
He neglected to write and say "Thank you".他忘了写信道谢。
She was severely criticized for neglect of duty.她因玩忽职守而受到严厉批评。
We cannot leave aside his neglect of duty.对他的玩忽职守我们不能听之任之。
The house has fallen into a state of neglect.这所房屋已处于荒废的状态。

nemesis

['neməsɪs], ['neməsɪs]


Image Search
n. 不可避免的报应
Nemesis.
n. [希神]复仇女神
the inescapable agent of someone's or something's downfall.
a long-standing rival; an archenemy.
a downfall caused by an inescapable agent.
retributive justice.
"the balance beam was the team's nemesis, as two gymnasts fell from the apparatus"
"will Harry Potter finally defeat his nemesis, Voldemort?"
"one risks nemesis by uttering such words"
"nemesis is notoriously slow"
To follow the proposed course of action is to invite nemesis.按照别人建议的行动步骤而行动就是自找报应。
You can't do as you want relying on power, or you may invite a nemesis.你们不能怙恃权势就为所欲为，小心遭报应。

nestle

['nesl], ['nesl]


Image Search
v. 依偎；（舒适地）安顿
settle or lie comfortably within or against something.
(of a place) lie or be situated in a half-hidden or obscured position.
"the baby deer nestled in her arms"
"picturesque villages nestle in the wooded hills"
She nestled her head on his shoulder.她将头依偎在他的肩上。
The village nestled at the foot of the hill.那村庄位于山脚下。
The child nestled up to its mother and fell asleep.孩子倚著母亲舒服地睡了。
The dog nestled up against the warm radiator.狗倚著暖烘烘的散热器。
I nestled down on the big sofa and began to read novels.我舒适地靠在大沙发上，开始看小说。

neutral

['njuːtrəl], ['nuːtrəl]


Image Search
adj. 中立的；中性的；空档的；素净色的
n. 中立者；空挡位置
not helping or supporting either side in a conflict, disagreement, etc.; impartial.
belonging to an impartial party, country, or group.
having no strongly marked or positive characteristics or features.
neither acid nor alkaline; having a pH of about 7.
electrically neither positive nor negative.
an impartial or unbiased country or person.
a neutral color or shade, especially light gray or beige.
a disengaged position of gears in which the engine is disconnected from the driven parts.
an electrically neutral point, terminal, conductor, or wire.
"during the Second World War, Portugal was neutral"
"on neutral ground"
"the tone was neutral, devoid of sentiment"
"he acted as a neutral between the parties"
"she slipped the gear into neutral"
That country remained neutral in the war.那个国家在那场战争中保持中立。
He has a rather neutral character.他品性平平。
When you start the engine, be sure the car is in neutral.你在发动引擎时，一定要让汽车处于空档。
A neutral tie can be worn with a shirt of any colour.暗灰色的领带配什麽颜色的衬衣都行。
For Britain, Switzerland was a useful and friendly neutral.对英国来说,瑞士是一个有利和友好的中立国。
The car's in neutral.那汽车在空挡位置.

nevertheless

[ˌnevəðə'les], [ˌnevərðə'les]


Image Search
adv. 尽管如此；不过；仍然
conj. 然而；不过
in spite of that; notwithstanding; all the same.
"statements which, although literally true, are nevertheless misleading"
Our defeat was expected；nevertheless，it was disappointing.我们的失败是意料中的事；尽管如此,还是令人失望。
We can't take your advice. Nevertheless, thank you for putting it.我们不能接受您的建议。不过,谢谢您提出来。
Despite his injured ankle, he nevertheless succeeded in gaining the final against Germany.尽管踝骨受伤,他仍然打入了与德国队的决赛。
Nevertheless as an exceptional measure, we have decided to overlook its late submission.然而,作为一项特别措施,我们决定不计较逾期问题。
We are going nevertheless we shall return.我们要走了, 不过我们还要回来。

niche

[niːʃ], [niːʃ]


Image Search
n. 壁龛；适当的位置；（特定产品或服务的）用户群；[生]生态龛；生态位；小生态环境
vt. 放在适当的位置
a shallow recess, especially one in a wall to display a statue or other ornament.
a comfortable or suitable position in life or employment.
a position or role taken by a kind of organism within its community. Such a position may be occupied by different organisms in different localities, e.g., antelopes in Africa and kangaroos in Australia.
a specialized segment of the market for a particular kind of product or service.
denoting or relating to products, services, or interests that appeal to a small, specialized section of the population.
place or position (something) in a niche.
"he is now a partner at a leading law firm and feels he has found his niche"
"he believes he has found a niche in the market"
"other companies in this space had to adapt to being niche players"
This is a stupa niche from the Sui Dynasty.你看这是隋代的塔龛。
He found the right niche for himself.他发现了一个适合他的职位。
He eventually found his niche in sports journalism.最后他在体育新闻界找到了理想的工作。
Your market niche is big women.你们的服装目标是体胖的女士。

nimble

['nɪmbl], ['nɪmbl]


Image Search
adj. 敏捷的；伶俐的；机敏的
quick and light in movement or action; agile.
(of the mind) quick to comprehend.
"with a deft motion of her nimble fingers"
"she is well-read and intellectually nimble"
He is a nimble climber.他是个敏捷的登山者。
She knitted a pair of mittens for me with her nimble fingers.她用灵巧的双手为我织了一副手套。
The nurse sewed up the wound with nimble fingers.护士用灵巧的手指缝好了伤口。
Habits will make us have two nimble hands and a clumsy brain.习惯会使我们的双手伶俐而头脑笨拙。
He is a nimble and versatile wit.他是一个机敏而又多才多艺的才子。

noncommittal

[ˌnɒnkə'mɪtl], [ˌnɒnkə'mɪtəl]


Image Search
adj. 态度暧昧的；含糊的
(of a person or a person's behavior or manner) not expressing or revealing commitment to a definite opinion or course of action.
"her tone was noncommittal, and her face gave nothing away"
I asked him if he approved of our plan,but he was noncommittal.我问他是否赞同我们的计划，但他态度不明朗。
Harry gave a noncommittal grunt.哈利含糊地咕噜了一句。

nonconformist

[ˌnɒnkən'fɔːmɪst], [ˌnɑːnkən'fɔːrmɪst]


Image Search
adj. 不墨守成规的
n. 不墨守成规的人
Nonconformist.
adj. 不信奉英国国教的
n. 不信奉英国国教的人
a person whose behavior or views do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
a member of a Protestant church in England that dissents from the established Anglican Church.
of or characterized by behavior or views that do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
relating to Nonconformists or their principles and practices.
An eccentric or nonconformist person, especially a member of a counterculture.离经叛道之人反常或不符合常规之人，尤指反主流文化的成员
A Nonconformist chapel, especially a Baptist or Methodist one.非英国国教的礼拜堂基督新教徒的教堂，尤指浸信会或卫理公会教徒
Angel Clare had sadly disappointed his father, first by nonconformist views and then by sincere scruples against taking orders.安吉尔·克莱使他的父亲十分失望，先是他不信奉国教的观点，后来又顾虑重重，不愿意当牧师。

nostalgic

[nɒ'stældʒɪk], [nɒ'stældʒɪk]


Image Search
adj. 怀旧的；乡愁的
characterized by or exhibiting feelings of nostalgia.
a nostalgic person.
"to see classmates' email addresses, nostalgics pay $36 a year"
The nostalgic atmosphere becomes less apparent.怀旧的气氛变淡了。
Dixon gave a sad, nostalgic smile.狄克逊脸上露出一丝怀旧的苦笑。
They are not nostalgic thoughts, not national allegories, but rich imaginaries about personal life demand and inner feeling.她的小说不是乡愁的言说，也不关乎国族寓言，而是有关个体生命诉求与情感旨归的多维想象。

notably

['nəʊtəbli], ['noʊtəbli]


Image Search
adv. 显著地；值得注意地；特别地
especially; in particular.
in a way that is striking or remarkable.
"a diet low in animal fat protects against potentially fatal diseases, notably diabetes"
"such a statement is notably absent from the administration's proposals"
British writer known for his essays and children's books, notably The Wind in the Willows(1908).格雷厄姆，肯尼思1859－1932英国作家，以其散文和儿童文学著名，著名的有杨柳风(1908年)
Many students were absent, notably the monitor.许多学生缺席，特别是连班长也没来。

notify

['nəʊtɪfaɪ], ['noʊtɪfaɪ]


Image Search
v. 通知；报告；通告
inform (someone) of something, typically in a formal or official manner.
give notice of or report (something) formally or officially.
"you will be notified of our decision as soon as possible"
"if he does not notify the occurrences, he may be guilty of nondisclosure"
Please notify us of any change of address.地址如有变动，请通知我们。
She notified us of the meeting.她通知我们开会。
We'll notify her to draw up a contract.我们将通知她起草一份合同。
They will notify her when to appear in court.他们将通知她何时出庭。
The nurse must notify the doctor if the patient shows unusual symptoms.护士需向医生报告异常情况。
Banks are also obligated to notify the Internal Revenue Service of certain questionable transactions.第三种信息来源来自银行有义务提交有关方面存在问题的报告给地方税务机关。
We will notify participants when the beta test is nearing completion.当测试接近尾声，我们会通告参与测试者。

notorious

[nəʊ'tɔːriəs], [noʊ'tɔːriəs]


Image Search
adj. 臭名昭著的
famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
"Los Angeles is notorious for its smog"
He is notorious for his goings-on.他因行为不检点而声名狼藉。
The district is notorious for its fogs.那地区以浓雾出名。
Hitler is a notorious dictator.希特勒是一个臭名昭著的独裁者。
The notorious thief will be put up for trial next week.那个臭名昭著的偷窃犯将于下周出庭受审。
They made the place a notorious centre of piracy.他们把这地方变成了臭名昭著的海盗中心。

novel

['nɒvl], ['nɑːvl]


Image Search
n. 小说
adj. 新奇的
a fictitious prose narrative of book length, typically representing character and action with some degree of realism.
the literary genre represented or exemplified by novels.
new or unusual in an interesting way.
"the novels of Jane Austen"
"the novel is the most adaptable of all literary forms"
"he hit on a novel idea to solve his financial problems"
The novel is considered a brilliant performance.这部小说被认为是出色的佳作。
I like reading novels in my spare time.我喜欢闲暇时读小说。
This film is based on a novel by D.H.Lawrence.这部影片是根据D.
It's a novel idea.那是个异常的想法。
It's a novel experience.那是一段新奇的经历。

novice

['nɒvɪs], ['nɑːvɪs]


Image Search
n. 新手；新信徒
a person new to or inexperienced in a field or situation.
a person who has entered a religious order and is under probation, before taking vows.
an animal, especially a racehorse, that has not yet won a major prize or reached a level of performance to qualify for important events.
"he was a complete novice in foreign affairs"
He is a novice at swimming.他是一个游泳新手。
I'm a complete novice at skiing.滑雪我完全是个新手。
The novice's expectation is inherently unrealistic and uninformed.新手的期望大多是不现实和零散的。

noxious

['nɒkʃəs], ['nɑːkʃəs]


Image Search
adj. <正式>有害的；有毒的
harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant.
"they were overcome by the noxious fumes"
Noxious gases had built up in the sewer.下水道 的有害气体越积越多。
Noxious chemicals are found in the river water.河水里发现了有毒化学物品。
We must trace the source of these noxious gases.我们必须查出毒气的来源。

null

[nʌl], [nʌl]


Image Search
adj. 无效的；无价值的；无效力的
n. 零；空
vt. 使无效
having no legal or binding force; invalid.
having or associated with the value zero.
(of a set or matrix) having no elements, or only zeros as elements.
lacking distinctive qualities; having no positive substance or content.
a zero.
a dummy letter in a cipher.
a condition of no signal.
a direction in which no electromagnetic radiation is detected or emitted.
combine (a signal) with another in order to create a null; cancel out.
"the establishment of a new interim government was declared null and void"
"his curiously null life"
Their actions rendered the contract null and void.他们的行为使合同无效。
The marriage was declared null and void.婚姻已宣告无效了。
The path must end with a null character.该路经必须以零结尾。
Vomit in null gravity wouldn't be fun.如果在零重力下呕吐了可不是件好笑的事。
A null reference pointer was passed to the stub.向占位程序传送了空的索引指针。
Primary keys do not allow null values.主键不允许空值。

numb

[nʌm], [nʌm]


Image Search
adj. 麻木的；失去知觉的
vt. 使麻木；使失去知觉
deprived of the power of sensation.
unable to think, feel, or respond normally.
deprive of feeling or responsiveness.
cause (a sensation) to be felt less intensely; deaden.
"my feet were numb with cold"
"the tragic events left us shocked and numb"
"the cold had numbed her senses"
"vodka might numb the pain in my hand"
My fingers were so numb that I could hardly write.我的手指都麻木了几乎不能写字。
I've just been to the dentist and my face is still numb.我刚刚去看了牙医，脸上现在还没知觉呢。
The anaesthetic made his whole face go numb.麻醉药使他的整张脸失去了知觉。
His leg was numbed by the intense pain.他的腿因剧痛而麻木。
She was completely numbed by the shock of her father's death.她父亲去世造成的打击使她目瞪神呆.

oaf

[əʊf], [oʊf]


Image Search
n. 蠢人；笨拙的人
a stupid, uncultured, or clumsy person.
The oaf stumbled over the bucket, spilling all the water.那个笨手笨脚的人绊到了木桶，把水全给泼了。
You clumsy oaf that's the second glass you've broken today!你这个笨家伙--这是你今天打碎的第二个玻璃杯！

obscure

[əb'skjʊə(r)], [əb'skjʊr]


Image Search
adj. 难解的；不著名的；微暗的；[语音学]轻音的
v. 使 ... 模糊；隐藏；变模糊
n. 模糊不清的东西
not discovered or known about; uncertain.
not clearly expressed or easily understood.
not important or well known.
hard to make out or define; vague.
(of a color) not sharply defined; dim or dingy.
keep from being seen; conceal.
make unclear and difficult to understand.
overshadow.
"his origins and parentage are obscure"
"obscure references to Proust"
"an obscure religious sect"
"I feel an obscure resentment"
"gray clouds obscure the sun"
"the debate has become obscured by conflicting ideological perspectives"
"none of this should obscure the skill, experience, and perseverance of the workers"
The rules for the competition are somewhat obscure.比赛的规则有点让人费解。
The reasons why he did it are obscure.他做那事的理由还不清楚。
The report had been published in an obscure German journal.这个报道刊登在德国一家不著名的报纸上。
He set the bed in an obscure corner.他把床放在一个昏暗的角落。
The moon was obscured by clouds.月亮被云遮住了。
Recent successes have obscured the fact that the company is still in trouble.近来的成功掩盖了公司仍旧处于困境中的事实。
This language serves to disguise and obscure.这种话是用来文过饰非的。
Hence things whichhave perplexed you and made the case more obscure have served to enlighten meand to strengthen my conclusions.因此，那些使你们大惑不解并且使案情更加模糊不清的事物，却会对我有所启发，并且能加强我的论断。

obsolete

['ɒbsəliːt], [ˌɑːbsə'liːt]


Image Search
adj. 已废弃的；过时的
no longer produced or used; out of date.
(of a part or characteristic of an organism) less developed than formerly or in a related species; rudimentary; vestigial.
cause (a product or idea) to be or become obsolete by replacing it with something new.
"the disposal of old and obsolete machinery"
"we're trying to stimulate the business by obsoleting last year's designs"
The army plans to phase out the equipment as it becomes obsolete.军队计划淘汰这些设备，因为它们已经报废了。
This usage of the word is obsolete.这个词的此类用法已经废弃了。
The obsolete regime is about to collapse.那过时的政权即将崩溃。
You always depend on an obsolete viewpoint.你老是信赖一个过时的观点。

obstacle

['ɒbstəkl], ['ɑːbstəkl]


Image Search
n. 障碍；绊脚石
a thing that blocks one's way or prevents or hinders progress.
"the major obstacle to achieving that goal is money"
Lack of education is an obstacle of success.缺乏教育是成功的障碍。
This is the chief obstacle to world peace.这是世界和平的主要障碍。
He took every obstacle in his stride.他轻易地度过一切难关。
Overstaffing has become the obstacle for reforms.人浮于事已成为改革的绊脚石。
Can you smooth away the obstacle on the road?你可以清除路上的障碍物吗?

obstinate

['ɒbstɪnət], ['ɑːbstɪnət]


Image Search
adj. 固执的；倔强的；不易屈服的；（病）难治的
stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action, despite attempts to persuade one to do so.
(of an unwelcome phenomenon or situation) very difficult to change or overcome.
"the obstinate problem of unemployment"
The obstinate child refused to answer.这固执的孩子拒绝回答。
Because their hearts had turned hard, stubborn and obstinate.重点是在于他们的心已经是硬的，是固执的，是顽固的。
He examined my obstinate expression, and switched to another line of attack.他打量着一脸倔强的我，又转移战地。
Only a man full of the milk of human kindness could have continued to befriend the proud and obstinate young man.只有天性善良的人才会和这个性情高傲脾气倔强的年轻人继续交往。

obstruct

[əb'strʌkt], [əb'strʌkt]


Image Search
v. 阻隔；妨碍；阻塞
block (an opening, path, road, etc.); be or get in the way of.
prevent or hinder (movement or someone or something in motion).
deliberately make (something) difficult.
commit the offense of intentionally hindering (a legal process).
(in various sports) impede (a player on the opposing team) in a manner that constitutes an offense.
"she was obstructing the entrance"
"they had to alter the course of the stream and obstruct the natural flow of the water"
"fears that the regime would obstruct the distribution of food"
They do not obstruct most individuals who use patented products.他们不会妨碍个人使用专利产品。
Five colors bewilder our eyes and obstruct our insights.五种变化多端的颜色，迷惑我们的眼睛，妨碍我们的洞察力。
Such masses may also focally obstruct the biliary tract and lead to an elevated alkaline phosphatase.肿物也可阻塞胆管，导致碱性磷酸酶升高。
But wherever Zhao went he would cause traffic jams and obstruct pavements as stunned crowds gathered to gawp.但赵良所到之处，都会因惊讶的人们围观而造成塞车和道路阻塞。

obtuse

[əb'tjuːs], [əb'tuːs]


Image Search
adj. 钝的；不尖的；钝角的；愚钝的
annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand.
difficult to understand.
(of an angle) more than 90° and less than 180°.
not sharp-pointed or sharp-edged; blunt.
"he wondered if the doctor was being deliberately obtuse"
"some of the lyrics are a bit obtuse"
"Sometimes it looks more like an obtuse triangle," Winter said.“有时候它看起来更像一个钝角三角形。”温特说。
You were too obtuse to take the hint.你太迟钝了，没有理解这种暗示。
The obtuse editor did not know he was being nibbled at.这位脑筋迟钝的编辑并不知道人家是在向他试探消息。

occupy

['ɒkjupaɪ], ['ɑːkjupaɪ]


Image Search
vt. 占用；占领；从事；使忙碌；专心
reside or have one's place of business in (a building).
fill or take up (a space or time).
be situated in or at (a place or position in a system or hierarchy).
hold (a position or job).
fill or preoccupy (the mind or thoughts).
keep (someone) busy and active.
take control of (a place, especially a country) by military conquest or settlement.
enter, take control of, and stay in (a building) illegally and often forcibly, especially as a form of protest.
"the apartment she occupies in Manhattan"
"two long windows occupied almost the whole wall"
"on the corporate ladder, they occupy the lowest rungs"
"her mind was occupied with alarming questions"
"Sarah occupied herself taking the coffee cups over to the sink"
"the region was occupied by Britain during World War I"
"the workers occupied the factory"
Is that seat occupied?那个座位有人吗？
Reading occupies most of my free time.阅读占去了我大部分的闲暇时间。
We occupy the farm and raise a lot of poultry.我们拥有这个农场并养着许多家禽。
The enemy occupied the town.敌人占据了这个城镇。
Our army won the battle and occupied the upland.我军在战斗中取得胜利并成功地占领了那片小高地。
These people occupy an inferior position in local society.这些人在当地社会居于下等地位。
Members of the group occupy positions of power in the country.那个组织的成员在该国从事着位高权重的工作。
Her time is fully occupied with her three children.她的时间全部用在她的三个孩子身上了。
She is now fully occupied with her homework.她现在在专心致志地做家庭作业。

oeuvre

['ɜːvrə], ['ɜːvrə]


Image Search
n. 全部作品
the works of a painter, composer, or author regarded collectively.
a work of art, music, or literature.
"the complete oeuvre of Mozart"
"an early oeuvre"
He studied the entire Wagnerian oeuvre他研究了瓦格纳的全部作品。
But no one else has duplicated his own oeuvre so perfectly.但却没有谁如此完美地复制过他自己的作品。
Therefore, this poem may be read as a cornerstone at the foundation of her oeuvre.因而，这首诗可说是她所有作品的一块基石。

okra

['əʊkrə], ['oʊkrə]


Image Search
n. 秋葵；秋葵荚
a plant of the mallow family with long ridged seedpods, native to the Old World tropics.
the immature seedpods of the okra plant eaten as a vegetable and also used to thicken soups and stews.
Experts say good choices for the garden include tomatoes, peppers, beans and okra.专家们建议在菜园中种植西红柿、胡椒、黄豆和秋葵。

ominous

['ɒmɪnəs], ['ɑːmɪnəs]


Image Search
adj. 不祥的；预兆的
giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; threatening; inauspicious.
"there were ominous dark clouds gathering overhead"
That evening has an ominous silence.那晚有着不祥的寂静。
She often has an ominous presentiment.她时时有一种不祥的预感。
There were ominous dark clouds gathering overhead.不祥的阴霾在头顶上汇聚。
He had a fall, which was ominous of his downfall.他曾跌倒，这是他垮台的征兆。

omit

[ə'mɪt], [ə'mɪt]


Image Search
vt. 省略；遗漏；忘记；删去
leave out or exclude (someone or something), either intentionally or forgetfully.
fail or neglect to do (something); leave undone.
"a significant detail was omitted from your story"
"the final rinse is omitted"
In writing telegrams omit superfluous words.写电报稿要省去不必要的文字。
I could omit the overseas section at this point.我可以暂时把海外部分省略掉。
Don't omit his name from the list.名单上不要遗漏了他的名字。
Don't omit locking the door.别忘了锁门。
You can omit the last two sentences of the passage.你可以把这篇文章的最后两句话删去。

onerous

['əʊnərəs], ['ɑːnərəs]


Image Search
adj. 繁重的
(of a task, duty, or responsibility) involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
involving heavy obligations.
"he found his duties increasingly onerous"
"an onerous lease"
Overtime work is often onerous, though it is well paid.报酬很好，但常常是很繁重的。
She desired a fixed occupation-no matter how onerous, how irksome.她希望有个固定的职业，不管这个职业多么繁重，多么令人厌倦。
I've always led an onerous timetable but I like it.我的日程表总是排得紧紧的，但我喜欢这样。

onset

['ɒnset], ['ɑːnset]


Image Search
n. 攻击；进攻；开始
the beginning of something, especially something unpleasant.
a military attack.
"the onset of winter"
The fierce onset of the enemy broke the ranks of the army.敌人的猛烈攻击致使全军大乱。
Our troops withstood the onset of the enemy.我们的部队抵挡住了敌人的进攻。
The onset of the enemy took us by surprise.敌人的进攻出乎我们意外。
He went to see a doctor at the onset of a fever.他开始发烧时便去看医生了。
The drug must be taken from the onset of the infection.这种药必须在感染的最初期就开始服用。

opaque

[əʊ'peɪk], [oʊ'peɪk]


Image Search
adj. 不透明的；难懂的
not able to be seen through; not transparent.
(especially of language) hard or impossible to understand; unfathomable.
an opaque thing or substance.
a substance for producing opaque areas on negatives.
"the windows were opaque with steam"
"technical jargon that was opaque to her"
This is an opaque cup.这是一个不透明的杯子。
The window is made of opaque glass.这扇窗是用不透明的玻璃做的。
The report was written in long, opaque sentences.报告中的句子又长又难懂。
Their intentions remained opaque.他们的意图仍然令人费解。

optimistic

[ˌɒptɪ'mɪstɪk], [ˌɑːptɪ'mɪstɪk]


Image Search
adj. 乐观的；乐观主义的
hopeful and confident about the future.
involving an overestimate.
"the optimistic mood of the sixties"
"previous estimates may be wildly optimistic"
The book ended on an optimistic note.该书的结尾寓意乐观。
The stockholders are optimistic about the company's future.股东对公司的前景很乐观。
We are still optimistic, whatever the result (may be).我们仍然乐观，不论结果如何。
I was exhausted and relieved, but I wasn't wildly optimistic.我已感到精疲力尽,同时也感到如释重负,然而,我并不抱盲目乐观的态度。

optional

['ɒpʃənl], ['ɑːpʃənl]


Image Search
adj. 任选的
available to be chosen but not obligatory.
"a wide range of optional excursions is offered"
The insurance cover is optional.保险范围可以随意选择。
It is optional with you.那是你的自由。
The goods are optional, but only one.这些物品是可以任选的, 但只能选一个。
A 4-speed automatic transmission is optional.四段自动变速器是可自由选择的。

opulent

['ɒpjələnt], ['ɑːpjələnt]


Image Search
adj. 富裕的；充足的
ostentatiously rich and luxurious or lavish.
wealthy.
"the opulent comfort of a limousine"
"his more opulent tenants"
An opulent priest is a contradiction.教士养尊处优，就是离经叛道。
David was easy, and even opulent in his circumstances.戴维的家境不差，甚至相当富裕。
The opulent clothing is decorated with jewelry over her body.她衣着华丽
She is depicted in a room within an opulent palace.她被描绘成住在一座豪华宫殿的房间中。

oracle

['ɒrəkl], ['ɔːrəkl]


Image Search
n. 神谕；神谕处；传达神谕的人；能提供可靠意见的人
a priest or priestess acting as a medium through whom advice or prophecy was sought from the gods in classical antiquity.
a place at which divine advice or prophecy was sought.
a person or thing regarded as an infallible authority or guide on something.
a response or message given by an oracle, typically one that is ambiguous or obscure.
"casting the attorney general as the oracle for and guardian of the public interest is simply impossible"
In times of difficulty, she prayed for an oracle to guide her.在困难的时候,她祈祷神谕来指引她。
The earth is the great parent of all, the stones are her bones; these we may cast behind us; this, I think, the oracle means.大地是万物之母，石头就是她的尸骨。我们可以往身后扔石头，我想神谕说的就是这个意思。
This oracle was still flourishing in 332 B.C.这个神示殿在公元前332年依然很兴旺。
They consulted the oracle at Delphi.他们在德尔斐神示所向神请示。
The message was passed by an oracle.这个信息是由传神谕者传递的。
My sister's the oracle on beauty matters.我妹妹是美容方面的大行家。

ostentatious

[ˌɒsten'teɪʃəs], [ˌɑːsten'teɪʃəs]


Image Search
adj. 炫耀的；浮夸的；浮华的；豪华的
characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
"books that people buy and display ostentatiously but never actually finish"
Their daughter was ostentatious on her wedding reception.他们的女儿在办婚事时摆阔。
Owning a sewing machine was a ostentatious display.那时候拥有缝纫机简直是可以炫耀的资本。
Those states, ostentatious and extravagant design will soon be cold-shouldered by the market.那些铺张、摆阔的设计一定会很快受到市场的冷落。
The singers carry the musical instrument to go out the ostentatious bar street wearily , returns to nearby own den to drink eats meal .歌手们背着乐器疲倦地走出浮华的酒吧街，回到自己的老巢边喝酒吃饭。
Their wedding was a most ostentatious and extravagant affair.他们的婚礼办得可排场了。
It is not , however , the most ostentatious house on the reservation.尽管如此，这并非是当地最豪华的公寓。

outright

['aʊtraɪt], ['aʊtraɪt]


Image Search
adj. 直率的；完全的；彻底的
adv. 率直地；立刻地；彻底地
altogether; completely.
without reservation; openly.
immediately.
not by degrees or installments.
open and direct; not concealed.
total; complete.
undisputed; clear.
"logging has been banned outright"
"she couldn't ask him outright"
"the impact killed four horses outright"
"they decided to buy the company outright"
"an outright refusal"
"the outright abolition of the death penalty"
"an outright victory"
Dissatisfaction often leads to outright treason.政治上的不满常常导致断然的背叛。
The statement was an outright lie.这话是十足的谎言。
They can now establish outright dictatorship.他们现在可以建立起彻头彻尾的独裁制度了。
I told him outright what I thought of him.我坦率地向他说出我对他的想法。
If you have a complaint you should tell me outright .如果你有不满意的事你应该直率地对我说。
Most of the crash victims were killed outright.飞机坠毁的遇难者大都是立即惨死。
She own outright.她大获全胜。

ovation

[əʊ'veɪʃn], [oʊ'veɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 热烈欢迎；热烈的鼓掌
a sustained and enthusiastic show of appreciation from an audience, especially by means of applause.
a processional entrance into Rome by a victorious commander, of lesser honor than a triumph.
"the performance received a thundering ovation"
The hero received a great ovation from the crowd.那位英雄受到人群的热烈欢迎。
He gets a standing ovation as he moves off stage.他离开舞台时，全体观众起立热烈鼓掌。

overarching

[ˌəʊvər'ɑːtʃɪŋ], [ˌoʊvər'ɑːrtʃɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 在头顶上方成拱形的；支配一切的；包罗万象的；首要的

forming an arch over something.
comprehensive; all-embracing.
form an arch over.
"the overarching mangroves"
"a single overarching principle"
"an old dirt road, overarched by forest"

overbearing

[ˌəʊvə'beərɪŋ], [ˌəʊvə'beərɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 傲慢的；骄傲自大的；蛮横的
unpleasantly or arrogantly domineering.
overcome by emotional pressure or physical force.
"his overbearing, sometimes ruthless desire to succeed"
"his will had not been overborne by another's influence"
No one liked his overbearing manners.没有人喜欢他那傲慢的样子。
His overbearing insolence angered everyone.他的傲慢无礼激起了大家的愤怒。
The aging actress was very high-strung and overbearing.这位上了年纪的女演员非常紧张,而且骄傲自大。
He's so overbearing that no one wants to work for him.他那么蛮横,没人愿为他工作。
Everybody was indignant at such an overbearing manner.对于这种蛮横态度，大家无不感到气愤。

overrated

[ˌəʊvə'reɪt], [ˌoʊvər'reɪt]


Image Search
vt. 评价过高；高估；估价过高
have a higher opinion of (someone or something) than is deserved.
"dismissing the work as pompous and overrated"
However, we should not overrate the role of the proposed law.尽管如此，我们也不能对草案可以发挥的作用评价过高。

overt

[əʊ'vɜːt], [oʊ'vɜːrt]


Image Search
adj. 公开的；明显的；公然的
done or shown openly; plainly or readily apparent, not secret or hidden.
"an overt act of aggression"
In many emerging economies corruption is egregious and overt.许多新兴经济体中的腐败是异乎寻常的和公开的。
Supreme People's Court promulgated the regulations on overt enforcement.最高人民法院颁布执行公开的规定。
It was full of overt propaganda and the props were primitive.节目充满了明显的宣传，一点也不精致，道具都是简单。
Spotting them can be tricky, since many animals display few overt symptoms.确诊蓝舌病本身已经很难，因为很多染病动物并无明显的临床症状。
Overt expression of hostility is considered evidence of marital problems.公然的敌意表现被认为是预示婚姻问题的前兆。

overture

['əʊvətʃʊə(r)], ['oʊvərtʃər]


Image Search
n. 提议；提案；主动表示；序曲
v. 提议；建议
an orchestral piece at the beginning of an opera, suite, play, oratorio, or other extended composition.
an independent orchestral composition in one movement.
an introduction to something more substantial.
an approach or proposal made to someone with the aim of opening negotiations or establishing a relationship.
"the talks were no more than an overture to a long debate"
"Coleen listened to his overtures of love"
And, knowing little about Geely, it didn't take the overture seriously, according to people familiar with the situation.据知情人士透露，由于对吉利知之甚少，福特汽车没有认真对待这一提议。
He resolved, therefore, to let things take their course without making any direct overture to the count.所以他决定让事情顺其自然发展，而不向伯爵作任何正面的提议。
Many spokesmen attacked consumingly this overture.大会上许多的发言人强烈抨击了这项提案。
Three-fours of the people agree with the overture presently.目前有四分之三的人赞成该提案。
They played the overture at a fairly slow tempo.他们用相当缓慢的速度演奏那首序曲。
This tool works differently from the Overture tool.这个工具厂不同序曲工具。
And, knowing little about Geely, it didn't take the overture seriously, according to people familiar with the situation.据知情人士透露，由于对吉利知之甚少，福特汽车没有认真对待这一提议。
He resolved, therefore, to let things take their course without making any direct overture to the count.所以他决定让事情顺其自然发展，而不向伯爵作任何正面的提议。

overwhelmed

[ˌəʊvə'welm], [ˌoʊvər'welm]


Image Search
vt. 打击；压倒；使感动；淹没；打败
bury or drown beneath a huge mass.
defeat completely.
give too much of a thing to (someone); inundate.
have a strong emotional effect on.
be too strong for; overpower.
"the water flowed through to overwhelm the whole dam and the village beneath"
"his teams overwhelmed their opponents"
"they were overwhelmed by farewell messages"
"I was overwhelmed with guilt"
"the wine doesn't overwhelm the flavor of the trout"
No difficulty can overwhelm us.困难压不倒我们。
If I cannot overwhelm with my quality, I will overwhelm with my quantity.如果我不能以质量压倒，我就一定要以数量压倒。
Your kindness quite overwhelmed me.你的好意使我感激难言。
The village was overwhelmed when the floods came.这个村庄在洪水泛滥时被淹没了。
Europe's golfers completely overwhelmed the Americans.欧洲的高尔夫运动员以压倒性的优势击败了美国对手。

pacifist

['pæsɪfɪst], ['pæsɪfɪst]


Image Search
adj. 非战主义的
n. 和平主义者；反战；反对武力
a person who believes that war and violence are unjustifiable.
holding the belief that war and violence are unjustifiable.
"she was a committed pacifist all her life"
Pacifist movements gathered strength in Norway.在挪威,和平主义的运动力量逐渐增强。
Ultimately he wants to revise the pacifist constitution.他最终希望修改和平宪法。
I've never met such an ardent pacifist as Terry.我从未见过像特里这样热情的和平主义者。

pacify

['pæsɪfaɪ], ['pæsɪfaɪ]


Image Search
v. 使 ... 平静；抚慰；安慰
quell the anger, agitation, or excitement of.
bring peace to (a country or warring factions), especially by the use or threatened use of military force.
"he had to pacify angry spectators"
"the general pacified northern Italy"
She knew that he had become delirious, and tried to pacify him.她知道他已经神志昏迷起来了，极力想使他镇静下来。
He tried to pacify the protesters with promise of reform.他试图以改革的承诺安抚抗议者。
I bought an ice cream to pacify my crying daughter.我买了个冰淇淋来抚慰哭泣的女儿。

pact

[pækt], [pækt]


Image Search
n. 契约；协定；条约
a formal agreement between individuals or parties.
It was a pact made in fun long ago.这是很久以前在开玩笑时定下的契约。
Tell Me Why You and I must make a pact.你和我必须订立契约。
They made a pact not to tell anyone.他们有协定，不告诉任何人。
They ratify the pact because they think it will bring peace.他们批准了这项协定，因为他们认为它将能带来和平。
They signed a nonaggression pact.他们签定了互不侵犯条约。
We will put military muscle into the mutual defence pact.我们将把兵力加进防御互助条约。

palpable

['pælpəbl], ['pælpəbl]


Image Search
adj. 易觉察的；可摸到的；明显的
(of a feeling or atmosphere) so intense as to seem almost tangible.
plain to see or comprehend.
able to be touched or felt.
"a palpable sense of loss"
"to talk of dawn raids in the circumstances is palpable nonsense"
"the palpable bump at the bridge of the nose"
The tension in the room was almost palpable.屋子里的紧张气氛几乎能感觉到。
None of the vessels and nerves of the hand is visible or palpable.手的血管和神经不能看到或摸到。
There is a palpable difference in their ages.他们的年龄有着明显的差别。
A sense of urgency was palpable in Bali.紧迫意识在巴厘岛会议中十分明显。

paltry

['pɔːltri], ['pɔːltri]


Image Search
adj. 微不足道的；琐碎的；无价值的；可鄙的
(of an amount) small or meager.
petty; trivial.
"she would earn a paltry $33 more each month"
"naval glory struck him as paltry"
His influence on this matter is paltry.他对这件事的影响是微不足道的。
This is a paltry sum to pay for such a masterpiece.对这样一部杰作只付这么一点钱, 未免太少了。
It's paltry to do that job.做这件工作是毫无价值的。
How can you deliberately get up such paltry falsehoods?你怎么能故意编造出这么卑鄙的谎话?

panorama

[ˌpænə'rɑːmə], [ˌpænə'ræmə]


Image Search
n. 全景；全景画；概观；一连串景象或事物
an unbroken view of the whole region surrounding an observer.
a picture or photograph containing a wide view.
a complete survey or presentation of a subject or sequence of events.
"the tower offers a wonderful panorama of Prague"
"the galleries will offer a full panorama of 20th-century art"
promise graciously
As we stood at the top of the mountain, a beautiful panorama spread out before us.我们登上山顶时，一幅美丽的景色展现在我们的面前。
The book presents a panorama of British history since the Middle Ages.该书概述了中世纪以来的英国历史。
Henry watched the panorama of pass people with wide eyes.亨利观看着一连串过往的人群。

pantomime

['pæntəmaɪm], ['pæntəmaɪm]


Image Search
n. 哑剧；童话剧；哑剧演员；手势
v. 打手势；演哑剧
a dramatic entertainment, originating in Roman mime, in which performers express meaning through gestures accompanied by music.
an absurdly exaggerated piece of behavior.
a ridiculous or confused situation or event.
a theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, that involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.
express or represent (something) by extravagant and exaggerated mime.
"he made a pantomime of checking his watch"
"the drive to town was a pantomime"
"the clown candidates pantomimed different emotions"
The actor is skilled in pantomime.这个演员擅长表演哑剧。
The audience roared with laughter at the pantomime.观众被这哑剧逗得哈哈大笑。
The children were very excited by the pantomime.孩子们看了童话剧非常兴奋。
Some tourists make themselves understood abroad by pantomime.一些游客在国外通常用手势来让别人明白自己的意思。
Apes are routinely beaten into submission and forced to pantomime human behaviors that are foreign and confusing.猿类被屈打得顺从，被迫模仿对于它们来说是莫名其妙，难以理解的人类行为举止。

papaya

[pə'paɪə], [pə'paɪə]


Image Search
n. 木瓜
a tropical fruit shaped like an elongated melon, with edible orange flesh and small black seeds.
the fast-growing tree that bears the papaya, native to warm regions of America. It is widely cultivated for its fruit, both for eating and for papain production.
He ate a papaya and his tummy got bigger.他吃了一个木瓜，肚子变大了一些。
It is OK really to eat papaya breast enhancement?吃木瓜真的可以丰胸嘛？

parody

['pærədi], ['pærədi]


Image Search
n. 仿作；拙劣的模仿
v. 拙劣模仿；作模仿诗文
an imitation of the style of a particular writer, artist, or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
an imitation or a version of something that falls far short of the real thing; a travesty.
produce a humorously exaggerated imitation of (a writer, artist, or genre).
mimic humorously.
"the movie is a parody of the horror genre"
"he seems like a parody of an educated Englishman"
"his specialty was parodying schoolgirl fiction"
"he parodied his friend's voice"
Time is the wealth of change, but the clock in its parody makes it.时间是变化的财富。时钟模仿它,却只有变化而无财富。
She has become a grotesque parody of her former elegant self.她成为了以前那个举止优雅的自己的怪诞模仿品。
The trial was a parody of justice.这次审判是对公正的一次拙劣的模拟。
His style has often been parodied.他的风格经常被拙劣地模仿。

parsimonious

[ˌpɑːsɪ'məʊniəs], [ˌpɑːrsə'moʊniəs]


Image Search
adj. 极度节省的；吝啬的
unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy or frugal.
"parsimonious New Hampshire voters, who have a phobia about taxes"
And physicists are very parsimonious with postulates.而物理学家的原则是使用尽量少的假定。
His parsimonious nature did not permit him to enjoy any luxuries.他那吝啬的本性不容许他享受任何奢侈品。

parsley

['pɑːsli], ['pɑːrsli]


Image Search
n. 欧芹；荷兰芹
a biennial plant with white flowers and aromatic leaves that are either crinkly or flat and used as a culinary herb and for garnishing food.
Parsley is used for flavoring food.欧芹常用来给食品调味。
He decorated the chicken with sprigs of parsley.他用欧芹的嫩枝点缀在鸡上。
Do you know about a third kind of parsley?这种荷兰芹通常被称为意大利欧芹或法国欧芹。
Parsley is often served with lamb fish and beef dishes.荷兰芹通常用在羊肉，鱼肉和牛肉中。

parsnip

['pɑːsnɪp], ['pɑːrsnɪp]


Image Search
n. 欧洲防风草；欧洲萝卜
a long tapering cream-colored root with a sweet flavor.
the widely cultivated Eurasian plant of the parsley family that yields this root.
This dish of parsnip tastes strange.这盘欧防风做的菜味道很怪。

particle

['pɑːtɪkl], ['pɑːrtɪkl]


Image Search
n. 颗粒；微粒；极小量；质点；粒子；[语]小品词
a minute portion of matter.
the least possible amount.
another term for subatomic particle.
a hypothetical object having mass but no physical size.
a minor function word that has comparatively little meaning and does not inflect, in particular.
(in English) any of the class of words such as in, up, off, over, used with verbs to make phrasal verbs.
(in ancient Greek) any of the class of words such as de and ge, used for contrast and emphasis.
"tiny particles of dust"
"he agrees without hearing the least particle of evidence"
We can see the dust particles floating in the sunlight clearly.我们可以很清楚地看到阳光下的灰尘颗粒。
An atom is the smallest indivisible particle of matter.原子是最小的不可分的物质微粒。
There wasn't a particle of truth in what he said.他说的没有一点真话。
The particle is displaced in a flow domain.这质点在流动区域内运动。
The particle will accelerate under the action of the applied force.这个粒子在所加力的作用下将作加速运动。
In 'She tore up the letter', the word 'up' is a particle.在 She tore up the letter 句中，up 便是小品词。

partisan

[ˌpɑːtɪ'zæn], ['pɑːrtəzn]


Image Search
adj. 偏袒的；党派性的
n. 强烈支持者；党羽；游击队员
a strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
a member of an armed group formed to fight secretly against an occupying force, in particular one operating in enemy-occupied Yugoslavia, Italy, and parts of eastern Europe in World War II.
prejudiced in favor of a particular cause.
"newspapers have become increasingly partisan"
You must listen to both points of view and try not to be partisan.你必须兼听双方观点
The other obstacle is partisan bickering.另一个障碍是党派间的纷争。
He is a staunch partisan of the Republican Party.他是共和党的坚定支持者。
Partisan politics is often an obstruction to good government.党羽的政治阴谋常是良好政府的阻碍。
Even after the country is defeated, partisan fight the invader in the hill.即使在国家被击败之后,游击队仍在山里与入侵者抗战。
It is the partisan who drove the enemy forces out of our country.是游击队员把敌人从我们国家赶出去的。

partition

[pɑː'tɪʃn], [pɑːr'tɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 划分；隔离物
vt. 区分；隔开；分割
(especially with reference to a country with separate areas of government) the action or state of dividing or being divided into parts.
a structure dividing a space into two parts, especially a light interior wall.
the distribution of a solute between two immiscible or slightly miscible solvents in contact with one another, in accordance with its differing solubility in each.
each of a number of portions into which some operating systems divide memory or storage.
divide into parts.
divide (a room) into smaller rooms or areas by erecting partitions.
separate a part of a room from the rest by erecting a partition.
"the country's partition into separate states"
"an agreement was reached to partition the country"
"the hall was partitioned to contain the noise of the computers"
"partition off part of a large bedroom to create a small bathroom"
The key to resolve the problem is elaborate partition for time and manpower.关键的解决这人问题的方法是把时间和人力精心划分。
I could hear what he was saying on the phone through the partition.我能隔着墙听见他在电话里说了些什么。
Our office is comparted by a partition board.我们的办公室用一个隔扇分成两部分。
There is a plywood partition between the two rooms.两个房子中间有一个夹板墙。
The workers partition a room into three parts.工人们把一间房间分成三部分。
He partition off part of the room as a study.他将房间一部分隔开作书房。
We've partitioned off one end of the kitchen to make a breakfast room.我们已把厨房的一头隔开作吃早饭的房间。

pasta

['pæstə], ['pɑːstə]


Image Search
n. 意大利面
a dish originally from Italy consisting of dough made from durum wheat and water, extruded or stamped into various shapes and typically cooked in boiling water.
Do you want chicken or pasta for dinner?晚餐您喜欢鸡肉还是意大利面？
I come from a large Italian family where pasta and cannoli are staples in our diet.我来自一个意大利大家庭，面食和奶油甜卷是我们膳食中的主食。

pathetic

[pə'θetɪk], [pə'θetɪk]


Image Search
adj. 可怜的；不足的；感伤的；悲哀的
arousing pity, especially through vulnerability or sadness.
miserably inadequate.
relating to the emotions.
"she looked so pathetic that I bent down to comfort her"
"his test scores in Chemistry were pathetic"
We saw the pathetic sight of starving children.我们看到挨饿的儿童悲惨可怜的样子。
She dances well, but as a singer, she is pathetic.她跳舞跳得好，但唱歌就差劲了。
God! The freshmen are pathetic this year!天啊！今年的大一新生什么也不懂！
I never heard anything that sounded so pathetic.我从未听说过如此悲伤的事了。
His tears were pathetic to witness.他的眼泪引起在场人的怜悯。
It was pathetic to watch her condition deteriorate.看着她的健康状况恶化真是感到难过。
The police do not pity those poor, pathetic and helpless homeless.警察一点也不同情那些既悲哀又无助的游民。
You are nothing but a pathetic fool.你只不过是个可怜的傻瓜。

patron

['peɪtrən], ['peɪtrən]


Image Search
n. 赞助人；老主顾；守护神
a person who gives financial or other support to a person, organization, cause, or activity.
a customer, especially a regular one, of a store, restaurant, or theater.
short for patron saint.
(in ancient Rome) a patrician in relation to a client.
(in ancient Rome) the former owner and (frequently) protector of a freed slave.
a person or institution with the right to grant a benefice to a member of the clergy.
"Charles became a patron of Rubens and van Dyck"
"we surveyed the plushness of the hotel and its sleek, well-dressed patrons"
Modern artists have difficulty in finding patrons.现代艺术家们很难找到赞助人。
He inscribed those poems to his patron.他将这些诗献给他的赞助人。
This store has many patrons.这家商店有许多老顾客。
The usher handed the patron to a reserved seat.引座员把顾客引到预订的座位上
St Christopher is the patron saint of travellers.圣·克里斯托弗是旅行者的守护神。

peak

[piːk], [piːk]


Image Search
n. 尖端；山顶；顶峰
v. 达到顶峰；使处于顶点
vi. 消瘦
the pointed top of a mountain.
a mountain, especially one with a pointed top.
a projecting pointed part or shape.
a point in a curve or on a graph, or a value of a physical quantity, higher than those around it.
the point of highest activity, quality, or achievement.
a stiff brim at the front of a cap.
the narrow part of a ship's hold at the bow or stern.
the upper, outer corner of a sail extended by a gaff.
reach a highest point, either of a specified value or at a specified time.
greatest; maximum.
characterized by maximum activity or demand.
decline in health and spirits; waste away.
"the snowy peaks rose against the blue of a cloudless sky"
"the rocky outcrops of peaks such as the Cassongrat offer a challenge to rock climbers"
"whisk 2 egg whites to stiff peaks"
"a slight increase in velocity provides a second peak on the general velocity curve"
"anyone who saw Jones at his peak looked upon genius"
"its popularity peaked in the 1940s"
"he did not expect to be anywhere near peak fitness until Christmas"
"at peak hours, traffic speeds are reduced considerably"
In Yersa I noticed a spike on the peak of the pyramid-shaped roof of a church.在叶拉萨村,我发现一座教堂的金字塔屋顶的尖端有一颗尖钉。
The mountain peaks are covered with snow all year.山顶上终年积雪。
Many mountaineers have reached that mountain peak.许多登山家都登上过那座大山的顶峰。
Tourism is at its peak in August.旅游业在八月份达到高峰。
Primary school enrolment will peak this year.今年小学入学人数将达到最高峰。
Sales tend to peak just before the holidays.节日前销售量趋于最高潮
Property prices have peaked.房地产价格已达到最高点。

peer

[pɪə(r)], [pɪr]


Image Search
n. 同辈；同等的人；贵族
vi. 凝视；窥视
look keenly or with difficulty at someone or something.
be just visible.
come into view; appear.
a member of the nobility in Britain or Ireland, comprising the ranks of duke, marquess, earl, viscount, and baron.
a person of the same age, status, or ability as another specified person.
make or become equal with or of the same rank.
"Blake screwed up his eyes, trying to peer through the fog"
"the two towers peer over the roofs"
"he has incurred much criticism from his academic peers"
Children are easily influenced by their peers.孩子很容易受同辈影响。
He was valued by both his peer and his superiors.他的同级和上级都很器重他。
The opinions of his peers are more important to him than his parents' ideas.在他看来，他同辈人的观点比他父母的观点更为重要。
It will not be easy to find his peer.很不容易找到像他那样的人.
He was created a peer of the UK in 2005.他在2005年被封为英国的贵族。
She peers through the mist, trying to find the right path.她透过雾眯着眼看，想找出正确的路。
She peer at me over the top of her glasses.她从眼镜上方盯着我看。
The cloud of data flowing through their workstations forms a clear digital globe for them to peer into.这些云聚的数据流过他们的工作站，形成了一种清澈的数据世界，让他们能够窥视其究竟。

penne

['peneɪ], ['peneɪ]


Image Search
n. 短管状通心面
pasta in the form of short wide tubes.

perishable

['perɪʃəbl], ['perɪʃəbl]


Image Search
adj. 易腐烂的；会枯萎的；会死的
（复数）perishables:易腐烂的东西（尤指食物）.
(especially of food) likely to decay or go bad quickly.
(of something abstract) having a brief life or significance; transitory.
things, especially foodstuffs, likely to decay or go bad quickly.
"ballet is the most perishable of arts"
Perishable goods are piling up at the docks.码头上易腐烂的货物堆积如山。
Unlike perishable agricultural products, oil can be stored in the ground.不同于易腐烂的农产品，石油可以长期埋在地下。

permeate

['pɜːmieɪt], ['pɜːrmieɪt]


Image Search
v. 弥漫；渗透；普及
spread throughout (something); pervade.
"the aroma of soup permeated the air"
His subtle satisfaction seemed to permeate the space around them.他难以捉摸的满足感好像弥漫在了他们的周围。
If your wine is still, pour it into the centre of the glass to let the bouquet permeate the vessel.如果是无汽泡的酒，直接倒入杯子中央，使酒的香气充分散发，弥漫整个酒杯。
Water will permeate blotting paper.水能渗透吸水纸。
Functional relationships permeate every part of science.函数关系渗透自然科学的每个部分。

perpetuate

[pə'petʃueɪt], [pər'petʃueɪt]


Image Search
vt. 使永存；使不朽
make (something, typically an undesirable situation or an unfounded belief) continue indefinitely.
preserve (something valued) from oblivion or extinction.
"the law perpetuated the interests of the ruling class"
"how did these first humans survive to perpetuate the species?"
These measures will perpetuate the hostility between the two groups.采取这些措施势必使那两集团永远对立。
They decided to perpetuate the memory of their leader by erecting a statue.他们为永远纪念那位领袖决定建一座雕像。

perplexed

[pə'plekst], [pər'plekst]


Image Search

动词perplex的过去式和过去分词.
completely baffled; very puzzled.
(of something complicated or unaccountable) cause (someone) to feel completely baffled.
complicate or confuse (a matter).
"she gave him a perplexed look"
"she was perplexed by her husband's moodiness"
"they were perplexing a subject plain in itself"
We were perplexed by his failure to answer the letter.他何以不回信,我们大惑不解。
When new math was introduced into schools, many parents were perplexed by it.当学校开设新的数学课时，许多家长对此感到迷惑不解。
Faced with that dilemma, he was perplexed.他面对进退两难的局面，不知如何是好。

persevere

[ˌpɜːsɪ'vɪə(r)], [ˌpɜːrsə'vɪr]


Image Search
v. 坚持；不屈不挠
continue in a course of action even in the face of difficulty or with little or no prospect of success.
"his family persevered with his treatment"
When things get difficult, you just have to grit your teeth and persevere.遇到困难只需咬紧牙关坚持下去。
If you persevere with work, you'll succeed in the end.你如果把工作坚持下去，最终会取得成功的。
He was hopeless at French, but his teacher persevered with him.他怎么也学不会法语,可是老师仍锲而不舍地帮助他。

persist

[pə'sɪst], [pər'sɪst]


Image Search
v. 坚持；执意；继续；持续
continue firmly or obstinately in an opinion or a course of action in spite of difficulty, opposition, or failure.
continue to exist; be prolonged.
"the minority of drivers who persist in drinking"
"if the symptoms persist for more than a few days, contact your doctor"
I hope you'll persist in your efforts.我希望你们再接再励。
He will persist in riding that dreadful bicycle.他执意要骑那辆破自行车。
If you persist, you will annoy them even more.你若固执，他们就更恼火了。
If you persist in breaking the law you will go to prison.如果你再继续违法的话，你会坐牢的。
They persist with the agricultural reform, despite opposition from the farmers.他们不顾农民反对,仍继续进行农业改革。
The cold weather will persist for the rest of the week.这种寒冷的天气将持续到本周末。

personify

[pə'sɒnɪfaɪ], [pər'sɑːnɪfaɪ]

"public pageants and dramas in which virtues and vices were personified"
"in the poem, the oak trees are personified"
"he fairly personifies trustworthiness"

He is kindness personified.他是善良的化身。
He personifies the worship of money.他是拜金的化身。
Artists personify beauty in their works.艺术家在作品中表现美。

pertain

[pə'teɪn], [pər'teɪn]


Image Search
vi. 关于；从属；适合
be appropriate, related, or applicable.
belong to something as a part, appendage, or accessory.
be in effect or existence in a specified place or at a specified time.
"matters pertaining to the organization of government"
"the premises, stock, and all assets pertaining to the business"
"their economic circumstances are vastly different from those which pertained in their land of origin"
This letter does not pertain to politics.这封信的内容与政治无关。
Learning the specific set of vocabulary words that pertain to one's business becomes a simple task.学习和自己行业有关的这组特殊字汇成为一件简单的工作。
They own the house and the land pertaining to it.他们拥有这栋房子以及附属于它的土地。
It does not pertain to the young to instruct their elders.年轻人不应该对老年人发号施令。

perturb

"nuclear weapons could be used to perturb the orbit of an asteroid"

pessimist

['pesɪmɪst], ['pesɪmɪst]


Image Search
n. 悲观主义者
a person who tends to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
a person who believes that this world is as bad as it could be or that evil will ultimately prevail over good.
"the pessimists point to ways in which life has deteriorated"
"he finds solace in the writings of pessimist philosophers"
He is a pessimist and a defeatist.他是悲观主义者，也是失败主义者。
It may be that I am a pessimist, for spring it is, not autumn, that makes me sad.因为春天而非秋天使我感到伤感，所以也许我是个悲观主义者。

pessimistic

[ˌpesɪ'mɪstɪk], [ˌpesɪ'mɪstɪk]


Image Search

tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
"he was pessimistic about the prospects"
I have to say I'm rather pessimistic.我得说我相当悲观。
Her pessimistic attitude turns him off.她那悲观的态度很令他不高兴。
There is a pessimistic tone to what he is saying.他的话语中带着悲观的调子。
This might account for his pessimistic views.这也许是他持悲观主义观点的原因。
Dreiser's novels reveal a stream of pessimistic emotion.德莱塞的小说里渗透着一股沉重的悲观主义情绪。

pestle

['pesl], ['pesl]


Image Search
n. 杵；乳钵槌
a heavy tool with a rounded end, used for crushing and grinding substances such as spices or drugs, usually in a mortar.
a mechanical device for grinding, pounding, or stamping something.
crush or grind (a substance such as a spice or drug) with a pestle.
"she measured seeds into the mortar and pestled them to powder"
He ground the rock candy with a mortar and pestle.他自己动手用研钵和杵把冰糖研成粉。
A pestle can be ground into a needle and true knowledge comes from perseverance.想得到真正的学问，必有须磨杵成针的精神。

petty

['peti], ['peti]


Image Search
adj. 小的；琐碎的；次要的；狭隘的
of little importance; trivial.
(of behavior) characterized by an undue concern for trivial matters, especially in a small-minded or spiteful way.
of secondary or lesser importance, rank, or scale; minor.
(of a crime) of lesser importance.
"the petty divisions of party politics"
"he was prone to petty revenge on friends and family"
"a petty official"
"petty theft"
The party split into petty factions.该党分裂成若干小派系。
The paymasters of these petty crooks are the big crime syndicates.操纵这帮小流氓的就是那个大犯罪集团。
In his short life he had run the entire gamut of crime, from petty theft to murder.他在短短的一生中,从小偷小摸到杀人,什么罪都犯过。
Don't bug me with petty details.不要讲那些琐碎的细节来烦我。
People do not discourage this kind of petty work.人们对这种次要的工作不加以阻止。
She grew tired of his petty jealousies.她越来越讨厌他那种心胸狭窄的忌妒行为。
She is very petty at times.她有时很小心眼。

phenomenon

[fə'nɒmɪnən], [fə'nɑːmɪnən]


Image Search
n. 现象；奇人；奇事
a fact or situation that is observed to exist or happen, especially one whose cause or explanation is in question.
a remarkable person, thing, or event.
the object of a person's perception; what the senses or the mind notice.
"glaciers are unique and interesting natural phenomena"
Their so-called prosperity is only a temporary phenomenon.但他们所谓的繁荣只是一个暂时的现象。
International terrorism is not just a recent phenomenon.国际恐怖主义并不是近年才有的现象。
Magnetism is a natural phenomenon.磁力是一种自然现象。
A child who could read at the age of one would indeed be a phenomenon.一个一岁的孩子能阅读，会被认为是个神童。
Beethoven was a phenomenon among musicians.贝多芬是音乐家中的奇才。
There are special reasons for this unusual phenomenon.这种奇事的发生，有其独特的原因。

phoneme

['fəʊniːm], ['foʊniːm]


Image Search
n. 音位；音素
any of the perceptually distinct units of sound in a specified language that distinguish one word from another, for example p, b, d, and t in the English words pad, pat, bad, and bat.
English has 24 consonant phonemes.英语有24个辅音音素。
Phoneme segmentation plays a key role in speech recognition.音素分割在语音识别的过程中起着重要的作用。
In English, the 's' in 'sip' and the 'z' in 'zip' represent two different phonemes.英语中sip中的s和zip中的z为两个不同的音素。

piggish

['pɪgɪʃ], ['pɪgɪʃ]


Image Search
adj. 猪似的；贪吃的；肮脏的
resembling a pig, especially in being greedy or unpleasant.
Piggish table manners,the piggy fat-cheeked little boy and his porcine pot-bellied father. 像猪一般的饮食方式，像猪一般的胖脸小男孩和他的猪一般大肚皮的父亲。
If you weren't feeling piggish after we hit an all-time high on the Nasdaq in 2000, you needed a shrink, pronto. 如果我们在2000年创了历史新高的时候你还没有当猪的感觉，我想你需要反省一下了。
If you weren’t feeling piggish after we hit an all-time high on the Nasdaq in 2000, you needed a shrink, pronto. 如果得到”绝对不买”的结论时,也许你此时应该减仓。
As we have learned, "Scene is piggish duck " also sufferred similar destiny in a lot of cities such as Jinan, Lanzhou, Beijing. 据了解,"风光馋嘴鸭"在济南、兰州、北京等许多城市也遭受了类似的命运。
A day of dusk, "Piggish " in the catnap in bistro, the hair comes up against the oil lamp on the desk, the person on the side saw cry in fear rises: "Be bad! 一天傍晚，“馋嘴”在小酒馆里打瞌睡，头发碰到桌上的油灯，旁边的人见了惊叫起来：“不好！
This strikes many people outside 85 Broad Street as piggish and unfair, since the American taxpayer helped rescue the system from which Goldman is now benefiting. 这让布罗德大街(BroadStreet)85号（高盛总部所在地，译者注）外的许多人感受到了高盛的贪婪和世道的不公，因为帮助金融体系纾困的是美国纳税人，现在受益的却是高盛。

pigment

['pɪɡmənt], ['pɪɡmənt]


Image Search
n. 色素； 颜料
v. 把 ... 加颜色； 变色
the natural coloring matter of animal or plant tissue.
a substance used for coloring or painting, especially a dry powder that, when mixed with oil, water, or another medium, constitutes a paint or ink.
color (something) with or as if with pigment.
"pigmented areas such as freckles"
This pigment is a good common food additive.该色素是稳定性好的食品添加剂。
How is retinal pigment denaturation treated?视网膜色素变性怎样治疗？
The primary white pigment is titanium dioxide.最重要的白色颜料是二氧化钛。
Of course, pigment is not the only part of a fresco.当然，颜料还不是画面的全部。
You just expand or shrink the millions of pigment cells or chromatophores in your skin to instantly change color.你只需要展开或收缩你皮肤里的上百万个色素细胞或色素体就可以立即变色。

Image Search

名词pile的复数形式.
动词pile的单数第三人称形式.
hemorrhoids.
a heap of things laid or lying one on top of another.
a large amount of something.
a lot of money.
a large imposing building or group of buildings.
a series of plates of dissimilar metals laid one on another alternately to produce an electric current.
dated term for nuclear reactor.
a funeral pyre.
place (things) one on top of another.
be stacked or loaded with.
increase in quantity.
cause to increase in quantity.
intensify or exaggerate something for effect.
(of a group of people) get into or out of a vehicle in a disorganized manner.
(of a vehicle) crash into.
a heavy beam or post driven vertically into the bed of a river, soft ground, etc., to support the foundations of a structure.
a triangular charge or ordinary formed by two lines meeting at an acute angle, usually pointing down from the top of the shield.
strengthen or support (a structure) with piles.
the soft projecting surface of a carpet or of a fabric such as velvet or flannel, consisting of many small threads.
furnish with a pile.
"he placed the books in a neat pile"
"the growing pile of work"
"he is admired for having made a pile for himself"
"a Victorian Gothic pile"
"she piled all the groceries on the counter"
"his in-box was piled high with papers"
"the work has piled up"
"the debts he piled up"
"you can pile on the guilt, but my heart has turned to stone"
"we all piled in and headed off to our mysterious destination"
"60 cars piled into each other on I-95"
"a thick-piled carpet"
The doctor told him to have a hip bath for seven days after having piles.医生告诉他得了痔疮后要用药剂坐浴七天。

pilfer

['pɪlfə(r)], ['pɪlfər]


Image Search
v. 盗；偷；窃
steal (typically things of relatively little value).
They may pilfer other animals' food.它们可能会偷吃其它动物的食品。
As we predicted from the results of the first experiments, knowers rushed to pilfer the human-made cache if they were paired with another knower.结果，知情渡鸦要是与另一只也知情的渡鸦在一起，就会急著去偷取人藏起的物事，符合我们根据先前的实验结果所做的预测。

"he had reached the pinnacle of his career"
"a rustic cross was pinnacled upon the makeshift altar"

pious

['paɪəs], ['paɪəs]


Image Search
adj. 虔诚的；伪善的；不太可能实现的
devoutly religious.
making a hypocritical display of virtue.
(of a hope) sincere but unlikely to be fulfilled.
dutiful or loyal, especially toward one's parents.
"there'll be no pious words said over her"
He is a pious Christian.他是一名虔诚的基督教徒。
He is a pious person to his belief.他是一个对其信仰虔诚的人。
Honest doubt is better than in a pious fraud.诚实的怀疑胜过伪善的信任。
Congress did no more than set out some pious hopes.国会除了提出一些不可能实现的希望之外别无所为。

pitiless

['pɪtiləs], ['pɪtiləs]


Image Search
adj. 无情的；冷酷的；无怜悯心的
showing no pity; cruel.
The fact stood out cut in steel on the pitiless daylight.在无情的光天化日下,这个事实是确凿无疑的。
This ruler is a pitiless tyrant.这个统治者是一个冷酷的暴君。
The pitiless north wind blew for weeks.凛冽的北风一连刮了几个星期。
The pitiless woman refused to help the poor sick girl.这铁石心肠的妇人拒绝帮助这个生病的可怜女孩。
They said he was a pitiless, cold-blooded fellow, with no geniality in him.他们说他是个毫无怜悯心、一点也不和蔼的冷血动物。

The concessions did little to placate the students.让步根本未能平息学生的愤怒。
