without a partner at a social gathering.
"a stag event"
"a lot of boys went stag"
Are you going to Jim's stag party on Friday evening?星期五晚上你打算去杰姆家参加男子交谊会吗？
The hunter shot the stag dead.猎人把雄鹿射死了。

stagnate

[stæɡ'neɪt], ['stæɡneɪt]


Image Search
v. 停止；停滞不前；不景气
(of water or air) cease to flow or move; become stagnant.
cease developing; become inactive or dull.
"teaching can easily stagnate into a set of routines"
The one unpardonable sin of nature is to stand still, to stagnate.自然界最不可饶恕的罪行就是驻足不前，淤滞停止。
The financial industry is likely to stagnate or shrink in the next few years.今后几年，金融行业可能会停滞不前，或缩水。
If you merely repeat the same experiences you'll stagnate and your mental capacity will atrophy.假如你只重复相同的经验，就会停滞不前，脑容量会萎缩。

staid

[steɪd], [steɪd]


Image Search
adj. 固定的；（指人﹑ 外表﹑ 行为﹑ 爱好等）古板的；保守的；一本正经的
sedate, respectable, and unadventurous.
"staid law firms"
He does this by transmitting not a staid image but a simulacra.他不是通过传输固定的图像而是传输某种拟像而做到了这一点。
The museum is trying to get rid of its staid image.博物馆力图改变自己古板的形象。
I always thought of him as a rather staid old gentleman.我一直以为他是个相当古板的绅士。
The locals were a very staid lot.当地居民非常保守。
We think of the Puritans as staid people.我们认为清教徒是很稳重的人。

stamina

['stæmɪnə], ['stæmɪnə]


Image Search
n. 精力；活力；耐力
n. [植]雄蕊
名词stamen的复数形式.
the ability to sustain prolonged physical or mental effort.
"their secret is stamina rather than speed"
He doesn't have the stamina to be a teacher.他没有当教师的精力。
It's no wonder you've got so much stamina.难怪你精力这么充沛。
Currently, this region's economic development continues to maintain growth stamina.目前，该地区经济发展继续保持增长活力。
He runs every day to hone his stamina.为了增强耐力，他每天都进行跑步锻炼。
Marathon runners need plenty of stamina.参加马拉松长跑要有耐力。

stature

['stætʃə(r)], ['stætʃər]


Image Search
n. 身高；名望
a person's natural height.
importance or reputation gained by ability or achievement.
"a man of short stature"
"an architect of international stature"
She was rather small in stature.她身材矮小。
He is five feet five inches in stature/height.他身高5英尺5英寸。
She had not yet grown to full stature.她的个子还没有完全长到应有的高度。
He is a musician of world stature.他是一个世界级的音乐家。
She is an artist of great stature.她是一位极具名望的艺术家。
The air weapon has now at last begun to attain its full stature.空中武器现在终于开始发挥它的充分作用了。
Time has devalued his stature as a play writer.随着时光的流逝，他作为剧作家的地位下降了。

steadfast

['stedfɑːst], ['stedfæst]


Image Search
adj. 坚定的；毫不动摇的
resolutely or dutifully firm and unwavering.
"steadfast loyalty"
Our nation is patient and steadfast.我们的国家是有耐心的，立场是坚定的。
He adopted a steadfast attitude towards this issue.他对这件事采取坚定的态度。
He is of a resolute and steadfast disposition.他的性格非常刚毅。

stoic

['stəʊɪk], ['stoʊɪk]


Image Search
n. 坚忍克己之人；禁欲主义者
adj. 坚忍克己的；禁欲的
Stoic.
n. 斯多葛派人士
adj. 斯多葛学派的
a person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining.
a member of the ancient philosophical school of Stoicism.
another term for stoical.
of or belonging to the Stoics or their school of philosophy.
A stoic person responds to hardship with imperturbation.坚忍克己之人经受苦难仍能泰然自若。

strand

[strænd], [strænd]


Image Search
n. 缕；(线等的)股；海滨，河岸，海滩
v. 使陷于困境；弄断；使落后；（使）搁浅
drive or leave (a boat, sailor, or sea creature) aground on a shore.
leave (someone) without the means to move from somewhere.
the shore of a sea, lake, or large river.
a single thin length of something such as thread, fiber, or wire, especially as twisted together with others.
a string of beads or pearls.
an element that forms part of a complex whole.
"the ships were stranded in shallow water"
"they were stranded in St. Louis by the blizzard"
"a heron glided to rest on a pebbly strand"
"a strand of cotton"
"certain strands of postmodern thought"
She twirled a strand of hair round her finger.她把一绺头发卷绕在手指上。
One strand of silk doesn't make a thread; one tree doesn't make a forest.单丝不成线,独木不成林。

stratify

['strætɪfaɪ], ['strætɪfaɪ]


Image Search
v. （使）成层；分层
form or arrange into strata.
arrange or classify.
place (seeds) close together in layers in moist sand or peat to preserve them or to help them germinate.
(of seeds) be germinated by stratifying.
"socially stratified cities"
"stratifying patients into well-defined risk groups"
"if you want to sow your own mistletoe, collect ripe berries and store them in moist sand to stratify"
Stratify teaching to be one to plant in lower individual-rization collective teaching form teaching tactics.分层教学是一种在集体教学形式下的个别化教学策略。

stretcher

['stretʃə(r)], ['stretʃər]


Image Search
n. 担架；伸张器；横档
a framework of two poles with a long piece of canvas slung between them, used for carrying sick, injured, or dead people.
a gurney.
a thing that stretches something, in particular.
a wooden frame over which a canvas is spread and tautened ready for painting.
an exaggeration or lie.
a rod or bar joining and supporting chair legs.
a crosspiece in the bottom of a boat on which a rower's feet are braced.
a brick or stone laid with its long side along the face of a wall.
The injured were carried away on stretchers.受伤的人被用担架抬走了。
An ambulance officer brought a stretcher for the injured woman.救护车工作人员带来了一副担架抢救那位受伤的女子。

strident

['straɪdnt], ['straɪdnt]


Image Search
adj. 刺耳的；吱吱尖叫的；尖锐的
loud and harsh; grating.
presenting a point of view, especially a controversial one, in an excessively and unpleasantly forceful way.
another term for sibilant.
"his voice had become increasingly sharp, almost strident"
"public pronouncements on the crisis became less strident"
His strident voice rang through the house.他那刺耳的嗓音响彻整个房子。
People are put off by her strident voice.人们对她刺耳的嗓音感到十分厌恶。
Here we can hear the strident calls of a crane or goose.这儿我们能听到一只鹤或鹅的尖锐鸣声。
The siren is really strident.警笛声好尖锐啊。
He is a strident advocate of nuclear power.他是发展核能的坚定拥护者。
The plan has provided strident criticism from local residents.这个计划招致当地居民的猛烈抨击。

strife

[straɪf], [straɪf]


Image Search
n. 争吵；冲突；倾轧；竞争
angry or bitter disagreement over fundamental issues; conflict.
"strife within the community"
She was faint with strife and dejected.她被争吵弄得精疲力竭，情绪低落。
We really shouldn't intervene in their marital strife.我们不该介入他们夫妻间的争吵。
The internecine strife was caused by a shortage of food.这次内部冲突，是由于食物匮乏而引致的。
And he remains edgy about the continuing strife in Somalia.梅莱斯也对索马里冲突不止而烦躁。
The party was rent with mutual strife.该党因互相倾轧而四分五裂。
Strife in nature is but disorder longing for order.自然界的竞争不过是混乱渴望着秩序。
Strife on college campuses helped change the attitude of the nation.高校间的竞争有助于改变国家的态度。

string bean


Image Search
any of various beans eaten in their fibrous pods, such as scarlet runners.
a tall thin person.
String beans belong to the pea family.菜豆属于豌豆属植物。

stringent

['strɪndʒənt], ['strɪndʒənt]


Image Search
adj. 严格的；银根紧的；紧迫的
(of regulations, requirements, or conditions) strict, precise, and exacting.
"California's air pollution guidelines are stringent"
Licences are only granted under the most stringent conditions.只有符合极其严格的条件才颁发许可证。
People began verify their scientific hypotheses by stringent tests.人们开始用精确的试验证实自己的科学假说。
Some of our most outstanding buildings have been created on a stringent budget.我们的一些杰出作品往往是在很紧凑的预算下设计建成的。
Based on above analysis the stringent problems needed to resolve are put forward.在此基础上指出今后迫切需要解决的问题。

structural

['strʌktʃərəl], ['strʌktʃərəl]


Image Search
adj. 结构的；构造的；建筑的；建筑用的
relating to or forming part of the structure of a building or other item.
relating to the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of a complex whole.
"the blast left ten buildings with major structural damage"
"there have been structural changes in the industry"
Such structural information could be bankable.这种蛋白质结构的资讯是可以卖钱的。
The dynamic simulation of FOPS will provide the basis for the structural design.落物保护结构的动态仿真为结构的设计提供了依据。
Note that in areas of monoclinal dip the closure of a trap may not be the same as its structural relief.值得注意的是，在只有单斜地层的构造内，圈闭的幅度可能与构造的起伏不一样。
Interpretation of these structures can be improved by the application of accurate structural models and balanced cross section techniques.利用准确的构造模型的平衡截面兔方法能提高对这些构造的解释。
Blue fluorescent tubes wash the floor with an eerie light while up-lighters accentuate structural members.蓝色的荧光灯管给地板渡上了一层奇特的光亮，向上照射的灯渲染着建筑的每一部分。
The structural type and design scheme for a building project should be based on its serviceable function and force conditions.摘要建筑工程设计时，需要根据建筑的使用功能和建筑结构的受力特征，确定结构形式及设计方案。

struggle

['strʌɡl], ['strʌɡl]


Image Search
vi. 努力；奋斗；斗争；挣扎
n. 斗争；竞争；奋斗
make forceful or violent efforts to get free of restraint or constriction.
strive to achieve or attain something in the face of difficulty or resistance.
have difficulty handling or coping with.
engage in conflict.
make one's way with difficulty.
a forceful or violent effort to get free of restraint or resist attack.
a conflict or contest.
a determined effort under difficulties.
a very difficult task.
"before she could struggle, he lifted her up"
"many families struggle to make ends meet"
"passengers struggle with bags and briefcases"
"politicians continued to struggle over familiar issues"
"he struggled to the summit of the world's highest mountain"
"a power struggle for the leadership"
"the center is the result of the scientists' struggle to realize their dream"
"it was a struggle to make herself understood"
He struggled to control his temper.他努力控制住自己的脾气。
They should therefore unite to struggle together.因此,他们要联合起来,共同努力奋斗。
Let's join hands and struggle together.咱们携起手来共同斗争。
People struggle at the dead-line.人们在死亡线上挣扎。
He gave up the struggle in despair.他绝望地放弃了斗争。
He came off very well in the struggle.在这场竞争中，他非常成功。
After a long struggle, she gained control of the business.她经过长期的努力，在业务上已能应付自如。

stupefy

['stjuːpɪfaɪ], ['stuːpɪfaɪ]


Image Search
v. (使)茫然；失去知觉
make (someone) unable to think or feel properly.
astonish and shock.
"the offense of administering drugs to a woman with intent to stupefy her"
"the amount they spend on clothes would appall their parents and stupefy their grandparents"
Exhilarated or stupefied by or as if by alcohol; intoxicated.醉的，陶醉的因(仿佛)喝酒类饮料而兴奋或木然的; 醉的
I was stupefied by what I read.我读到的内容把我惊呆了。

submissive

[səb'mɪsɪv], [səb'mɪsɪv]


Image Search
adj. 服从的；顺从的
ready to conform to the authority or will of others; meekly obedient or passive.
She followed him like a submissive child.她对他百依百顺，像个听话的孩子。
The submissive daughter was never able to fight against her parents.这个顺从的女儿从不和她的父母吵架。
He is a humble and submissive servant .他是个恭顺的仆人。

subordinate

[sə'bɔːdɪnət], [sə'bɔːrdɪnət]


Image Search
adj. 下级的；次要的
n. 属下；附属物
vt. 使服从；把 ... 放在次要
lower in rank or position.
of less or secondary importance.
a person under the authority or control of another within an organization.
treat or regard as of lesser importance than something else.
make subservient to or dependent on something else.
"his subordinate officers"
"in adventure stories, character must be subordinate to action"
"practical considerations were subordinated to political expediency"
He is a subordinate officer.他是位下级军官。
She works in the subordinate hospital of our universtiy.她在我们学校的附属医院工作。
All the other issues are subordinate to this one.所有问题都要以这个问题为主。
He was always friendly to his subordinates.他对下级一向和蔼可亲。
Please delegatea task to a subordinate.请把任务委托给下属。
He subordinated his wishes to the general good of the group.他使自己的愿望服从于集体的利益。
WE should subordinate our personal interests to those of the collective.我们应该让个人利益服从集体利益。
In her book, she subordinates this issue to more general problems.在她的书中,她把这个问题处理的不如一般问题重要。

subsequent

['sʌbsɪkwənt], ['sʌbsɪkwənt]


Image Search
adj. 随后的；后来的
coming after something in time; following.
(of a stream or valley) having a direction or character determined by the resistance to erosion of the underlying rock, and typically following the strike of the strata.
"the theory was developed subsequent to the earthquake of 1906"
Subsequent events proved me wrong.後来发生的事证明我错了。
He confessed to other crimes subsequent to the bank robbery.他供认抢劫银行案後，又坦白了其他罪行。
Subsequent to its success as a play, it was made into a film.该剧在舞台上获得成功之後，又摄制成了电影。
Subsequent events confirmed our doubts.后来发生的事证实了我们的怀疑。
The events I'm speaking of were subsequent to the war.我现在说到的事情都是战后发生的。

subside

[səb'saɪd], [səb'saɪd]


Image Search
vi. 沉没；平息；下陷
become less intense, violent, or severe.
lapse into silence or inactivity.
(of water) go down to a lower or the normal level.
(of the ground) cave in; sink.
(of a swelling) reduce until gone.
"I'll wait a few minutes until the storm subsides"
"Fred opened his mouth to protest again, then subsided"
"the floods subside almost as quickly as they arise"
"the island is subsiding"
"it took seven days for the swelling to subside completely"
The hematoma will usually subside in time.血肿通常随时间消逝。
The storm began to subside.风暴渐渐平息了。
He waited until the applause had subsided.他一直等到掌声平息后才继续下去。
Weak foundations caused the house to subside.由于地基不牢，这所房子已下陷。

substance

['sʌbstəns], ['sʌbstəns]


Image Search
n. 实质；物质；财产；内容；重要性
a particular kind of matter with uniform properties.
an intoxicating, stimulating, or narcotic chemical or drug, especially an illegal one.
the real physical matter of which a person or thing consists and which has a tangible, solid presence.
the quality of having a solid basis in reality or fact.
the quality of being dependable or stable.
the quality of being important, valid, or significant.
the most important or essential part of something; the real or essential meaning.
the subject matter of a text, speech, or work of art, especially as contrasted with the form or style in which it is presented.
wealth and possessions.
the essential nature underlying phenomena, which is subject to changes and accidents.
"a steel tube coated with a waxy substance"
"proteins compose much of the actual substance of the body"
"the claim has no substance"
"some were inclined to knock her for her lack of substance"
"he had yet to accomplish anything of substance"
"the substance of the treaty"
"a woman of substance"
The Substance and Prospect of "East China Sea" Dispute between China and Japan中日"东海问题"的实质及展望
The emery is a hard metallic substance.金刚砂是非常坚硬的金属物质。
Beware of what you do with this dangerous substance.你处理这些危险品时，可要当心。
Later he became a man of substance.后来，他成为颇具资产的人。
There is not anything of real substance in their book.他们的书中没有什么实质性的内容。
This argument has some substance.这项争论具有一定的重要性。

succinct

[sək'sɪŋkt], [sək'sɪŋkt]


Image Search
adj. 简洁的
(especially of something written or spoken) briefly and clearly expressed.
"use short, succinct sentences"
Milton summarizes the people's case in many such succinct passages.弥尔顿在许多简洁的段落中概括了人民的处境。

sulky

['sʌlki], ['sʌlki]


Image Search
adj. 生气的；阴沉的
morose, bad-tempered, and resentful; refusing to be cooperative or cheerful.
expressing or suggesting gloom and bad temper.
a light two-wheeled horse-drawn vehicle for one person, used chiefly in harness racing.
"disappointment was making her sulky"
"she had a sultry, sulky mouth"
He was very sulky about it indeed.他对这事确实很生气。
The boss was as sulky as a bear that day.老板那天怒气冲冲。
I should have been sulky and mean.我应该阴沉而自卑。
I see that Basil is in one of his sulky moods.我觉得贝西尔现在情绪很低沉。

sullied

['sʌli], ['sʌli]


Image Search
v. 玷污；弄脏
n. <古>污点；污斑
damage the purity or integrity of; defile.
"they were outraged that anyone should sully their good name"
I wouldn't sully my hands by acceptinga bribe.我决不接受贿赂，一尘不染。
You shouldn't sully his character for no reason.你不应该平白无故地污蔑他人格低下。
Any further recalls will sully their reputations, perhaps irreparably.再有任何召回事件都会玷污它们的声誉，而且可能无法挽回。
No speck of dirt had ever sullied his hands.他的双手从来都是一尘不染。
She wondered if she dared risk sullying the gleaming sink.她犹豫了一下，怕把亮闪闪的洗涤槽弄脏。

superb

[suː'pɜːb], [suː'pɜːrb]


Image Search
adj. 极好的
excellent.
impressively splendid.
"a superb performance"
"a superb Egyptian statue of Osiris"
The sports facilities are superb in this city.这个城市的运动设施是一流的。
The goalkeeper brought off a superb save.守门员漂亮地救出了险球。
Ideas will come to you easily and some will prove to be superb.你总很容易就能想到好计划，其中一些将得到极好的证实。

superfluous

[suː'pɜːfluəs], [suː'pɜːrfluəs]


Image Search
adj. 多余的；过剩的；不必要的
unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
"the purchaser should avoid asking for superfluous information"
Repack all the superfluous cups in the box.把多余的杯子都重新装入箱中。
He has already been told, so our comments are superfluous.早就有人同他说过，所以我们的意见是多余的。
The market is already superfluous.市场已经过剩了。
She crossed out all the superfluous words and phrases in the draft.她把草稿中不必要的词句都杠掉了。
In writing telegrams omit superfluous words.写电报稿要省去不必要的文字。

supplement

['sʌplɪmənt], ['sʌplɪmənt]


Image Search
n. 增刊；补充物
vt. 增补；补充
something that completes or enhances something else when added to it.
a substance taken to remedy the deficiencies in a person's diet.
a separate section, especially a color magazine, added to a newspaper or periodical.
the amount by which an angle is less than 180°.
add an extra element or amount to.
"the handout is a supplement to the official manual"
"multivitamin supplements"
"she took the job to supplement her husband's income"
It comes out each week and it has a magazine supplement.每周出版一期，还附有杂志增刊。
The upset supplement supplier went up with the puppet to the upper room for supper.心烦意乱的增刊供给者与傀儡一起到上面的房间吃晚餐。
The money I got was a useful supplement to my ordinary income.我得到的那笔钱是很管用的外快。
Man's work is rather the needful supplement to himself than the outcome of it.一个人的工作更多地是他自身的必要补充,而非这种补充的结果。
She gives private lessons to supplement her income.她给私人授课以贴补收入。
I supplement my grant by working in the evenings.我除享受助学金外还打夜工以增加收入。
I never refuse odd jobs to supplement my income it's all grist to the mill.我为增加收入，对于做零活总是来者不拒--多多益善。

suppose

[sə'pəʊz], [sə'poʊz]


Image Search
vt. 假设；假定；认为；想；应该；让(虚拟语气)
vi. 推测
assume that something is the case on the basis of evidence or probability but without proof or certain knowledge.
used to make a reluctant or hesitant admission.
used to introduce a hypothesis and trace or ask about what follows from it.
used to introduce a suggestion.
(of a theory or argument) assume or require that something is the case as a precondition.
believe to exist or to possess a specified characteristic.
be required to do something because of the position one is in or an agreement one has made.
be forbidden to do something.
"I suppose I got there about half past eleven"
"I'm quite a good actress, I suppose"
"suppose he had been murdered—what then?"
"suppose we leave this to the police"
"the procedure supposes that a will has already been proved"
"he supposed the girl to be about twelve"
"I'm supposed to be meeting someone at the airport"
"I shouldn't have been in the kitchen—I'm not supposed to go in there"
Suppose you have a thousand dollars, what will you do with it.假设你有一千美元，你会用它做什么。
Let us suppose another planet with conditions similar to those on the earth.让我们假定另外有一个具有和地球上相似条件的行星。
Some religions suppose that there is a Heaven physically above the earth.一些宗教认为地球上面真有一个天国。
I suppose we shall be having some sort of celebration for the bride.我想我们还是来为新娘庆贺一番吧。
You are not suppose to stay home during the weekend.你不应该周末还呆在家里。
Suppose we dine together.让我们一块儿吃饭吧
I suppose he would be about fifty when he obtained a doctorate.我推测他获得博士学位时大概是五十岁左右。

surge

[sɜːdʒ], [sɜːrdʒ]


Image Search
n. 汹涌；波涛；猛增
v. 汹涌；涌起；激增；[海]缆绳滑脱
a sudden powerful forward or upward movement, especially by a crowd or by a natural force such as the waves or tide.
a sudden large increase, typically a brief one that happens during an otherwise stable or quiescent period.
a major deployment of military forces to reinforce those already in a particular area.
a powerful rush of an emotion or feeling.
a sudden marked increase in voltage or current in an electric circuit.
(of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
increase suddenly and powerfully, typically during an otherwise stable or quiescent period.
(of an emotion or feeling) affect someone powerfully and suddenly.
(of an electric voltage or current) increase suddenly.
(of a rope, chain, or windlass) slip back with a jerk.
"flooding caused by tidal surges"
"the firm predicted a 20% surge in sales"
"Sophie felt a surge of anger"
"the journalists surged forward"
"shares surged to a record high"
"indignation surged up within her"
A surge of demonstrators broke through the fence.汹涌而来的示威者冲破了围栏。
The great surge had built up in the Gulf Stream.汹涌的巨浪在墨西哥湾流形成了。
Oil was the prime cause of the price surge.石油是物价上涨的主要原因。
The tides surged over the rocks.潮水奔腾着涌过礁石。
The crowd surged past him.人们从他身边涌过。
Anger surged up within him.怒火在他心中燃烧。
The value of exports surged last year.去年出口值激增。

surpass

[sə'pɑːs], [sər'pæs]


Image Search
vt. 超越；胜过
exceed; be greater than.
be better than.
do or be better than ever before.
"prewar levels of production were surpassed in 1929"
"he continued to surpass me at all games"
"the organist was surpassing himself"
To be in love is to surpass oneself.人在爱中超越自我。
You seem to surpass yourself in this painting.你在这幅画的创作上似乎超越了你自己。
Her sweetness nothing can surpass.温柔甜蜜世无双。
It is hard to surpass Evans in speed.要在速度上胜过艾文斯很难。

surreptitiously

[ˌsʌrəp'tɪʃəsli], [ˌsʌrəp'tɪʃəsli]


Image Search
adv. 偷偷摸摸地；暗中地
in a way that attempts to avoid notice or attention; secretively.
"Mary surreptitiously slipped from the room"
One time, my brother and I surreptitiously made gunpowder.有一次，我和我哥哥偷偷摸摸地制作了火药。

surrogate

['sʌrəɡət], ['sɜːrəɡət]


Image Search
n. 代理人；代用品；代孕者
adj. 替代的
a substitute, especially a person deputizing for another in a specific role or office.
(in the Christian Church) a bishop's deputy who grants marriage licenses.
a judge in charge of probate, inheritance, and guardianship.
"she was regarded as the surrogate for the governor during his final illness"
I do not know if your company has surrogate in our country.我不知道贵公司在我国是否有代理。
In addition, the patient or surrogate may correct any historical misinformation at this time.病人或代诉者还可在此时纠正病史中的一些错误信息。
Fiction is a poor surrogate for real experience.小说中的事远逊于实际体验。
The youngest child of Michael Jackson was borned by a surrogate.迈克尔杰克逊最小的孩子是由一位代孕母亲所生的。
She saw him as a sort of surrogate father.在她心目中，他仿佛是能替代父亲角色的人。

swindle

['swɪndl], ['swɪndl]


Image Search
v. 诈骗；骗取
n. 诈取；骗局
use deception to deprive (someone) of money or possessions.
obtain (money) fraudulently.
a fraudulent scheme or action.
"a businessman swindled investors out of millions of dollars"
"he was said to have swindled $62.5 million from the pension fund"
"he is mixed up in a $10 million insurance swindle"
He tried to swindle the insurance company.他企图诈骗保险公司。
Honest merchants do not swindle their customers.诚实的商人不欺骗他们的顾客。
The gang swindle the bank out of $1.5m.该团伙骗走银行150万美元。
I got bitten in a mail order swindle.我在一次邮购诈欺中受骗了。
The big bank swindle involved a lot of people.许多人与这起诈骗银行的大案有牵连。
It is nothing more or less than a swindle.这完完全全是一个骗局。

swoop

[swuːp], [swuːp]


Image Search
v. 抓取；猛扑；突然袭击
n. 俯冲；攫取；突然袭击
(especially of a bird) move rapidly downward through the air.
carry out a sudden attack, especially in order to make a capture or arrest.
seize with a sweeping motion.
a swooping or snatching movement or action.
"the barn owl can swoop down on a mouse in total darkness"
"investigators swooped on the Graf family home"
"she swooped up the hen in her arms"
"four members were arrested following a swoop by detectives on their homes"
The robber swooped up the banknotes.劫匪把钞票一把抢走了。
The eagle poised in mid-air ready to swoop on its prey.那鹰在半空中盘旋准备扑向猎物。
The owl swooped down on the mouse.那只猫头鹰向着老鼠猛扑下来。
We decided to swoop down upon the enemy there.我们决定突袭驻在那里的敌人。
The plane made a swoop over the city.那架飞机突然向这座城市猛降下来。
Police made a dawn swoop.警方于拂晓时发动了突袭。

syncope

['sɪŋkəpi], ['sɪŋkəpi]


Image Search
n. [语]字中音省略；中略；[医]昏厥
temporary loss of consciousness caused by a fall in blood pressure.
the omission of sounds or letters from within a word, e.g., when probably is pronounced ˈpräblē.
Can you give me some medicine to calm the syncope down?你有什么药能治我这晕厥病吗?

[sɪ'nɒpsɪs], [sɪ'nɑːpsɪs]


Image Search

a brief summary or general survey of something.
an outline of the plot of a book, play, movie, or episode of a television show.
"a synopsis of the accident"
He just wants the synopsis and the list of options.他只想要选项的摘要和列表。
The synopsis of the book is very good.这本书的梗概非常好。
Biographies, filmographies and synopsis can also be sent on a separate sheet.您也可以将个人简介、电影作品目录及参赛作品介绍作为附件寄来。

tacky

['tæki], ['tæki]


Image Search
adj. 发粘的；俗气的；破烂的
(of glue, paint, or other substances) retaining a slightly sticky feel; not fully dry.
showing poor taste and quality.
"the paint was still tacky"
"even in her faintly tacky costumes, she won our hearts"
The paint is still tacky so don't touch it.油漆未干，切勿碰摸。
The solution must be allowed to become tacky.必须让胶水发粘。
She looks really tacky in that dress.她穿那件衣服看起来俗不可耐。
This is sort of tacky gift for a birthday.这个生日礼物有点俗气。
The tacky tractor trailers trucks.破烂的拖拉机是用来拖卡车的。

A minister of foreign affairs has to have tact.外交部长必须机智老练。

tally

['tæli], ['tæli]


Image Search
n. 帐；记分；一致；标签
vt. 计算；记录；使一致
vi. 计算；记分；一致
a current score or amount.
a record of a score or amount.
a particular number taken as a group or unit to facilitate counting.
a mark registering a number or amount.
a piece of wood scored across with notches for the items of an account and then split into halves, each party keeping one.
an account kept on a tally stick.
a counterpart or duplicate of something.
a label attached to a plant or tree, or stuck in the ground beside it, that gives information about it, such as its name and class.
agree or correspond.
calculate the total number of.
"that takes his tally to 10 goals in 10 games"
"I kept a running tally of David's debt on a note above my desk"
"their signatures should tally with their names on the register"
"the votes were being tallied with abacuses"
Don't forget to keep a careful tally of what you spend.别忘了仔细记下你的开支帐目。
You can buy on tally in this shop.在这家商店里可以赊购。
He added to his tally in the last minute.他在比赛最后一分钟又得了分。
All the figures tally with the projected total.合计和预算的总额一致。
What you are now doing does not quite tally with your statement.你现在的所作所为与你声称的不大一致。
The tally of computation and observation is in a good agreement.将计算值与实测资料比较，结果表明符合程度良好。
When the votes were counted, they fell short of the tally needed for a non-binding resolution rejecting a troop buildup.当计算票数时，其议员感觉在对于无须遵守的表决抵制集结军队的一项缺少纪录。
Our team tallied three runs in that inning.我队在那一局中得三分。
The tally of computation and observation is in a good agreement.将计算值与实测资料比较，结果表明符合程度良好。
When the votes were counted, they fell short of the tally needed for a non-binding resolution rejecting a troop buildup.当计算票数时，其议员感觉在对于无须遵守的表决抵制集结军队的一项缺少纪录。
The two lists do not tally.这两张单子不相符。
His account of the accident tallies with yours.他对该故事的说法和你一样。

tangible

['tændʒəbl], ['tændʒəbl]


Image Search
adj. 可触摸的；实际的；有形的；确凿的
perceptible by touch.
clear and definite; real.
a thing that is perceptible by touch.
"the atmosphere of neglect and abandonment was almost tangible"
"the emphasis is now on tangible results"
It is the only tangible object the astronomer can handle.这是天文学家能够掌握的唯一可接触的对象。
The tension between them was almost tangible.他们之间的紧张关系几乎让人都感觉得出来。
The plan brought few tangible benefits to the poor.这个计划没有给穷人带来多少实际好处。
Fossils give us tangible evidence that dinosaurs really existed.化石给了我们恐龙确实存在的确切证据。

taper

['teɪpə(r)], ['teɪpər]


Image Search
n. 小蜡烛；蜡芯；尖锥形；渐弱
v. 逐渐变小；逐渐消失
adj. 尖细的；划分等级的
diminish or reduce or cause to diminish or reduce in thickness toward one end.
gradually lessen.
a slender candle.
a wick coated with wax, used for conveying a flame.
a gradual narrowing.
a gradual or incremental reduction.
"the tail tapers to a rounded tip"
"the impact of the dollar's depreciation started to taper off"
"the current industry standard taper of 5 degrees"
"with the taper in training, athletes can feel less hungry"
They had red tapers on the table at Christmastime.在圣诞节期间他们在桌子上点红色的细蜡烛。
Financial aids generally taper off after the first year of college.助学金通常在大学一年级之后逐渐减少。
Taper the plug off a bit with the chisel so that it will fit into the hole.用凿子把塞子的一头削掉一点，使它能塞进洞里。
The storm is beginning to taper off now.风暴现在逐渐减弱了。

taro

['tɑːrəʊ], ['tɑːroʊ]


Image Search
n. 芋头
a tropical Asian plant of the arum family that has edible starchy corms and edible fleshy leaves, especially a variety with a large central corm grown as a staple in the Pacific.
the corm of the taro plant.
They were the first people to cultivate taro.他们是最先开始种植芋头的人。
Taro is a tropical plant used widely in the Pacific Islands.芋头是太平洋群岛普遍食用的热带植物。

tarry

['tæri], ['tæri]


Image Search
v. 耽搁；逗留
adj. 用柏油覆盖的
of, like, or covered with tar.
stay longer than intended; delay leaving a place.
"a length of tarry rope"
"she could tarry a bit and not get home until four"
Then open the door, and flee, and tarry not.说完了，就开门逃跑，不要迟延。
Why did he tarry so long on his way?他为什么在途中耽搁了那么久?
He tarried for a few days in my house.他在我家里小住了几天。
Tarry awhile at this charming country inn.在这个可爱的乡村小酒馆里呆一会儿吧。
This road needs to be tarry so that it can last longer.这条路需要用柏油覆盖才能用更长的时间。

an open pastry case containing a filling.
a woman who dresses or behaves in a way that is considered tasteless and sexually provocative.
a prostitute.

decorate or improve the appearance of something.
sharp or acid in taste.

"the tarts were touting for trade"
"the page layouts have been tarted up with cartoons"
"a tart apple"
"I bit back a tart reply"
She replied, speaking for the first time, in her usual tart and offhand way.于是她开口回答了，用她平常那种尖酸刻薄的声调随口说道。
She popped the tart into the oven.她把果馅饼很快地放进烤箱里。

task

[tɑːsk], [tæsk]


Image Search
n. 任务；工作
vt. 交给某人（任务)；使做艰苦的工作
a piece of work to be done or undertaken.
assign a piece of work to.
make great demands on (someone's resources or abilities).
"NATO troops are tasked with separating the warring parties"
"it tasked his diplomatic skill to effect his departure in safety"
It's an arduous task.这是一项艰巨的任务。
It is an irksome task.那是件令人厌烦的工作。
Her work is a laborious task.她的工作很艰苦。
This is a task well within your ability.这完全是你力所能及的工作。
We should devote all our efforts to task.我们应该全力以赴地工作。

taskmaster

['tɑːskmɑːstə(r)], ['tæskmæstər]


Image Search
n. 工头(监工)；严厉的主人、师父或教师
a person who imposes a harsh or onerous workload on someone.
The profession of medicine is a stern taskmaster. 医生这个职业总要求其从事者承担繁重的任务
You are now halfway through this taskmaster's visit to your sign. 经由这个监工对你宫位的拜访，你正处于中间状态。
I see the evil taskmaster with arms crossed and foot tapping. 我甚至能看到那邪恶的工头站在面前，双臂交叉，脚尖打着拍子。
Captives are altogether at ease; They do not hear the voice of the taskmaster. 18被囚的人同得安逸，听不见督工的声音。
When I was in the Army, Lt. Surge was my strict CO. He was a hard taskmaster . 当我在军中的时候;马志士上尉是我严格的指挥官;他可是一个严厉的上司.
She was such a taskmaster when we worked together on a group project. 我们一起做项目的时候，她对我们的要求非常严格。

taunt

[tɔːnt], [tɔːnt]


Image Search
n. 辱骂；嘲弄
v. 嘲弄
a remark made in order to anger, wound, or provoke someone.
provoke or challenge (someone) with insulting remarks.
reproach (someone) with something in a contemptuous way.
"students began taunting her about her weight"
"she had taunted him with going to another man"
His genial sufficiency was a taunt and a mockery to many.他那么和蔼自满的态度，许多人都认为是一种辱骂和嘲弄。
But in England if the palm faces inward it's a taunt, especially if executed with an up-ward jerk of the fingers.可在英国，做该手势时如果掌心向内，特别是还同时把手指往上伸的话，则表示对人的辱骂。
He will taunt an opponent endlessly, even during battle, raising their ire until they make a fatal mistake - and then take advantage of them.即使在战斗中，他也会无休止的嘲弄对手，激起他们的怒气直到他们犯下致命错误，然后他就会取得优势。

taut

[tɔːt], [tɔːt]


Image Search
adj. 拉紧的；绷紧的；紧张的；整洁的
stretched or pulled tight; not slack.
(especially of muscles or nerves) tense; not relaxed.
(of writing, music, etc.) concise and controlled.
(of a ship) having a disciplined and efficient crew.
"the fabric stays taut without adhesive"
"a taut text of only a hundred and twenty pages"
If a bow-string is too taut, it will snap.拉得太紧，弓弦就会断。
The lovely mouth was taut with irony.漂亮的嘴讥讽地绷紧着。
He had a taut expression on his face, apparently very angry.他脸紧绷绷的，像很生气的样子。
As she rubbed those taut muscles, she hummed and prayed.她一边蹭着紧张的肌肉，一边嘟嘟囔囔地祈祷着。
He waved his arm at the taut wire of the horizon.他挥臂指向笔直的地平线。

teal

[tiːl], [tiːl]


Image Search
n. 蓝绿色；水鸭
adj. 蓝绿色的
a small freshwater duck, typically with a greenish band on the wing that is most prominent in flight.
a dark greenish-blue color.
For example, the color may be aqua, teal, or green.例如,颜色可以是浅绿、蓝绿色,或者绿色。
This would moisten a bit of the exposed lake bed and provide an emergency stopover for the enormous flocks of geese, avocets, grebes and teal that visit the Salton Sea.这可以使裸露的河床潮湿一点，给鹅群，长嘴鸟，水鸟没，野鸭等提供暂时在索尔顿湖的栖息之地。
I was shocked and saw the sky quickly, and there was a teal fireball past slowly.我吓了一跳迅速往天空看，看到一枚蓝绿色的光球缓慢的划过。

telco

['telkəʊ], ['telkoʊ]


Image Search
n. 电话公司
a telecommunications company.
Our training courses are targeted for IT and Telco professionals. 我们的培训课程是以IT与电信业专业人士为定位的。
The Internet is rapidly replacing the telco's own network. 网络正迅速地替换网络供应商自己的网络。
Vacuum tube amplifiers used the first time in coast-to-coast telco circuits. 真空管放大器首次用于大西洋岸至太平洋岸的电信电路中。
The new company you will join is a Telco giant with solid reputation. 你要加盟的新公司是声誉显赫的电信业巨臂。
Proctor Test Set is a tool used by Telco personnel to diagnose problems with phone lines. 代理测试集是电讯工作人员用来检测电话线路问题的一种工具。
Confirming Design Layout Report Date. The date a common carrier accepts the facility designed proposed by the Telco. 确认设计布局报告日期。公用电信公司接受电信公司提议设计的设备的日期。

template

['templeɪt], ['templeɪt]


Image Search
n. 样板；模板
a shaped piece of metal, wood, card, plastic, or other material used as a pattern for processes such as painting, cutting out, shaping, or drilling.
something that serves as a model for others to copy.
a preset format for a document or file, used so that the format does not have to be recreated each time it is used.
a nucleic acid molecule that acts as a pattern for the sequence of assembly of a protein, nucleic acid, or other large molecule.
a timber or plate used to distribute the weight in a wall or under a support.
"the plant was to serve as the template for change throughout the company"
"a memo template"
This template allows for slight song variations.这个样板可以允许歌声稍有变化。
The French Revolution was the template for all the future revolutions.法国革命是后来所有革命的样板。
Save the active document or template with its current name.以其目前的名字保存当前的文件或模板。
A template is like an online blank form.模板类似于一份联机空白表格。

tenable

['tenəbl], ['tenəbl]


Image Search
adj. 站得住脚的；无懈可击的
able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
(of an office, position, scholarship, etc.) able to be held or used.
"such a simplistic approach is no longer tenable"
"the post is tenable for three years"
None of these arguments are tenable.这些论点没有一个是站得住脚的。
The lectureship is tenable for a period of three years.讲师这一职位任期三年。
In a word, our theory is tenable.综上所述，我们的理论成立。

tenacious

[tə'neɪʃəs], [tə'neɪʃəs]


Image Search
adj. 抓紧的；坚决的；(记忆力)强的
tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
not readily relinquishing a position, principle, or course of action; determined.
persisting in existence; not easily dispelled.
"a tenacious grip"
"you're tenacious and you get at the truth"
"a tenacious local legend"
He hold on to my arm with a tenacious grip.他紧紧抓住我的手臂不放。
The eagle seized its prey in a tenacious grip.鹰将捕获物紧紧抓住。
She is tenacious in defence of her rights.她坚决维护自己的权利.
He is tenacious of his opinions.他固执己见。

tend

[tend], [tend]


Image Search
v. 趋向；易于；朝向
v. 照料；照管
regularly or frequently behave in a particular way or have a certain characteristic.
be liable to possess or display (a particular characteristic).
go or move in a particular direction.
approach (a quantity or limit).
care for or look after; give one's attention to.
direct or manage; work in.
wait on as an attendant or servant.
"written language tends to be formal"
"Walter tended toward corpulence"
"the road tends west around small mountains"
"the Fourier coefficients tend to zero"
"Viola tended plants on the roof"
"I've been tending bar at the airport lounge"
Weeds tend to displace other plants.杂草越来越多，有取代其他植物之势。
During the interview, some interviewees tend to exaggerate.面试时,有些面试者会有夸大的倾向。
He's a good salesman, but his offhand manner does tend to put people off.他是个很好的推销员，可是他那随便的态度容易使人产生反感。
Prices are tending upward.物价在上涨。
Mother being ill, he had to tend her at home.母亲病了,他得在家照料她。
You'd better tend to your own affairs.你还是管好自己的事情吧!

tepid

['tepɪd], ['tepɪd]


Image Search
adj. 微温的；不热心的
(especially of a liquid) only slightly warm; lukewarm.
showing little enthusiasm.
"the applause was tepid"
Her feet firmly planted on the tepid rough brick of the floor.她一双脚稳固地立在微温而粗糙的砖地上。
The play was greeted with tepid applause.这台戏只得到了零落的掌声。
The critics's reaction to the film was rather tepid.评论家对那部影片的反映不太热烈。

terrain

[tə'reɪn], [tə'reɪn]


Image Search
n. 地带；地形
a stretch of land, especially with regard to its physical features.
variant form of terrane.
a fault-bounded area or region with a distinctive stratigraphy, structure, and geological history.
"they were delayed by rough terrain"
The car blitzed through rough terrain.这辆汽车长驱穿越了崎岖地带。
Valley glaciers are confined to valleys in mountainous terrain.山谷冰川只限于多山地带的山谷。
It's a difficult terrain for tanks.这是坦克作战的困难地形。
They stopped and began to reconnoitre the terrain.他们停下来，开始勘测地形。
The terrain in that part of the country is as falt as a board.这个国家有些地方的地形很平坦。

terse

Image Search
adj. 简洁的；简明的
sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
"a terse statement"
I admire his terse style of writing.我很欣赏他那简洁的写作风格。
Her reply about the matter was terse.她对此事的答复简明扼要。

testimonial

[ˌtestɪ'məʊniəl], [ˌtestɪ'moʊniəl]


Image Search
n. 证明书；推荐书；奖品；感谢信
adj. 证明书的；表扬的
a formal statement testifying to someone's character and qualifications.
a public tribute to someone and to their achievements.
(in sports) a game or event held in honor of a player, who typically receives part of the income generated.
"the Yankees held a testimonial day for Gehrig"
He bears a testimonial as to his character.他带着一张他的品行证明书。
She sent a testimonial from her former employer when applying for the post.她申请那职位时寄去了前雇主的推荐书。
At the testimonial dinner everyone flattered him shamelessly .在庆祝获奖宴会上，每个人都对他进行无耻的奉承。

theory

['θɪəri], ['θɪri]


Image Search
n. 学说；理论；原理；意见
a supposition or a system of ideas intended to explain something, especially one based on general principles independent of the thing to be explained.
a set of principles on which the practice of an activity is based.
an idea used to account for a situation or justify a course of action.
a collection of propositions to illustrate the principles of a subject.
"Darwin's theory of evolution"
"a theory of education"
"my theory would be that the place has been seriously mismanaged"
There're many theories about the origin of life.关于生命起源的学说有很多。
In theory, anything could happen.理论上来说,任何事情都会发生。
Not everyone can understand Einstein's Theory of Relativity.不是每个人都能读懂爱因斯坦的相对论的。
In his book, he explained the operating theories of computer in detail.在他的书中,他详细阐述了计算机的工作原理。
Mary is full of fascinating theories about men and women.玛丽对男人和女人充满了迷人的想法。
She has a theory that drinking milk prevents cold.她有一种说法,认为喝牛奶能防止感冒。

thrifty

['θrɪfti], ['θrɪfti]


Image Search
adj. 节俭的；兴旺的；茁壮的
(of a person or their behavior) using money and other resources carefully and not wastefully.
(of livestock or plants) strong and healthy.
prosperous.
Her mother is a thrifty housewife.她妈妈是一个节俭的主妇。
Only very thrifty children manage to fill up a money-box.只有非常节俭的儿童才会设法填满一个储蓄罐。
Mr. Thompson is so thrifty that he is able to save more than half of his weekly salary.汤普森先生是如此节俭,以致他能省下超过一半的周薪。

thrive

[θraɪv], [θraɪv]


Image Search
vi. 兴旺；繁荣；茁壮成长
(of a child, animal, or plant) grow or develop well or vigorously.
prosper; flourish.
"the new baby thrived"
"education groups thrive on organization"
A business cannot thrive without good management.没有良好的经营管理，事业就不会兴旺发达。
But will they survive and thrive?但是，他们会生存下来并兴旺繁殖吗?
May our country prosper and thrive forever!希望我们的国家繁荣兴旺，长盛不衰。
A business can not thrive without investment.没有投资任何生意都无法繁荣。
Few plants or animals thrive in the desert.很少植物或动物能在沙漠中很好地生长。
Sheep do not thrive on long pasture.羊吃长草不能健壮。
Children thrive on fresh air and good food.儿童的健康成长需要有新鲜的空气和富有营养的食物。

thrombosis

[θrɒm'bəʊsɪs], [θrɑːm'boʊsɪs]


Image Search
n. [医]血栓形成；血栓症
local coagulation or clotting of the blood in a part of the circulatory system.
"increased risk of thrombosis"
Thrombosis may occur as early as the first day after cannulation.血栓形成可早在置管后第一天发生。

thwart

[θwɔːt], [θwɔːrt]


Image Search
v. 反对；阻碍
n. 座板
adv. 横过
adj. 横向的
prevent (someone) from accomplishing something.
oppose (a plan, attempt, or ambition) successfully.
a structural crosspiece sometimes forming a seat for a rower in a boat.
from one side to another side of; across.
"he never did anything to thwart his father"
"the government had been able to thwart all attempts by opposition leaders to form new parties"
"a pink-tinged cloud spread thwart the shore"
She intends to thwart his plans, and be revenged on him.她要破坏他的计划，以图报复。
Sometimes it isn't you I hate but your power to thwart me.有时让我讨厌的并不是你，而是你阻挠我的能力。
I don't think that will thwart our purposes.我认为那不会使我们的目的受到挫折。
Our course must thwart those designs.我们的方针是必须挫败他们这种企图。
He made the fish fast to bow and stern and to the middle thwart.他把绑鱼的绳子系在船头、船梢的中间的座板上。

timid

['tɪmɪd], ['tɪmɪd]


Image Search
adj. 胆怯的；害羞的
showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened.
"I was too timid to ask for what I wanted"
They taunted him for being timid.他们讥笑他胆小。
He is as timid as a sheep.他像绵羊一样怯懦。
The least noise would startle the timid child.最小的响声也会吓着这个胆小的孩子的。
He is a timid boy; it's impossible for him to brawl with anyone.他是一个胆小的男孩，他不可能和任何人吵架。
She was too timid to talk with other travelers.她很害羞，不敢和其他旅行者交谈。
She is a timid cat.她是个腼腆的女人。
I wanted to take him fishing but I was too timid to ask him.我曾想带他去钓鱼，但我不好意思对他开口。

tint

[tɪnt], [tɪnt]


Image Search
n. 色彩； 浅色； 染发剂
vt. 给 ... 染色
a shade or variety of color.
an area of faint even color printed as a halftone, used for highlighting overprinted text.
a set of parallel engraved lines to give uniform shading.
a trace of something.
an artificial dye for coloring the hair.
an application of hair dye.
color (something) slightly; tinge.
dye (someone's hair) with a tint.
"the sky was taking on an apricot tint"
"a tint of glamour"
"peering into the mirror to see if any white hair showed after her last tint"
"her skin was tinted with delicate color"
Tint leaves the footage colors but wipes out darks.著色使得画面的色彩，但清除掉深色衣物。
Today salt-loving bacteria thrive in brine pools on the dry lake bed, lending a blood-red tint in this aerial view.如今，喜爱盐分的宅细菌在干涸湖床上的咸水池里繁茂生长，使得这幅空拍画面带着血红的色彩。
She gave me instructions on how to apply the tint.她告诉我如何使用染发剂。

tiresome

['taɪəsəm], ['taɪərsəm]


Image Search
adj. 令人厌倦的；讨厌的
causing one to feel bored or annoyed.
"weeding is a tiresome but essential job"
I had planned to go to your party, but you know I had to finish that tiresome paper.我原本打算去参加你的晚会，可你知道我还得完成那令人厌倦的考卷。
His speech is really tiresome.他的演讲实在令人厌倦。
Deliver me from such tiresome people.让我离开这些讨厌的人们吧。
He can be a very tiresome child at times.他有时候会是一个非常讨厌的孩子。

toil

[tɔɪl], [tɔɪl]


Image Search
n. 辛苦；苦工；罗网；圈套
v. 费力地做；苦干；跋涉
work extremely hard or incessantly.
move slowly and with difficulty.
exhausting physical labor.
"we toiled away"
"she began to toil up the cliff path"
"a life of toil"
We were quite exhausted with the toil.我们因那件辛苦的工作而感到十分疲惫。
Every grain of it comes from hard toil.粒粒皆辛苦。
Thus his youth had been spent in rude and ill-paid toil.他的青年时期便是那样在干着报酬微薄的辛苦工作中消磨过去的。
He was destined to plod the path of toil.他注定要在艰辛的道路上跋涉。
She was caught in the toils of despair.她陷于绝境。
The thief was caught in the toils of the law.窃贼落入了法网。
I shall have to toil and moil all my days.我必须一年到头拼命地干。
We toil away all afternoon to get the house ready for our guest.我们忙了一下午收拾房子准备迎接宾客。
The slaves toiled up the hill pulling the heavy blocks.那些奴隶艰难地把沉重的石块拖上山。

topple

['tɒpl], ['tɑːpl]


Image Search
vt. 使倒塌；推翻
vi. 倒塌
overbalance or become unsteady and fall slowly.
cause to become unsteady and fall.
"she toppled over when I touched her"
"the push almost toppled him to the ground"
The explosion toppled the near chimney.这次爆炸把不远处的烟筒炸倒了。
He toppled his opponent.他摔倒对方。
This scandal may topple the government.这桩丑闻有可能使政府垮台。
The pile of books toppled over onto the floor.那一摞书倒在地上了。
That Building is going to topple down.那幢建筑物摇摇欲坠。

torment

['tɔːment], ['tɔːrment]


Image Search

annoy or provoke in a deliberately unkind way.
"their deaths have left both families in torment"
"the journey must have been a torment for them"
"he was tormented by jealousy"
"every day I have kids tormenting me because they know I live alone"
He was in torment after the operation.手术后他非常痛苦。
That child is a torment to his parents.这孩子对他的父母是一种折磨。
He suffered a hideous torment when the enemy caught him.敌人抓到他后，他受到可怕的折磨。
What a little torment that child is!这孩子真烦人！
She torments everyone with silly questions.她用无聊的问题来烦扰大家。
Seth was tormented by feelings of guilt.内疚之感折磨着塞斯。

tout

[taʊt], [taʊt]


Image Search
v. 兜售；高价卖；刺探；吹捧
n. 贩子

scalp (a ticket).
offer racing tips for a share of any resulting winnings.
spy out the movements and condition of (a racehorse in training) in order to gain information to be used when betting.
a person soliciting custom or business, typically in an aggressive or bold manner.
a person who buys tickets for an event to resell them at a profit; a scalper.
a person who offers racing tips for a share of any resulting winnings.
an informer.
used before the name of a city to refer to its high society or people of importance.
"Jim was touting his wares"
"the headquarters facility was touted as the best in the country"
"le tout Washington adored him"
We should tout our wares on television.我们应该在电视上兜售商品。
Toyota Motor Corp., Nissan Motor Co. and Honda Motor Co. will tout their latest models at the Beijing car show tomorrow.日本丰田、本田和日产汽车公司在昨日开幕的北京国际车展上极力推介自己的新产品。
The politician was touted as a friend of people.这个政客被吹捧为人民之友。

tragedy

['trædʒədi], ['trædʒədi]


Image Search
n. 悲剧；灾难；惨事
an event causing great suffering, destruction, and distress, such as a serious accident, crime, or natural catastrophe.
a play dealing with tragic events and having an unhappy ending, especially one concerning the downfall of the main character.
the dramatic genre represented by tragedy.
"a tragedy that killed 95 people"
"Greek tragedy"
Tragedy is in store for that poor girl from the beginning.从一开始，那个女孩的悲剧就是不可避免的。
Shakespeare's Hamlet is a very famous tragedy.莎士比亚的《哈姆雷特》是一部十分著名的悲剧。
It was not long before tragedy struck again.没多久，灾难又再次降临。
This recent tragedy has put the manufacturersof the drug squarely in the dock.新近发生的这一悲惨事件使药品厂商受到指控。
It was a tragedy that she died so young.她这么年轻就去世，真是太不幸了。

tragic

['trædʒɪk], ['trædʒɪk]


Image Search
adj. 悲剧的；悲惨的
causing or characterized by extreme distress or sorrow.
suffering extreme distress or sorrow.
very bad or inadeqate.
relating to tragedy in a literary work.
"the shooting was a tragic accident"
"the tragic parents reached the end of their tether"
"on the other hand, I like degenerate, tragic food"
This delay was to have tragic results.这样的延误即将导致悲剧的结局。
I don't like the tragic ending of the film.我不喜欢电影悲剧的结尾。
Her tragic story touched us all deeply/touched our hearts with sorrow.她的经历很悲惨，我们都深受感动[我们都很伤心]。
She listened to the tragic news ashen-faced.她听到这一悲惨消息，脸都白了。
The university was shocked at the tragic incident.大学人员都被这场悲惨的事故震惊了。

Image Search

a genetically determined characteristic.
"he was a letter-of-the-law man, a common trait among coaches"
They suddenly exhibit a striking new trait.它们突然呈现出一种新的显著特征。
One of his less attractive traits is criticizing his wife in public.他有个不大讨人喜欢的特点，就是爱当众责备妻子。
Our CEO talks and behaves without a trait of authority.我们公司的首席执行官言行举止没有一点官气。

transform

[træns'fɔːm], [træns'fɔːm]


Image Search

vi. 改变；变形；变态
make a thorough or dramatic change in the form, appearance, or character of.

the product of a transformation.
a rule for making a transformation.
"lasers have transformed cardiac surgery"
"an automobile that transformed into a boat"
She is responsible for the character part of the hero's devoted mother.她负责这个主人公的忠诚的母亲的角色部分。
The magician transformed the frog into a princess.魔术师把青蛙变成了公主。
His plans were transformed overnight into reality.他的计划迅速变为现实。
We should try to transform heat into power.我们应该设法将热转化为能量。
I believe she would transform me into a talker.我相信，她会把我这个沉默寡言的人变成个碎嘴子。

"there is no excuse for trespassing on railroad property"

"a man who had trespassed against Judaic law"
"the defendants were guilty of trespass"
"the worst trespass against the goddess Venus is to see her naked and asleep"
They forgive the people who trespass against them.他们总是宽恕冒犯他们的人。

trifle

['traɪfl], ['traɪfl]


Image Search
n. 琐事；少量
v. 浪费；玩弄
a thing of little value or importance.
a small amount of something.
a cold dessert of sponge cake and fruit covered with layers of custard, jelly, and cream.
treat (someone or something) without seriousness or respect.
talk or act frivolously.
waste something, especially time, frivolously.
"we needn't trouble the headmaster over such trifles"
"the thousand yen he'd paid seemed the merest trifle"
"he is not a man to be trifled with"
"we will not trifle—life is too short"
I do not want to make a fuss over such a trifle.我不想为这种小事大惊小怪。
They had an altercation about a trifle.他们为一点小事争吵起来。
He told her not to pester him with trifles.他告诉她别拿些琐事来烦他。
I have only a trifle of wine left.我只剩下一点点酒了。
I'll have just a trifle of the dessert.我只要吃少量的甜点心。
Don't trifle away your time on curio hunting.别把时间都浪费在搜集古玩上面。
Don't trifle with serious matter.对大事不可儿戏。
Never trifle with other's affections.不要玩弄别人的感情。
It's dangerous to trifle with such a fierce animal.逗弄如此凶残的动物是很危险的。

trite

[traɪt], [traɪt]


Image Search
adj. 平庸的；陈腐的
(of a remark, opinion, or idea) overused and consequently of little import; lacking originality or freshness.
"this point may now seem obvious and trite"
For the rest, she was a strong-minded woman; never said a weak or a trite thing.此外，她还是个意志坚强的女人，从来不说一句示弱或者平庸的话。
He ended his lecture with a trite morality.他以陈腐的说教结束了演讲。

trove

[trəʊv], [troʊv]


Image Search
n. 贵重发现物；珍藏品

"the museum's trove of antique treasure"
He assembled a rich trove of Chinese porcelain.他收集了一批中国瓷器。
Mogao Grottoes is a veritable treasure trove of cultural relics.莫高窟还是一座名副其实的文物宝库。
Somewhere in the BBC archives, there is a treasure trove of cricket history for future reference.在英国广播公司档案馆的一处，有些可供今后参考的珍贵的板球史料。
The center housed a priceless treasure trove.该中心存放着一件无价之宝。
The gallery is a treasure trove of medieval art.这个画廊是中世纪艺术的宝库。

turbid

['tɜːbɪd], ['tɜːrbɪd]


Image Search
adj. 混浊的；泥水的；浓密的
(of a liquid) cloudy, opaque, or thick with suspended matter.
confused or obscure in meaning or effect.
"the turbid estuary"
"a turbid piece of cinéma vérité"
Flushed by a clear stream, the turbid water was being diluted and squeezed out.在一股清流的冲击下，杯子里的浑水不断地被稀释、充溢了出来。
The turbid yellow river water fiercely reflected the blazing sun of the plateau.那浑黄的河水在高原阳光的曝晒下，反射着强烈的光。

Image Search

a bright yellow aromatic powder obtained from the rhizome of a plant of the ginger family, used for flavoring and coloring in Asian cooking and formerly as a fabric dye.
the Asian plant from which turmeric is obtained.
Turmeric has been used for thousands of years.姜黄已经被使用了数千年。

the European plant of the cabbage family that produces the turnip.
a large, thick, old-fashioned pocket watch.
My nephew loves to eat raw turnip.我的侄子喜欢生吃萝卜。
She was very surprised to see the turnip.牠很惊讶的看到了萝卜，
Would you like some turnip?吃点芜菁吗？

tussle

['tʌsl], ['tʌsl]


Image Search

"there was a tussle for the ball"
"the demonstrators tussled with police"
I had a tussle to get the knife off him.我与他扭打一阵才把刀子夺下。
We have a tussle every year about where to go on holiday.我们每年都要为前往何处度假而争论一番.
They began to tussle with each other for the coin.他们为争夺硬币扭打起来。
The children were tussling with one another for the ball.孩子们在你抢我夺地争球。

ultimate

['ʌltɪmət], ['ʌltɪmət]


Image Search
adj. 根本的；极限的；最后的；终极的
n. 终极；极品；根本
being or happening at the end of a process; final.
being the best or most extreme example of its kind.
basic or fundamental.
denoting the maximum possible strength or resistance beyond which an object breaks.
the best achievable or imaginable of its kind.
a final or fundamental fact or principle.
short for Ultimate Frisbee.
"their ultimate aim was to force his resignation"
"the ultimate accolade"
"the ultimate constituents of anything that exists are atoms"
"the ultimate in decorative luxury"
Hard work is the ultimate source of success.努力工作是成功之本。
This had been an ultimate issue.这个问题是个原则性的问题。
GUPTA And the Ironman is the ultimate competition.甘普塔铁人是一个极限的竞争。
I believe that I will bring my ultimate competitiveness in the advanced business management into full play with the guidance of professional teachers.我认为在精英的师资力量的指导下我将在高级商业管理方面发挥我极限的竞争力。
The British made the ultimate triumph.英国人取得了最后的胜利。
Our ultimate objective is the removal of all nuclear weapons.我们的最终目标是消除所有核武器。
Nuclear weapons are the ultimate deterrent.核武器是终极的威慑力量。
Such behavior is the ultimate in idiocy.这样的行为愚蠢透顶。
These ceramic tiles are the ultimate in modern kitchen design.这种瓷砖是现代厨房装修中的极品。
The crew is always the ultimate factor in the boat.船员一直是船上的根本因素。
The ultimate source of these rollercoaster movements was the Asian savings surplus.导致这类剧烈波动的最根本原因是亚洲的储蓄过剩。

uncouth

[ʌn'kuːθ], [ʌn'kuːθ]


Image Search
adj. 粗俗的；笨拙的；无教养的
(of a person or their appearance or behavior) lacking good manners, refinement, or grace.
(especially of art or language) lacking sophistication or delicacy.
(of a place) uncomfortable, especially because of remoteness or poor conditions.
"he is unwashed, uncouth, and drunk most of the time"
"uncouth sketches of peasants"
His nephew is an uncouth young man.他的侄子是一个粗野的年轻人。
He behaves in a most uncouth way.他的举止真是笨拙。
She may embarrass you with her uncouth behavior.她的粗野行为可能会让你尴尬。

underestimate

[ˌʌndər'estɪmeɪt], [ˌʌndər'estɪmeɪt]


Image Search
n. 低估
v. 低估
estimate (something) to be smaller or less important than it actually is.
regard (someone) as less capable than they really are.
an estimate that is too low.
"the administration has grossly underestimated the extent of the problem"
"he had underestimated the new president"
The figure of $10 million was a serious underestimate.一千万美元这个数据是一个严重的低估。
It seems to have been due to his consistent underestimate of her political weight.看来是由于希思一贯低估她的政治能量。
Never underestimate the power of a woman.决不要低估妇女的力量。
Don't underestimate the difficulties of the work.不要低估了这项工作的艰巨性。
You shouldn't underestimate the risks of the enterprise.你不应低估这一计划的风险。

undermine

[ˌʌndə'maɪn], [ˌʌndər'maɪn]


Image Search
vt. 逐渐削弱；暗中损害；在...下挖；从根基处损害
erode the base or foundation of (a rock formation).
dig or excavate beneath (a building or fortification) so as to make it collapse.
damage or weaken (someone or something), especially gradually or insidiously.
"this could undermine years of hard work"
They will do anything to undermine their adversary's reputation.他们会不择手段地去损害对手的名誉。
The President's enemies are spreading rumours to undermine his authority.总统的敌人在散布谣言以逐渐破坏他的威信。
Badgers had undermined the foundations of the church.獾在这座教堂的地基处打了洞。
A mole can undermine the strongest rampart.一只田鼠能毁坏最坚固的堡垒。

underscore

[ˌʌndə'skɔː(r)], [ˌʌndər'skɔːr]


Image Search
vt. 划线于；强调；提供伴奏乐
n. 下划线；影片伴奏乐
a line drawn under a word or phrase for emphasis.
(on a computer or typewriter keyboard) a short horizontal line (_) on the baseline.
underline (something).
emphasize.
"the company underscored the progress made with fuel cells"
Let me underscore two of many reasons for this concern.值得担忧的原因很多，让我着重说明其中两点。
Please underscore the word three times for emphasis.为了强调起见，请在该词下面划三条线。
Let me underscore that you should focus on an important problem.让我强调一下：你必须关注于某一重要问题。
These results underscore the importance of context in studies of social capital.这些结果强调了社会资本研究中环境的重要性。
They must begin with a letter or the underscore character开始部分必须为一个字母或是下划线

unerring

[ʌn'ɜːrɪŋ], [ʌn'ɜːrɪŋ]


Image Search
adj. 不犯错误的；一贯准确的；万无一失的
always right or accurate.
"an unerring sense of direction"
The antique dealer has an unerring ability to spot a fake.那古董商慧眼识珠，鉴别假货从不出错。
You can trust his unerring taste in cloths.你可以相信他的衣着品位，绝对没问题。
He had an unerring instinct for when people were lying to him.他具有准确的直觉，能判断别人什么时候是在说谎。
He have an unerring knack of saying the wrong thing.他有个出言必失的本事。

unfazed

[ʌn'feɪzd], [ʌn'feɪzd]


Image Search
adj. 无畏的；无顾虑的
not disconcerted or perturbed.
"the protestors were unfazed by the prospect of arrest"

unfortunately

[ʌn'fɔːtʃənətli], [ʌn'fɔːrtʃənətli]


Image Search
adv. 不幸地；遗憾地
it is unfortunate that.
"unfortunately, we do not have the time to interview every applicant"
Unfortunately, I missed the last train.我不幸错过了末班火车。
Unfortunately, I hurt my knee when I fell down on the ice.真不幸，我在冰上摔倒时摔伤了膝盖。
Unfortunately I am not aware of that.遗憾的是，我不知道此事。
Unfortunately, the restaurant he recommended fell far short of our expectations.遗憾的是,他推荐的餐厅与我们心目中的相去甚远。

ungainly

[ʌn'ɡeɪnli], [ʌn'ɡeɪnli]


Image Search
adj. 笨拙的；难看的；不雅的
(of a person or movement) awkward; clumsy.
"an ungainly walk"
He walked in long ungainly strides.他迈着笨拙的大步子行走。
I thought him terribly ungainly when he danced.我觉得他跳舞极其难看。

unique

[ju'niːk], [ju'niːk]


Image Search
adj. 独特的；独一无二的；稀罕的
being the only one of its kind; unlike anything else.
particularly remarkable, special, or unusual.
belonging or connected to (one particular person, group, or place).
a unique person or thing.
"the situation was unique in modern politics"
"a unique opportunity to see the spectacular Bolshoi Ballet"
"a style of architecture that is unique to Portugal"
He occupies a unique place in English literature.他在英国文学中占有独特的地位。
The elephant's trunk is a unique form of appendage.象的鼻子是一种独特的附肢。
It's a unique work of art.这是独一无二的艺术作品。
The custom is unique to the region.这种风俗是这一地区特有的。
Her style of writing is rather unique.她的写作风格很不寻常。

universal

[ˌjuːnɪ'vɜːsl], [ˌjuːnɪ'vɜːrsl]


Image Search
adj. 普遍的；全世界的；宇宙的；全体的；通用的
n. 通用原理，普遍原则
of, affecting, or done by all people or things in the world or in a particular group; applicable to all cases.
denoting a proposition in which something is asserted of all of a class.
denoting or relating to a grammatical rule, set of rules, or other linguistic feature that is found in all languages.
(of a tool or machine) adjustable to or appropriate for all requirements; not restricted to a single purpose or position.
a person or thing having universal effect, currency, or application, in particular.
a universal proposition.
a term or concept of general application.
a nature or essence signified by a general term.
a universal grammatical rule or linguistic feature.
"universal adult suffrage"
These phenomena is very universal.这些现象己经非常普遍了。
Overpopulation is a universal problem.人口过多是全球性的问题。
Music has been called the universal language.人们称音乐为世界的语言。
The doer is a universal structure.行事者是一个宇宙的结构。
A universal theory cannot be induced from a finite number of facts.一项宇宙的学说不能从有限数目的事实归纳而得。
Americans strongly favour the introduction of universal health care.美国人强烈赞同推行覆盖全体国民的医保制度。
Therefore any attempt at a universal tool set also proves futile.因此,任何建立一个通用工具集的尝试被认为是徒劳的。
There are no economic universals.英语是一种世界通用的语言。

unruly

[ʌn'ruːli], [ʌn'ruːli]


Image Search
adj. 难控制的；无法无天的；任性的
disorderly and disruptive and not amenable to discipline or control.
"complaints about unruly behavior"
They are unruly mob.他们是些难以控制的暴徒。
The unruly students mocked their teacher.这群无法无天的学生嘲笑老师。
The unruly crowd became even more boisterous when he tried to quiet them.他试图使那些横蛮任性的人们安静下来，可他们却吵嚷得更加厉害。

unscrupulous

[ʌn'skruːpjələs], [ʌn'skruːpjələs]


Image Search
adj. 肆无忌惮的；不道德的
having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.
You always take part with the unscrupulous man.你总是袒护那些肆无忌惮的人。
He once did me such an unscrupulous shot in the eye.他曾经如此肆无忌惮地恶意中伤过我。
He was utterly unscrupulous in his competition with rival firms.他与对立公司竞争完全不讲道德。

upheaval

[ʌp'hiːvl], [ʌp'hiːvl]


Image Search
n. 向上的运动；剧变；动乱
a violent or sudden change or disruption to something.
an upward displacement of part of the earth's crust.
"major upheavals in the financial markets"
The French Revolution was a volcanic upheaval in European history.法国大革命是欧洲历史上的一次剧变。
It was a terrible upheaval when his father died.他父亲去世时家里一团糟。
I can't face the upheaval of moving house again.我无法忍受再次搬家的折腾。
Many years ago, Johnson faced a major upheaval in his life.许多年前，约翰逊遭遇生命中的剧变。
A drastic interest-rate cut this week coincided with stockmarket upheaval.伴随着本周利率的大幅降低而来的是证券市场有力的反弹。
Mass unemployment may lead to social upheaval.大批失业会导致社会动乱。
It was a violent political upheaval.这是一场激烈的政治动乱。
The country has been thrown into an upheaval.这个国家已经陷入动乱之中。

uproot

[ˌʌp'ruːt], [ˌʌp'ruːt]


Image Search
vt. 连根拔起；迁离；根除
pull (something, especially a tree or plant) out of the ground.
eradicate; destroy.
move (someone) from their home or a familiar location.
"the elephant's trunk is powerful enough to uproot trees"
"a revolution is necessary to uproot the social order"
"my father traveled constantly and uprooted his family several times"
Whthin seconds a tornado can uproot trees.几秒钟内，龙卷风就能连根拔起大树。
The trunk of an elephant is powerful enough to uproot trees.大象的长鼻强壮得足以将树木连根拔起。
The family decided to uproot themselves and emigrate to Australia.他们全家决定离开故土，移居澳大利亚。
To take the new job he had to uproot his whole family and settled abroad.他为接受新的工作不得不举家迁居，在国外重新安家。
A bad habit once contracted takes a very long time to uproot (or root up).坏习惯一旦养成，需要很长的时间才能根除。
A bad habit once contracted takes a very long time to uproot.坏习惯一旦养成，需要很长的时间才能根除。

utilitarian

[ˌjuːtɪlɪ'teəriən], [ˌjuːtɪlɪ'teriən]


Image Search
adj. 功利的；实用的
n. 功利主义者
designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive.
relating to or adhering to the doctrine of utilitarianism.
an adherent of utilitarianism.
"a utilitarian theorist"
In the selection, he attempts to clarify the utilitarian standard.在这段选文中，他试图对功利标准作一清楚表述。
The buildings were utilitarian rather than decorative.这些建筑是实用性的，而不是装饰性的。
He is very down to earth and is a real utilitarian.他那个人很现实, 是个十足的功利主义者。

utilize

['juːtəlaɪz], ['juːtəlaɪz]


Image Search
vt. <美>利用或使用
=utilise（英）
make practical and effective use of.
"vitamin C helps your body utilize the iron present in your diet"
What criteria do you utilize in selecting employees?在筛选雇员时你使用什么标准？
In order to utilize land more fully, they adopted close planting.为了更充分利用土地，他们采取了密植的办法。

vacate

[və'keɪt], [və'keɪt]


Image Search
v. 空出；让出
leave (a place that one previously occupied).
give up (a position or office).
cancel or annul (a judgment, contract, or charge).
"rooms must be vacated by noon on the last day of your vacation"
"he will vacate a job in government sales"
You might envision passengers standing and waiting for others to vacate a seat so that they may limber up.你能想象到乘客们站立着等待其他人空出座位，那么他们就能放松下了。

vacillate

['væsəleɪt], ['væsəleɪt]


Image Search
v. 游移不定；踌躇；犹豫
alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
"I had for a time vacillated between teaching and journalism"
She vacillated between hope and fear.她时而抱有希望，时而心存恐惧。
But a few cadres started to vacillate.但是,也有少数干部起了波动。
You are bound to vacillate at times.有时你肯定还是会犹豫不决。
You can tell when they're stressed out, they'll equivocate and vacillate.当他们压力过大时，你是可以辨别出来的，因为他们会支支吾吾、犹豫不决。

vagabond

['væɡəbɒnd], ['væɡəbɑːnd]


Image Search
n. 流浪汉；无业游民
adj. 流浪的；居无定所的
a person who wanders from place to place without a home or job.
a rascal; a rogue.
having no settled home.
wander about as or like a vagabond.
The vagabond began to regret his waste of time.这个流浪汉开始后悔他虚度了光阴。
He leads a vagabond life.他过着流浪生活。

valiant

['væliənt], ['væliənt]


Image Search
adj. 勇敢的；英勇的
n. 勇士；勇敢的人
possessing or showing courage or determination.
"she made a valiant effort to hold her anger in check"
Let's hail to the valiant victors.让我们向勇敢的胜利者致敬！
A large reception was held in honor of the valiant explorers.为勇敢的探险家们举行了一个盛大的招待会。
The valiant hero saved the little girl's life.那个英勇的英雄拯救了小女孩的生命。
The man put up a valiant fight for victory.这个人为了赢得胜利进行了英勇的斗争。
To a valiant heart nothing is impossible.勇士面前无难事。
The man was also a valiant warrior, but he was a leper.他又是大能的勇士，只是长了大麻疯。
Let's hail to the valiant victors.让我们向勇敢的胜利者致敬！
A large reception was held in honor of the valiant explorers.为勇敢的探险家们举行了一个盛大的招待会。

vandalism

['vændəlɪzəm], ['vændəlɪzəm]


Image Search
n. 【U】故意破坏公物（艺术或文化的等）的行为
action involving deliberate destruction of or damage to public or private property.
Vandalism used to be a rare occurrence here.过去这里很少发生故意破坏公物的事。
The school suffered from widespread vandalism.这所学校遭受广泛的野蛮破坏。
However, vandalism and theft are criminal offenses.然而，故意破坏和偷窃是犯罪行为。

variable

['veəriəbl], ['veriəbl]


Image Search
adj. 可变的；易变的
n. 变量；易变的东西
not consistent or having a fixed pattern; liable to change.
(of a wind) tending to change direction.
(of a quantity) able to assume different numerical values.
(of a species) liable to deviate from the typical color or form, or to occur in different colors or forms.
able to be changed or adapted.
(of a gear) designed to give varying ratios or speeds.
an element, feature, or factor that is liable to vary or change.
a quantity that during a calculation is assumed to vary or be capable of varying in value.
a data item that may take on more than one value during the runtime of a program.
short for variable star.
the region of light, variable winds to the north of the northeast trade winds or (in the southern hemisphere) between the southeast trade winds and the westerlies.
"the quality of hospital food is highly variable"
"the drill has variable speed"
"there are too many variables involved to make any meaningful predictions"
Prices are variable according to the rate of exchange.物价会随汇率而变动。
His mood is as variable as the weather.他的情绪如天气般反覆无常。
The quality of the hotel food is distinctly variable.这个旅馆的饭菜有时很好有时很差.
The temperature is a variable in the experiment.在该实验中温度是个变量。
With so many variables, the exact cost is difficult to estimate.由于有许多可变因素,很难准确地估算出成本。
All these variables can affect a student's performance.所有这些变数都会影响学生的成绩。

[vend], [vend]


Image Search
v. 叫卖；出售
offer (small items, especially food) for sale, especially either from a stall or from a slot machine.
sell (something).
"there was a man vending sticky cakes and ices"
A vending machine.投币或自动售货机
A roll of postage stamps prepared for use in a vending machine.一卷邮票准备用于自动售货机的一卷邮票

veneration

[ˌvenə'reɪʃn], [ˌvenə'reɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 崇敬
great respect; reverence.
"the traditional veneration of saints"
The relics were objects of veneration/were held in veneration.这些遗物是备受崇敬之物.
Her veneration for traditional learning never wavered.她对传统学问的敬意从未动摇。

veracity

[və'ræsəti], [və'ræsəti]


Image Search
n. 真实性；诚实
conformity to facts; accuracy.
habitual truthfulness.
"officials expressed doubts concerning the veracity of the story"
"voters should be concerned about his veracity and character"
I don't doubt the veracity of your report.我毫不怀疑你报告中的真实性。
The chairman disallowed the veracity of his report.主席不承认他的报道的真实性。
There is no question of his veracity.他的诚实是毫无疑问的。
I can testify to this man's veracity and good character.我可以作证,此人诚实可靠,品德良好。

verge

[vɜːdʒ], [vɜːrdʒ]


Image Search
v. 接近；濒于；下沉；趋于
v. 处在...的边沿
n. 边缘；界限；权杖
an edge or border.
an extreme limit beyond which something specified will happen.
a grass edging such as that by the side of a road or path.
an edge of tiles projecting over a gable.
approach (something) closely; be close or similar to (something).
a wand or rod carried before a bishop or dean as an emblem of office.
incline in a certain direction or toward a particular state.
"they came down to the verge of the lake"
"I was on the verge of tears"
"despair verging on the suicidal"
"his style verged into the art nouveau school"
The path verges on the edge of a precipice.这条小径濒临断崖的边缘。
He is verging on a breakdown.他正濒临精神崩溃。
The sun was verging towards the horizon.太阳向地平线下降。
The economy verges toward inflation.经济倾向于通货膨胀。
Her land verges on the neighboring township.她的土地与邻镇相连。
The country's economy is on the verge of collapse.这个国家的经济已到了崩溃的边缘。
Large numbers of people had to struggle on the verge of starvation.那时许多人不得不挣扎在饥饿的边缘。
The little boy walked along the grass verge, trying not to step into the field.这个小男孩沿着草地的边上走,以防踩到地里。
The old man was on the verge of eighty.那老人已年近八十。

veritable

['verɪtəbl], ['verɪtəbl]


Image Search
adj. 真实的；确实的；真正的
used as an intensifier, often to qualify a metaphor.
"the early 1970s witnessed a veritable price explosion"
This campaign took on the proportions of a veritable war against the peasantry .这次运动很大部份是反农民的真实的战争。
The show is a veritable reservoir of new talent.这个演出真是新秀集萃。
We found ourselves in the midst of a veritable fairyland.我们发现我们在名副其实的仙境中。
It was not easy to work in the shed; in winter it was a veritable ice-box.在这木棚里工作可不轻松，冬天简直是个冰箱。
The public gave her a veritable ovation.观众给了她一个真正的哄堂喝彩。
This book is a veritable feast for the mind.这是本给心灵带来真正快乐的书。

versatile

['vɜːsətaɪl], ['vɜːrsətl]


Image Search
adj. 多才多艺的；通用的；多功能的
able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
changeable; inconstant.
"a versatile sewing machine"
Versatile actors can play all kinds of roles.多才多艺的演员能演各种类型的角色。
He is one of the most versatile actors.他是最多才多艺的演员之一。
These cotton towels are quite versatile for this reason.鉴于这点,这些毛巾都是通用的。
I bought a versatile kitchen machine last month.我上个月买了一部多功能的厨房用机器.
This knife is actually a highly versatile tool.这把小刀实际上是一个多功能的工具。
Plastics are a kind of versatile material in industry.在工业中,塑料是一种多用途材料。

vertigo

['vɜːtɪɡəʊ], ['vɜːrtɪɡoʊ]


Image Search
n. 眩晕
a sensation of whirling and loss of balance, associated particularly with looking down from a great height, or caused by disease affecting the inner ear or the vestibular nerve; giddiness.
It is very important to determine if vertigo truly exists.要确定是否真的有眩晕困扰是十分重要的。

vibrant

['vaɪbrənt], ['vaɪbrənt]


Image Search
adj. 震颤的；响亮的；充满活力的；精力充沛的；(色彩)鲜明的
full of energy and enthusiasm.
quivering; pulsating.
(of color) bright and striking.
(of sound) strong or resonating.
"a vibrant cosmopolitan city"
"Rose was vibrant with anger"
"a vibrant male voice"
The leaves were vibrant in the breeze.叶子在微风中抖动。
His vibrant voice commove the air.他响亮的声音振动了空气。
The city is vibrant with life.这城市充满生机。
She was vibrant with health and enthusiasm.她健康活泼生气勃勃。
He always uses vibrant colours in his paintings.他在画中总是使用鲜明的色彩。

viewpoint

['vjuːpɔɪnt], ['vjuːpɔɪnt]


Image Search
n. 观点；看法
another term for point of view.
I look at this problem from a different viewpoint.我从不同的观点来看这个问题。
You always depend on an obsolete viewpoint.你老是信赖一个过时的观点。
Either viewpoint must lead to the same answer.任何一种看法都应该导致同一答案。
She will have her own viewpoint on the matter.她对这个问题会有她自己的看法。

vigilant

['vɪdʒɪlənt], ['vɪdʒɪlənt]


Image Search
adj. 警戒的；警惕的
keeping careful watch for possible danger or difficulties.
"the burglar was spotted by vigilant neighbors"
We must keep an vigilant eye upon imperialism.我们必须对帝国主义保持警戒。
A pilot must be vigilant at all times.飞行员必须随时保持警惕。
The night shift has to be doubly vigilant.值夜班要加倍警惕。
The British Prime Minister Gordon Brown has urged people to be vigilant against the potential terrorist attack.英国首相戈登.

vigorous

['vɪɡərəs], ['vɪɡərəs]


Image Search
adj. 精力充沛的；有力的；元气旺盛的
strong, healthy, and full of energy.
characterized by or involving physical strength, effort, or energy.
(of language) forceful.
"vigorous aerobic exercise"
"a vigorous denial"
Old as he is, he is none the less vigorous and active.虽然他年纪很大了，他仍然精力充沛。
He never ceased to chase after his dream in his vigorous youth.在精力充沛的年轻时代他从未停止过追求自己的梦想。
She gave the floor a vigorous sponge all over.她用海绵把地板 使劲儿擦了一遍。
He uttered several vigorous expletives when he dropped the iron on his foot.他的熨斗掉下砸在脚上，他随口骂了几声。
These corn plants are very vigorous.这些玉米秧正茁壮生长。

vivacious

[vɪ'veɪʃəs], [vɪ'veɪʃəs]


Image Search
adj. 活泼的
(especially of a woman) attractively lively and animated.
She is an artless, vivacious girl.她是一个天真活泼的女孩。
The picture has a vivacious artistic conception.这幅画气韵生动。

vivid

['vɪvɪd], ['vɪvɪd]


Image Search
adj. 生动的；鲜艳的；栩栩如生的
producing powerful feelings or strong, clear images in the mind.
(of a color) intensely deep or bright.
(of a person or animal) lively and vigorous.
"memories of that evening were still vivid"
This place conjures up vivid memories.这个地方使人回忆起许多生动的往事。
My daughter is a child with vivid imagination.我女儿是一个想象力活跃的孩子。
This girl gave a vivid description of the event.那女孩对这件事作了一番生动的描述。
Only the vivid red hair ever stood out.只有鲜艳的红头发非常令人注目。
The actresses were wearing vivid historical costumes.女演员们穿着鲜艳的古装。
The new varieties have very vivid designs and beautiful colors.那新产品图案新颖，色泽鲜艳。
Television presents a vivid world in front of us.电视在我们面前展示出一个栩栩如生的世界。
Dickens'novels are full of vivid characterization.狄更斯的小说中充满了栩栩如生的人物形象。
The sculpture is really very vivid.真是被雕刻得栩栩如生啊。

vocation

[vəʊ'keɪʃn], [voʊ'keɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 职业；行业；使命
a strong feeling of suitability for a particular career or occupation.
a person's employment or main occupation, especially regarded as particularly worthy and requiring great dedication.
a trade or profession.
"not all of us have a vocation to be nurses or doctors"
"her vocation as a poet"
She chose nursing as her vocation.她选择护士为职业。
He was equipped with knowledge for the vocation.他具有这项职业的学识。
She struggled for years to find her true vocation.她多年来苦苦寻找真正适合自己的职业。
The industry is facing vocation conformity in China.在中国,这种工业面临行业整合。
Teaching children is a vocation.教育儿童是一项使命。

voracious

[və'reɪʃəs], [və'reɪʃəs]


Image Search
adj. 狼吞虎咽的；贪婪的；贪吃的；求知欲强的
wanting or devouring great quantities of food.
having a very eager approach to an activity.
"he had a voracious appetite"
"his voracious reading of literature"
After swimming, I find that I have a voracious appetite.游完泳后,我发现我的食欲大增。
They are aggressively territorial and voracious to fault.好斗与贪婪也是它们的弱点。
Kids can have voracious appetites.小孩会很贪吃。
He was a voracious reader of the translations of Eastern religious works.他如饥似渴地阅读东方宗教著作的译本。

vow

[vaʊ], [vaʊ]


Image Search
n. 誓约
v. 发誓
a solemn promise.
a set of promises committing one to a prescribed role, calling, or course of action, typically to marriage or a monastic career.
solemnly promise to do a specified thing.
dedicate to someone or something, especially a deity.
"he vowed that his government would not tolerate a repeat of the disorder"
"I vowed myself to this enterprise"
You'd better carry out your solemn vow.你最好是履行你那庄严的誓约。
All the men took a vow of loyalty to their leader.所有士兵都发誓效忠他们的指挥官。
Once he took the vow his loyalty never wavered.他一旦宣了誓，他就一直忠贞不渝。
Catholic priests take a vow of celibacy.天主教神父发誓不结婚。
I vowed never to reveal the secret.我发誓决不泄漏这一秘密。
I vow to give my time and strength to this case.我发誓将我的时间和精力致力于这一事业。

voyage

['vɔɪɪdʒ], ['vɔɪɪdʒ]


Image Search
n. 航行；旅程
v. 航行；旅行
a long journey involving travel by sea or in space.
go on a long journey, typically by sea or in space.
sail over or along (a sea or river).
"a six-year voyage to Jupiter"
"he has voyaged through places like Venezuela and Peru"
This is the virgin voyage of the ship.这是这艘船的处女航。
The ship hit heavy fog on its voyage.船在航行时碰上了大雾。
She went on a long sea voyage.她乘船在海上长途旅行。
Once the voyage comes to an end.旅程结束之际。
Happiness is a voyage, not a destination.快乐是旅程，不是目的地。
My dream is to voyage around the world in a hot air balloon.我的梦想是乘着热气球周游世界。
They planned to voyage across the Pacific Ocean.他们计划做穿越太平洋的旅行。

wade

[weɪd], [weɪd]


Image Search
v. 跋涉；涉水
n. 跋涉
walk through water or another liquid or soft substance.
walk through (something filled with water).
read laboriously through (a long piece of writing).
get involved in (something) vigorously or forcefully.
make a vigorous attack or intervention.
an act of wading.
"we waded ashore"
"firefighters waded the waist-deep flood water"
"he waded into the yelling, fighting crowd"
"Nicola waded in and grabbed the baby"
I wade down a shallow pebbly stream daily.我每天沿着一条浅的有卵石的小溪跋涉。
I assume that Wade discussed the quality issues with you.我承担那跋涉与你讨论质量议题。
We'll wade the stream at its shallowest point.我们将在小河最浅的地方涉水过去。
A child can wade across them without a parent's cautions.无须父母的告诫，孩子们就可以涉水而过。
I wade down a shallow pebbly stream daily.我每天沿着一条浅的有卵石的小溪跋涉。
I assume that Wade discussed the quality issues with you.我承担那跋涉与你讨论质量议题。

wane

[weɪn], [weɪn]


Image Search
n. 衰落；亏缺；变弱
v. 变小；亏缺；呈下弦
(of the moon) have a progressively smaller part of its visible surface illuminated, so that it appears to decrease in size.
(especially of a condition or feeling) decrease in vigor, power, or extent; become weaker.
the amount by which a plank or log is beveled or falls short of a squared shape.
"confidence in the dollar waned"
The empire was on the wane after its period of prosperity.帝国经过全盛以后逐渐衰落。
By now the power of the Roman Empire was on the wane.到这时，罗马帝国已日益衰败。
Why should the moon have wax and wane?为什么一定会月有阴晴圆缺?
The sick man's strength is on the wane.病人的体力越来越弱。
The government's popularity is on the wane.政府的声望日益低落。
As time went on, so their hopes began to wane.随着时间的消逝，他们的希望开始变得渺茫。
The moon waxes and wanes every month.月亮每个月都有盈亏。
When the moon is at its full, it begins to wane.月盈则亏。

wax

[wæks], [wæks]


Image Search
n. 蜡；蜂蜡
vt. (用蜡)涂
vi. 变圆
a sticky yellowish moldable substance secreted by honeybees as the material of honeycomb; beeswax.
a white translucent material obtained by bleaching and purifying beeswax and used for such purposes as making candles, modeling, and as a basis of polishes.
a viscous substance, typically a lipid or hydrocarbon.
earwax.
used in reference to phonograph records.
cover or treat (something) with wax or a similar substance, typically to polish or protect it.
remove unwanted hair from (a part of the body) by applying wax and then peeling off the wax and hairs together.
make a recording of.
(of the moon between new and full) have a progressively larger part of its visible surface illuminated, increasing its apparent size.
become larger or stronger.
begin to speak or write about something in the specified manner.
a fit of anger.
"he didn't get on wax until 1959"
"I washed and waxed the floor"
"he waxed a series of tracks that emphasized his lead guitar work"
"his anger waxed"
"they waxed lyrical about the old days"
"she is in a wax about the delay to the wedding"
Blobs of wax covered the candlestick.烛台上全是一团团的蜡。
He is modeling a unicorn in wax .他在用蜡制作独角兽。
They bought wax and honey up by the great.他们大量购进蜜蜡和蜂蜜。
Why did she have to wax the floors herself?她干什么非要自己动手给地板打腊?
I wax my boots chiefly to waterproof them.我给靴子打蜡主要是为了防水。
The moon is waxing.月亮越来越圆。

waylay

[weɪ'leɪ], [weɪ'leɪ]


Image Search

He waylaid me with a request for a loan.他等我经过时拦住我向我借钱。
The patrol was waylaid by bandits.巡逻队遭到土匪伏击。
